story:
Welcome to my Indiegogo page for this year's Hamburg Marathon.


I'll be running the Hamburg marathon on the 4th May. This year i'll be sharing donations between two good causes:

Firstly, donations will go to Itapoa Reserve, a rainforest project in Ecuador. Every now and then you meet someone in life whose dedication and devotion in the face of adversity humbles you. Raul and his project does just that. $16,800 has already been raised to purchase 50 hectares of rainforest and save it from the logging companies. We need to push this to around $22,000 to get the legal work done to turn it into a national reserve. If I could raise just $500 that would really help the final push. Spread the word and we could do much better.

I would be here all night if I tried to write why this is such a good cause so if you would like to know more here are some links for you:

www.itapoareserve.com

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Itapoa-Tropical-Rainforest-Reserve/161706220523717?fref=ts

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kBNrQJpmtZU


Royal National Lifeboat Institution


If saving the rainforest isn't your thing, maybe the RNLI is. I'll also be running in memory of friend who sadly lost his fight with cancer recently. His favoured charity is the RNLI. I thought it would be a nice idea if we could raise a bit for them too.

So who's willing to donate the cost of a beer in return for me slogging 42kms? If you have a preference as to where your money goes please email me waynethacker@fastmail.co.uk and i'll be sure to see your donation goes to the right place.

Check back here and i'll try to update the fund raising along the way.

Cheers, Wayne

story:
Why Worm Poop?

Worm poop is a high value material which, when blended with soil, can restore soil tilth. With only up to 20% of worm castings in the soil, plants also:

  • germinate better,
  • grow faster,
  • and produce higher yields.

Worm castings also improve soil aeration and drainage, and increase water retention in the soil. 

 

About us

Source One Serenity was founded by Elena and Rusty Lininger, a post-9/11 veteran who wanted to share the healing power of nature with other vets. It was his gratitude for being saved through fly fishing.

Due to the lack of resources in rural settings and higher rates of suicides, homelessness and other health and social issues among our veterans, the activities by Source One Serenity are indisputable. Since 2016, we have established:

  • a fly fishing program (incl. weekly fly tying classes at the Roseburg VA Medical Center, fly fishing retreats and week-long schools) 
  • a hiking program for women veterans on the North Umpqua Trail
  • and land stewardship projects.

We are proud to say that we served more than 400 veterans and brought hope to them to find their purpose.

 

Our solution to find a sustainable revenue to fund these healing outdoor activities for veterans became a social enterprise worm farm HealTerra.

It furthers our mission of:

 

 

 

Since November 2017, we have run a test phase with small household bins. The test phase provided us with an opportunity to do a thorough research about vermicomposting, to write a thorough business plan, and to distribute free samples to local growers.

During this phase:

 

 

Become a Founder and Make an Impact!

 

By participating in this crowdfunding campaign, you'll be a founder of the worm farm to make an impact on the community! Everyone who participates at any reward level will be a founder. All founder's names will be on our founder's wall (unless you want to stay anonymous)!

 

 

You will be proud to use worm castings and being an advocate of this natural product, which improves and restores our soil, and nourishes plants without any harmful additives!

 

What will we do with the funds raised? 

 

Right now we are raising money for equipment, and specifically, for building a digester (about 8 ft x 100 ft) which will process up to 1 ton of food waste every day! This type of digester  is a large-scale flow-through vermicomposting system. This decision is based on the numerous advantages, such as its efficiency and profitability.

Our adviser Dan Holcombe from Philomath, OR who has been at the forefront of vermicomposting industry, has designed this system for his own worm farm, which operated successfully in Portland area for about 20 years. Dan's system is used by several worm farms throughout the country. Small, household type bins take 2-4 months to harvest worm castings, but automated flow-through systems take only one to two months. Therefore, these systems are expected to meet the challenge of recovering large volumes of food waste via advances in technology what aligns with our goals to prevent larger amount of food waste to be landfilled. 

The worm digester will be placed in a greenhouse at the proposed location of the Glide Transfer Site which is a serene place surrounded by forest. 

The total amount of fabricating a digester by a local welder including expenses for steel is $56,000. We have already raised $25,000 through grants. 

 

What else have we already accomplished?

 

It has been exciting and satisfying to work with our community including our local government, businesses and local citizens on establishing our worm farm.  During the planning phase which included advising, marketing and purchasing blueprints of the digester we raised $22,150 thanks to: the Cow Creek Umpqua Indian Foundation,  Umpqua Business Center, The Ford Family Foundation, Walmart Community Fund and individual donors. 

 

 

At our current stage concerning securing funding for equipment (digester) and construction (concrete floor and greenhouse), we have already raised $30,000! 

 

What Rewards Will You Get?

 

As we are already harvesting worm poop in smaller quantities, the first ones will receive it in the next weeks as long as supply lasts!

 

*1 gallon is approximately 5 lb.

If you are not a gardener/farmer and don't need worm castings, or cannot contribute, please help us spread the word and tell about it to your friends and neighbors. We will appreciate it a lot! 

 

Testimonials:

 

"Your worm poop is awesome! I don't need anything else for my plants."

Garry, an avid gardener in Roseburg, OR

 

"The ones [plants] with your worm castings are definitely a shade or two darker in green which is a good sign. No burning which is another good sign. Looks like you guys are on the right track!"

Sean, a farm owner in Eugene, OR

story:
>>>>>>>>>>>>>> ITALIANO IN BASSO, ENGLISH BELOW <<<<<<<<<<<<<<
 

Hallo wir sind Claire & Margit,
wir leben in Südtirol und hier befindet sich In der Stadt Brixen, wie durch ein Wunder, ein letztes Stück Auwald - und zwar mitten in der Industriezone.

Der Wald ist mit seiner lebendigen Kronenstruktur, seiner Pflanzenvielfalt und seinem reichen Boden voller Pilze, ein dringend schützenswerter Lebensraum unzähliger, zum Teil gefährdeter Arten. Wir lieben diesen Auwald & möchten gemeinsam mit dir alles tun, um ihn davor zu bewahren abgesägt und durch ein Industriegebäude ersetzt zu werden.

Der Brixner Gemeindeausschuss hat das geplante Gebäude der Firma ‘Progress’, dem der Auwald weichen soll, zwar schon genehmigt, aber noch ist es nicht zu spät!

Es stehen noch weitere Entscheidungen aus und gemeinsam mit dem Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen ist nun alles vorbereitet, um Rekurs einzuleiten.

Was wir jetzt brauchen

...deine Hilfe, die Gerichtskosten zu decken. Mit deiner Spende kannst du direkt mitwirken, dieses wertvolle Lebewesen Wald vor der Abholzung bewahren und aktiv für deine Werte und für’s Leben einstehen.

Gib was du kannst und weit mehr, als du eigentlich geben würdest und noch mehr und spüre, wie deine Großzügigkeit in den Wald, in die Erde und in die zukünftigen Generationen fließt. Danke dir, für deinen Beitrag und dein Mitgestalten unserer aller Zukunft.

 

Der Plan

Konkret benötigen wir Unterstützung, um folgende Dinge zu finanzieren:

Studium der Causa, Einleitung des Prozesses inclusive Erstverhandlung

→  5.690 EURO

Sicherheitspolster für Eventualitäten und weitere Verhandlungen 

→ + ca. 4.400 EURO

Indiegogo Plattformgebühr

→ + ca. 500 EURO

 

Wohin geht das Geld der Crowdfunding Kampagne? 
Direkt auf’s Onlus-Spendenkonto vom ‘Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen’ von da aus wird ein Teil der Summe dem Anwalt zur Einleitung vom Rekurs am regionalen Verwaltungsgericht in Bozen überwiesen. Das Sicherheitspolster bleibt vorerst auf dem Konto des Onlus Vereins und wird für Eventualitäten verwendet, bis der Prozess abgeschlossen ist. Wenn der Wald sicher ist, und noch etwas übrig ist, kann das Geld gemäß der Satzung des Artenschutzzentrums für den Erhalt der Biodiversität eingesetzt werden. 

 

WICHTIG: Brauchst du einen Spendenbeleg vom Artenschutzzentrum?
In dem Fall muss das Geld direkt auf’s Konto überwiesen werden. Bitte kontaktiere Claire (claire@claireidansun.com) für deinen Spendenbeleg & überweise deine Spende an:

Onlus-Spendenkonto Raiffeisenkasse Bruneck: Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen EO
Überweisungsgrund: 'Spende Auwald’ 
IBAN: IT04H0803558242000300242012
Swift-Code: RZSBFT21005
Steuer Nr. 92024840214

 

Wie du sonst noch helfen kannst

Uns ist klar, dass manche Menschen einfach nicht finanziell beitragen können, aber das bedeutet nicht, dass sie nichts tun können. Jeder kann mitwirken die Kampagne in sozialen Medien zu verbreiten, mit Freunden und Familie zu sprechen und jeden Baumliebhaber zu erreichen, den du kennst, um ihn wissen zu lassen, dass er helfen kann, einen Wald zu retten! Wenn du Einflussnehmer oder größere Spender kennst, die daran interessiert sind, dieses Projekt zu unterstützen, nimm bitte Kontakt mit uns auf! Danke, dass du uns hilfst, diesen geliebten Wald zu retten!

  • Teile die Kampagne in persönlichen Nachrichten (Whatsapp und Messenger) und inspiriere dein Umfeld mit deiner ganz eigenen Sichtweise, was dir dieser Wald bedeutet! 
     
  • Mach ein Facebook Live über die Kampagne auf deiner Seite wo du Menschen einlädst großzügig zu spenden und mitzuwirken.
     
  • 'like' & teile ‘Atem für's Leben: normalising Earth-based culture’ auf Facebook.
     
  • Sprich über den Auwald, informiere dich über die Funktion von Wäldern (auf unserer Fb Seite findest du einige von uns empfohlene Quellen) 
     
  • Kommentiere und & interagiere mit unseren Inhalten (das hilft uns bei der Sichtbarkeit) - bring dich aktiv mit deinen Gefühlen ein, du wirst genauso gebraucht wie du bist! 
     
  • Werde Teil unserer Atem für's Leben Community auf Facebook, ein Ort der Unterstützung, um für den Auwald aufzustehen, denn du musst es nicht alleine tun. Die Gruppe ist ein lebendiger Forschungs- und Bildungsraum für die Kultur der Beziehung mit der Erde.
     

Weitere Infos zum Auwald

Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen

Facebook Seite der Kampagne 

Facebook Seite SOS Auwald
 

Get involved +39 329 924 6945
 

 

Ciao, siamo Claire & Margit,
viviamo in Alto Adige e qui nella città di Bressanone c’è rimasto, come per miracolo, un ultimo pezzo di bosco ripariale - proprio nel mezzo della zona industriale.

Con la sua struttura, la varietà di piante e il suo terreno ricco di funghi, il bosco è un habitat che ha urgentemente bisogno della nostra protezione. È la casa di innumerevoli specie, alcune delle quali sono in pericolo di estinzione. Noi amiamo questo bosco e insieme a te vogliamo fare tutto il possibile per evitare che venga abbattuto e sostituito da un edificio industriale.

La giunta comunale di Bressanone ha già approvato il progetto di costruzione dell a ditta "Progress", a cui il bosco deve cedere il passo, ma non è troppo tardi!

Altre decisioni devono ancora essere prese e, insieme all 'Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen/centro di protezione delle specie', abbiamo preparato tutto per avviare un ricorso! 

 

Cosa ci serve

...abbiamo bisogno del tuo aiuto per coprire le spese legali. Con tua donazione contribuisci direttamente a salvare questo prezioso bosco e di mostrare attivamente i tuoi valori, difendendo la vita. 

Dai quello che puoi, e se riesci molto più di quanto daresti di solito e ancora di più e poi fermati a sentire come la tua generosità fluisce nella foresta, nella terra e nelle generazioni future. Grazie, per il tuo contributo e per creare il nostro futuro.
 

Il piano

In particolare, abbiamo bisogno di sostegno per finanziare

Studio del caso, avvio del processo, comprese le trattative iniziali

→ 5.690 EURO

Cuscino di sicurezza per le eventualità e per ulteriori trattative 

→ + ca. 4.400 EURO

Tassa per la piattaforma Indiegogo

→ + ca. 500 EURO
 

Dove vanno a finire i soldi del crowdfunding? 
Direttamente sul conto della Onlus dell'Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen, da lì una parte del denaro sarà trasferita all'avvocato per avviare il ricorso presso il tribunale amministrativo regionale di Bolzano. Per il momento il cuscino di sicurezza rimane sul conto dell'Associazione Onlus e sarà utilizzato per gli imprevisti fino al completamento del processo. Se la foresta è sicura, e c'è ancora qualcosa da fare, il denaro può essere utilizzato per la conservazione della biodiversità secondo gli statuti del Centro di protezione delle specie. 
 

IMPORTANTE SE HAI BISOGNO DI UNA RICEVUTA DI DONAZIONE
dal Centro Conservazione delle Specie? In questo caso il denaro deve essere trasferito direttamente sul conto - non su indiegogo. Si prega di contattare Claire (claire.idansun@gmail.com) per la ricevuta della donazione e di trasferire la donazione:

Conto onlus Banca Raiffeisen di Brunico: Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen EO
motivo del trasferimento: "Spende Auwald"
IBAN: IT04H0803558242000300242012
Swift-Code: RZSBFT21005
Codice fiscale 92024840214
 

Altri modi per aiutare

Ci rendiamo conto che alcune persone non possono contribuire finanziariamente, ma questo non significa che non si possa aiutare. Tutti possono contribuire a diffondere la notizia, condividerla sui social media, parlare con gli amici e la famiglia e contattare qualsiasi persona amante degli alberi che conosci per fargli sapere che può aiutare a salvare una foresta! Se conosci qualche persona influente o donatori più grandi interessati a sostenere questo progetto, contattateci!

  • Condividi la campagna in messaggi personali (Whatsapp e Messenger) e ispira chi ti circonda con la tua visione personale e con ciò che la foresta significa per te! 
     
  • parla del bosco e della campagna LIVE sulla tua pagina Facebook e invita le persone a donare generosamente. 
     
  • Metti ‘mi piace’ e condividi "Atem für's Leben: normalising Earth-based culture“ su Facebook, il luogo in cui si svolge la campagna.
     
  • Parla del bosco, scopri e informati sulla la funzione delle foreste (sulla nostra pagina Fb trovi alcune delle nostre fonti consigliate) 
     
  • Commenta e interagisci con i nostri contenuti su Facebook (questo ci aiuta con la visibilità) - partecipa attivamente con i tuoi sentimenti, abbiamo bisogno di te così come sei! 
     
  • Fai parte della nostra 'Atem für's Leben Community' su Facebook, un luogo di sostegno per difendere il bosco ripariale, perché non devi farlo da soli. Il gruppo è uno spazio vivo di ricerca ed educazione.

 

Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen

Facebook del crowdfunding

Facebook SOS Auwald
 

Get involved +39 329 924 6945
 

 

Hi, we are Claire & Margit,
we live in South Tyrol and here, in the city of Bressanone there is, by miracle, a last piece of flood plain forest - in the middle of the industrial zone.

With its vibrant crown structure, its plant diversity and its rich soil full of mushrooms, the forest is a habitat urgently needing our protection. It's the home of countless species, some of which are endangered. We love this flood plain forest & together with you we want to do everything we can to prevent it from being logged and replaced by an industrial building.

The municipal committee of Brixen has already approved the planned building of the company 'Progress', which the flood plain forest is to give way to, but it is not too late!

Further decisions have yet to be made and, together with the 'Artenschutzzentrum/Species Protection Center St. Georgen', we've got everything  ready now to lodge an appeal against approvals!

 

What we need

... your help to cover the legal fees. With your donation you can directly contribute to saving this precious living forest from deforestation and actively stand up for your values and for life. Thank you for being here! 

Give what you can, with your possibilities give far more than you would usually give and even more and then stop to feel how your generosity flows into the forest, into Earth and into future generations. Thank you, for your contribution and for helping to shape our future.

 

The Plan

Specifically, we need support to finance the following:

Study of the case, initiation of the process including the initial negotiation

→ 5.690 EURO

Safety cushion for eventualities and further negotiations 

→ + approx. 4.400 EURO

Indiegogo platform fee

→ + approx. 500 EURO

 

Where does your crowdfunding money go? 
Directly to the onlus-donation account of the Species Protection Centre (Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen), from where a part of the money is transferred to the lawyer to initiate an appeal at the regional administrative court in Bozen. For the time being, the safety cushion remains on the Onlus-Association’s account and will be used for any eventualities until the process is completed. When the forest is safe, and there is still something left, the money can be used for the conservation of biodiversity according to the statutes of the Species Protection Centre. 

 

IMPORTANT: IF YOU NEED A DONATION RECEIPT from the Species Protection Centre
In this case the money has to be transferred directly to the account - not through Indiegogo. Please contact Claire (claire@claireidansun.com) for your donation receipt and transfer your donation to:

Onlus donation account, Raiffeisen bank Bruneck: Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen EO
reason for transfer: 'Spende Auwald'
IBAN: IT04H0803558242000300242012
Swift-Code: RZSBFT21005
tax no. 92024840214

 

Other ways you can help

We realise that some people just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Everyone can spread the word, share this on social media, talk to your friends and family, and reach out to any tree-loving individual that you know to let them know that they can help save a forest! If you know any influencers or larger donors interested in supporting this project please get in touch! Thank you for helping us save our beloved forest!

  • Share the campaign in personal messages (Whatsapp and Messenger) and inspire those around you with your very own view of what the forest means to you! 
     
  • help us by talking about the campaign LIVE on your Facebook page and invite people to give generously.
     
  • like' & share ‘Atem für’s Leben: normalising earth-based culture' on Facebook, the place where the campaign is happening.
     
  • Talk about the alluvial forest, find out about the function of forests (on our Fb page you can find some of our recommended sources) 
     
  • Comment and & interact with our content on Facebook (this helps us with visibility) - get actively involved with your feelings, you are needed just as you are! 

 

Get involved +39 329 924 6945

Uns ist klar, dass manche Menschen einfach nicht finanziell beitragen können, aber das bedeutet nicht, dass sie nichts tun können. Jeder kann mitwirken die Kampagne in sozialen Medien zu verbreiten, mit Freunden und Familie zu sprechen und jeden Baumliebhaber zu erreichen, den du kennst, um ihn wissen zu lassen, dass er helfen kann, einen Wald zu retten! Wenn du Einflussnehmer oder größere Spender kennst, die daran interessiert sind, dieses Projekt zu unterstützen, nimm bitte Kontakt mit uns auf! Danke, dass du uns hilfst, diesen geliebten Wald zu retten!

Teile die Kampagne in persönlichen Nachrichten (Whatsapp und Messenger) und inspiriere dein Umfeld mit deiner ganz eigenen Sichtweise, was dir dieser Wald bedeutet!  
Mach ein Facebook Live über die Kampagne auf deiner Seite wo du Menschen einlädst großzügig zu spenden und mitzuwirken. 
'like' & teile ‘Atem für's Leben: normalising Earth-based culture’ auf Facebook. 
Sprich über den Auwald, informiere dich über die Funktion von Wäldern (auf unserer Fb Seite findest du einige von uns empfohlene Quellen)  
Kommentiere und & interagiere mit unseren Inhalten (das hilft uns bei der Sichtbarkeit) - bring dich aktiv mit deinen Gefühlen ein, du wirst genauso gebraucht wie du bist!  
Werde Teil unserer Atem für's Leben Community auf Facebook, ein Ort der Unterstützung, um für den Auwald aufzustehen, denn du musst es nicht alleine tun. Die Gruppe ist ein lebendiger Forschungs- und Bildungsraum für die Kultur der Beziehung mit der Erde. 

Weitere Infos zum Auwald
Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen
Facebook Seite der Kampagne 
Facebook Seite SOS Auwald 
Get involved +39 329 924 6945 

 
Ciao, siamo Claire & Margit,viviamo in Alto Adige e qui nella città di Bressanone c’è rimasto, come per miracolo, un ultimo pezzo di bosco ripariale - proprio nel mezzo della zona industriale.
Con la sua struttura, la varietà di piante e il suo terreno ricco di funghi, il bosco è un habitat che ha urgentemente bisogno della nostra protezione. È la casa di innumerevoli specie, alcune delle quali sono in pericolo di estinzione. Noi amiamo questo bosco e insieme a te vogliamo fare tutto il possibile per evitare che venga abbattuto e sostituito da un edificio industriale.
La giunta comunale di Bressanone ha già approvato il progetto di costruzione dell a ditta "Progress", a cui il bosco deve cedere il passo, ma non è troppo tardi!
Altre decisioni devono ancora essere prese e, insieme all 'Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen/centro di protezione delle specie', abbiamo preparato tutto per avviare un ricorso! 
 

Cosa ci serve
...abbiamo bisogno del tuo aiuto per coprire le spese legali. Con tua donazione contribuisci direttamente a salvare questo prezioso bosco e di mostrare attivamente i tuoi valori, difendendo la vita. 
Dai quello che puoi, e se riesci molto più di quanto daresti di solito e ancora di più e poi fermati a sentire come la tua generosità fluisce nella foresta, nella terra e nelle generazioni future. Grazie, per il tuo contributo e per creare il nostro futuro. 

Il piano
In particolare, abbiamo bisogno di sostegno per finanziare
Studio del caso, avvio del processo, comprese le trattative iniziali
→ 5.690 EURO
Cuscino di sicurezza per le eventualità e per ulteriori trattative 
→ + ca. 4.400 EURO
Tassa per la piattaforma Indiegogo
→ + ca. 500 EURO 
Dove vanno a finire i soldi del crowdfunding? Direttamente sul conto della Onlus dell'Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen, da lì una parte del denaro sarà trasferita all'avvocato per avviare il ricorso presso il tribunale amministrativo regionale di Bolzano. Per il momento il cuscino di sicurezza rimane sul conto dell'Associazione Onlus e sarà utilizzato per gli imprevisti fino al completamento del processo. Se la foresta è sicura, e c'è ancora qualcosa da fare, il denaro può essere utilizzato per la conservazione della biodiversità secondo gli statuti del Centro di protezione delle specie.  
IMPORTANTE SE HAI BISOGNO DI UNA RICEVUTA DI DONAZIONEdal Centro Conservazione delle Specie? In questo caso il denaro deve essere trasferito direttamente sul conto - non su indiegogo. Si prega di contattare Claire (claire.idansun@gmail.com) per la ricevuta della donazione e di trasferire la donazione:
Conto onlus Banca Raiffeisen di Brunico: Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen EOmotivo del trasferimento: "Spende Auwald"IBAN: IT04H0803558242000300242012Swift-Code: RZSBFT21005Codice fiscale 92024840214 

Altri modi per aiutare
Ci rendiamo conto che alcune persone non possono contribuire finanziariamente, ma questo non significa che non si possa aiutare. Tutti possono contribuire a diffondere la notizia, condividerla sui social media, parlare con gli amici e la famiglia e contattare qualsiasi persona amante degli alberi che conosci per fargli sapere che può aiutare a salvare una foresta! Se conosci qualche persona influente o donatori più grandi interessati a sostenere questo progetto, contattateci!

Condividi la campagna in messaggi personali (Whatsapp e Messenger) e ispira chi ti circonda con la tua visione personale e con ciò che la foresta significa per te!  
parla del bosco e della campagna LIVE sulla tua pagina Facebook e invita le persone a donare generosamente.  
Metti ‘mi piace’ e condividi "Atem für's Leben: normalising Earth-based culture“ su Facebook, il luogo in cui si svolge la campagna. 
Parla del bosco, scopri e informati sulla la funzione delle foreste (sulla nostra pagina Fb trovi alcune delle nostre fonti consigliate)  
Commenta e interagisci con i nostri contenuti su Facebook (questo ci aiuta con la visibilità) - partecipa attivamente con i tuoi sentimenti, abbiamo bisogno di te così come sei!  
Fai parte della nostra 'Atem für's Leben Community' su Facebook, un luogo di sostegno per difendere il bosco ripariale, perché non devi farlo da soli. Il gruppo è uno spazio vivo di ricerca ed educazione.

 
Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen
Facebook del crowdfunding
Facebook SOS Auwald 
Get involved +39 329 924 6945 

 

Hi, we are Claire & Margit, we live in South Tyrol and here, in the city of Bressanone there is, by miracle, a last piece of flood plain forest - in the middle of the industrial zone.
With its vibrant crown structure, its plant diversity and its rich soil full of mushrooms, the forest is a habitat urgently needing our protection. It's the home of countless species, some of which are endangered. We love this flood plain forest & together with you we want to do everything we can to prevent it from being logged and replaced by an industrial building.
The municipal committee of Brixen has already approved the planned building of the company 'Progress', which the flood plain forest is to give way to, but it is not too late!
Further decisions have yet to be made and, together with the 'Artenschutzzentrum/Species Protection Center St. Georgen', we've got everything  ready now to lodge an appeal against approvals!
 


What we need
... your help to cover the legal fees. With your donation you can directly contribute to saving this precious living forest from deforestation and actively stand up for your values and for life. Thank you for being here! 
Give what you can, with your possibilities give far more than you would usually give and even more and then stop to feel how your generosity flows into the forest, into Earth and into future generations. Thank you, for your contribution and for helping to shape our future.
 


The Plan
Specifically, we need support to finance the following:
Study of the case, initiation of the process including the initial negotiation
→ 5.690 EURO
Safety cushion for eventualities and further negotiations 
→ + approx. 4.400 EURO
Indiegogo platform fee
→ + approx. 500 EURO
 
Where does your crowdfunding money go? Directly to the onlus-donation account of the Species Protection Centre (Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen), from where a part of the money is transferred to the lawyer to initiate an appeal at the regional administrative court in Bozen. For the time being, the safety cushion remains on the Onlus-Association’s account and will be used for any eventualities until the process is completed. When the forest is safe, and there is still something left, the money can be used for the conservation of biodiversity according to the statutes of the Species Protection Centre. 
 
IMPORTANT: IF YOU NEED A DONATION RECEIPT from the Species Protection CentreIn this case the money has to be transferred directly to the account - not through Indiegogo. Please contact Claire (claire@claireidansun.com) for your donation receipt and transfer your donation to:
Onlus donation account, Raiffeisen bank Bruneck: Artenschutzzentrum St. Georgen EOreason for transfer: 'Spende Auwald'IBAN: IT04H0803558242000300242012Swift-Code: RZSBFT21005tax no. 92024840214
 


Other ways you can help
We realise that some people just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Everyone can spread the word, share this on social media, talk to your friends and family, and reach out to any tree-loving individual that you know to let them know that they can help save a forest! If you know any influencers or larger donors interested in supporting this project please get in touch! Thank you for helping us save our beloved forest!

Share the campaign in personal messages (Whatsapp and Messenger) and inspire those around you with your very own view of what the forest means to you!  
help us by talking about the campaign LIVE on your Facebook page and invite people to give generously. 
like' & share ‘Atem für’s Leben: normalising earth-based culture' on Facebook, the place where the campaign is happening. 
Talk about the alluvial forest, find out about the function of forests (on our Fb page you can find some of our recommended sources)  
Comment and & interact with our content on Facebook (this helps us with visibility) - get actively involved with your feelings, you are needed just as you are! 

 
Get involved +39 329 924 6945

story:
The Idea!

I am a computer systems engineer, and one day while driving in my car listening to KPFK in LA, I heard talk about a movie showing the plight of the world’s oceans, and plastics in the Pacific Garbage Patch. I thought to myself, what is so hard about cleaning them up?

As it turns out the plastics in our oceans can be very small and hard to collect, and even when you do collect them what are you to do with them? 

Most of the ideas I have read about, people just want to collect the waste, and transport it back to land where it can be processed. I thought what if you processed them right where you collected them?

My idea is to recycle an oil platform that is no longer being used by the oil industry, combine that with a machine purchased from Agilyx, and start producing synthetic crude oil from the plastics just floating in the ocean. 

 Oil platforms are decommissioned and then destroyed because they have to be reused or re-purposed. The derricks are capable of withstanding major storms and other related issues while floating in the gyres.

Oil recovery from plastics is already a proven technology that thanks to Agilyx, plastics that traditionally are not recyclable; even those that are mixed or contaminated can now have a profi­table recovery option. Here are three ways Agilyx accomplishes that:

  • Energy returned on energy invested – recovers fi­ve times more energy than is consumed by the process.

  • Financial value – produces synthetic crude oil a high value energy commodity, far out-pacing the BTU-equivalent price as electricity and leaves it in a convenient storable medium

  • Greenhouse gas emissions (GHG) – the crude oil produced has lower carbon intensity than traditional sources.  

What We Need & What You Get

The first thing I need to do is get the money to incorporate and start doing feasibility studies on this venture, I will be developing contacts with others that will help facilitate this project, and I am hoping to be at the first stages of actually putting this project in the ocean in 3 to 5 years.

I am thinking that what I need is 3 to 5 million dollars to really get things moving, but seeing as this is unproven and caries risk of failure I am asking for just 1 million to get the ball rolling.

  • 1 dollar contribution, Thank you so much for helping us move one step closer to production

  • 5 dollar contribution, a thank you on Facebook page

  • 10 dollar contribution, bumper sticker, or window decal, and a thank you on Facebook page

  • 100 dollar contribution, T-shirt, and a thank you on Facebook page

  • 500 dollar contribution, Polo-Shirt, and a personalized thank you on Facebook page

  • 1000 dollar contribution; a personalized thank you on Facebook, the bumper sticker, the polo-shirt, and a high end pen with the company logo.

  • 10000 dollar contribution, all of the 1000 dollar items, plus a 3 day all expenses trip to the platform once it is operational.
If I am unable to reach the goal then I will use what I do have to fund the research on this project, I really believe the answer to the problem is to process the plastics into something that is worth more than the plastic itself, so that it makes sense to ship that new product back to land.

The Impact

By being able to collect and transform the plastics into a commodity, it is more likely to succeed.  The plastics are going to be with us for years to come why not turn them into a resource rather than just letting them destroy our oceans and ecosystem.


    Risks & Challenges

    At this point I see two risks:

    1. Is it really feasible to put an oil platform in the middle of the ocean to collect this plastic, and convert it to oil.  
    2. Once it is converted it is going to have to be stored in some way until a ship can come to pick it up.
    In a pic I posted Challenge 2 may not be a challenge, it seems that some of the deep water derricks have storage already built in.

    The real challenge is how to actually collect the plastic without killing sea life in the process.  There is a guy on Indiegogo that is trying to come up with an idea for that, I plan on working with him if I can on this project , because I believe he has half of the answer.


      Other Ways You Can Help

      I will be setting up an email address for this project and once I do I will post it for everyone to see if you can't contribute, but want to help, you may email me and let me know what you might be able to do.


      Mainly please help to get the word out to as many people as you can.  I appreciate you taking the time to read my idea, and look forward to getting started on this project.

story:
The Adventure

In April of 2015, I am going to attempt to be the first woman to row the 6,000 nautical miles (or roughly 180 day) crossing of the North Pacific Ocean from Japan to San Francisco.  In partnership with ABC News, my team and I will get the opportunity to create a larger conversation about ocean awareness on an international platform. We will be creating an open source website with real time data uploading and conducting in-school programs to educate on how oceans drive our every day lives.

The money raised here will be used to support the remaining expenses required to get this project off of the ground including marine equipment, software, and safety support. And no, TV does not = $, but it does mean eyes which is the most important part of getting a message out.

The Reason

While many people focus on atmospheric changes as lead indicators of climate change, ocean currents and temperatures often act as the precursors.  For instance, once incredibly rare (every 100 year) wildfires in the Amazon are precipitated by rising ocean temperatures (learn more here).  

But, perhaps something more relevant to your everyday life will impart the importance of oceanographic research to you as an individual?  The 2014 polar vortex began and ended over an ocean.  Starting in the North Western Pacific, this incredibly destructive system brought on weather the likes of which had not been seen by North America and the UK in centuries (learn more here).  It brought the conversation about disappearing winters and snow to the forefront of the news this winter and spring not just because of the massive economic losses sustained over multiple industries, but because this could mean the end of cold weather for many places whose environments thrive during the winter months.

The North Pacific has one of the most powerful currents in the world, the Kuroshio Current that connects to the California Current, but little is known about the surface layers of this often tumultuous piece of water.  Within this host of the largest plastic gyre in the entire world and the many species of fish in danger of being wiped out due to overfishing, there lies an undiscovered body of knowledge that may help us unlock why our environment is changing so rapidly.  My team and I aim to educate and collect as much information as possible throughout this expedition.

The Science

Through a partnership with Earth and Space Research (lead researchers for NASA's Aquarius project) Liquid Robotics and YSI, I will be collecting thousands of data points over a six month period to help calibrate and validate current NASA oceanographic research tools like the Aquarius satellite and add to the body of knowledge about ocean salinity, fresh water and temperature.  

This mission will be the first collection of shallow surface data as my rowboat sits just 1 foot below the water.  Current autonomous floats and other traditional research vessel collection methods only collect accurate data between 5 and 100 feet of depth.  This leaves upper-most surface level unaccounted for. Like the ocean floor, little is known about this highly reactive and temperamental portion of the ocean.  

The reason why this type of scientific data has never been collected is simple: the incredible cost associated with sending research vessels is prohibitive and the size of the vessels are far too big to collect accurate data at the surface level (or stay out for the duration I can. This is the advantage of my small boat and my unassisted GREEN expedition.

All data collected will be open source and shared on a public website for researchers around the world to access.  In turn, I will be engaging with partner schools about the importance of the data and how the ocean plays into student's everyday lives through a multi-month education program currently in development.

The Expedition

  • 6000 nautical miles
  • 1 woman, unassisted
  • No sails, no motor, no gas
  • 1 custom built carbon rowing boat: 24 feet long, 6 feet wide
  • 180 days of Backpacker’s Pantry dehydrated food (5 bags/day, over 600 lbs.)
  • 400 Watts of Solar (Solbian Flex Mounted Panels and Goal Zero Handheld)
  • 3 Jetboils to boil water and rehydrate food
  • 75 lbs. of science equipment
  • 3 pairs of Sawyer made-in-America wood/carbon ocean rowing oars
  • 25 Liters per hour freshwater using a desalinizer

In late April/Early May 2015, I will be leaving the coast of Japan heading for San Francisco over 6,000 nm away across the Pacific Ocean and 3 degrees of latitude North.  Historically, only 3 other boats have successfully crossed over to North America - two solo Frenchmen (1991, 2003) and one pair of British men (2009). I am attempting to be the first woman to successfully complete this route and, by the time I take my first stroke from Japan, will have already invested 3 years of my life in this goal. To put it in terms more people understand, completing this route will be like conquering K2.

Life on Board: I will row 3 hours on, 3 hours off (weather dependent) for the entire crossing. The only power I have on board is 400 watts of Solbian panels recharging my Lithium Battery Co. batteries to run vital systems (like my desalinator, GPS, and other marine electronics).   Therefore, my power is heavily dependent upon rationed usage, sunlight and keeping the water out of my main cabin.  My boat is made to self-right if a wave pushes me over. The rowing space is completely exposed to the elements and the cabin is built just large enough for me to lay down flat and sit up, with my legs bent in a foot well. I have 16 individually partitioned watertight compartments on deck to hold my food (70% dehydrated requiring water, 30% edible without rehydration).  This is done so that if one floods, it won't spoil my other food stores.

Route: The assistance from trade winds will be minimal on this route. I will be dependent on staying in the driving currents: Kuroshio, Pacific, California.  It will require tactical use of my parachute anchor when there are head winds (often) and hopefully minimal time spent in eddies. My router will text me directions each day for the best route to take dependent on the impending weather system. The water is around 75 degrees in the current, and low 60s to high 50s outside of it - I'll train myself to wake up hourly to make sure I'm still in the current.

Support: I’ll have an experienced shore team providing psychological, physical, technological, and risk management support from afar. Which means, for instance, if my watermaker breaks at 3 am when a wave rolls my boat and my EPIRB goes off (but I'm still okay), I can call them up to help guide me on fixing the watermaker, as they contact Coast Guard to let them know I'm okay and to ignore the automated call for assistance, and give me some sort of upbeat quote to ponder all day while I get myself sorted. I wouldn't be able to successfully complete this journey without the dedication of this team.

**(A note about being unaccompanied: I am crossing unsupported and unfollowed for reasons beyond setting a record. The cost of having a chase vessel would be exorbitant, require a lot of petrol (gas) and it would negate the green energy-efficient nature of my expedition.  Other issues include: a sailboat would need to go in to refuel, would either go much faster or much slower than me, and in many cases would be less safe than my boat in high seas.)

The Budget

I’ve spent two years working on getting much of the gear donated and I’m 70% there, but am still coming up a bit short to get on the water successfully.  Here’s an idea of what we’ve got left:

$10,000 – Safety On-shore Support

$10,000 – Medical Support

$12,000 – Remaining Electronics

$6,000 – Other equipment (life raft, ropes, and other unglamorous – live saving - stuff)

$4,000 - Satellite Phone Minutes (in order to engage students and get routing updates)

With your help, we can make this real!  And, there’s some cool stuff that you, as an empowered environmental supporter and supporter of women in the outdoors, can get for taking part. 

IMPACT

At least a million people will get involved in the ocean-conservation conversation through our media platforms.

More than 30,000 volunteer service hours will be donated toward environmental preservation through the Ocean Ambassadors program.

Scientists and ocean studies students around the world will gain access to the data collected, impacting our knowledge of climate change in our oceans.

More positive representation of powerful women in the media - another win for women's empowerment.

Ocean Ambassador Extras

Even if you don’t have the funds to support this program monetarily, you can still be a direct supporter!

  • Follow us on Instagram/Twitter/Facebook at Epoch Expedition to get updates on the journey and other ways to help
  • Become an Ocean Ambassador and become a part of the collective good! Donate hours of service in the environment toward matching my miles rowed as either an individual or as a group.
  • Keep track and send me messages at http://ExpeditionPacific.com

You’d be surprised, but it can get very monotonous spending months by yourself out in the big blue.  Positive thoughts and energy make every day better!

autonomous floats and other traditional research vessel collection methods only
collect accurate data between 5 and 100 feet of depth.  This leaves
upper-most surface level unaccounted for. Like the ocean floor, little is known
about this highly reactive and temperamental portion of the ocean.  The reason why this type of scientific data has never been collected is simple: the incredible cost associated with sending research vessels is prohibitive and the size of the vessels are far too big to collect accurate data at the surface level (or stay out for the duration I can. This is the advantage of my small boat and my unassisted GREEN expedition.
All data collected will be open source and shared on a public website for researchers around the world to
access.  In turn, I will be engaging with partner schools about
the importance of the data and how the ocean plays into student's everyday
lives through a multi-month education program currently in development.
The Expedition

6000 nautical miles
1 woman, unassisted
No sails, no motor, no gas
1 custom built carbon rowing boat: 24 feet long, 6 feet wide
180 days of Backpacker’s Pantry
dehydrated food (5 bags/day, over 600 lbs.)
400 Watts of Solar (Solbian Flex
Mounted Panels and Goal Zero Handheld)
3 Jetboils to boil water and rehydrate food
75 lbs. of science equipment
3 pairs of Sawyer made-in-America wood/carbon ocean rowing oars
25 Liters per hour freshwater using a desalinizer

In late April/Early May 2015, I will be leaving the coast of Japan heading for San Francisco over 6,000 nm away across the Pacific Ocean and 3 degrees of latitude North.  Historically, only 3 other boats have successfully crossed over to North America - two solo Frenchmen (1991, 2003) and one pair of British men (2009). I am attempting to be the first woman to successfully complete this route and, by the time I take my first stroke from Japan, will have already invested 3 years of my life in this goal. To put it in terms more people understand, completing this route will be like conquering K2.Life on Board: I will row 3 hours on, 3 hours off (weather dependent) for the entire crossing. The only power I have on board is 400 watts of Solbian panels recharging my Lithium Battery Co. batteries to run vital systems (like my desalinator, GPS, and other marine electronics).   Therefore, my power is heavily dependent upon rationed usage, sunlight and keeping the water out of my main cabin.  My boat is made to self-right if a wave pushes me over. The rowing space is completely exposed to the elements and the cabin is built just large enough for me to lay down flat and sit up, with my legs bent in a foot well. I have 16 individually partitioned watertight compartments on deck to hold my food (70% dehydrated requiring water, 30% edible without rehydration).  This is done so that if one floods, it won't spoil my other food stores.Route: The assistance from trade winds will be minimal on this route. I will be dependent on staying in the driving currents: Kuroshio, Pacific, California.  It will require tactical use of my parachute anchor when there are head winds (often) and hopefully minimal time spent in eddies. My router will text me directions each day for the best route to take dependent on the impending weather system. The water is around 75 degrees in the current, and low 60s to high 50s outside of it - I'll train myself to wake up hourly to make sure I'm still in the current.Support: I’ll have
an experienced shore team providing psychological, physical, technological, and
risk management support from afar. Which means, for instance, if my watermaker breaks at 3 am when a wave rolls my boat and my EPIRB goes off (but I'm still okay), I can call them up to help guide me on fixing the watermaker, as they contact Coast Guard to let them know I'm okay and to ignore the automated call for assistance, and give me some sort of upbeat quote to ponder all day while I get myself sorted. I wouldn't be able to successfully complete this journey without the dedication of this team.
**(A note about being unaccompanied: I am crossing unsupported and
unfollowed for reasons beyond setting a record. The cost of having a chase
vessel would be exorbitant, require a lot of petrol (gas) and it would negate
the green energy-efficient nature of my expedition.  Other issues include: a sailboat would need
to go in to refuel, would either go much faster or much slower than me, and in
many cases would be less safe than my boat in high seas.)
The Budget
I’ve spent two years
working on getting much of the gear donated and I’m 70% there, but am still
coming up a bit short to get on the water successfully.  Here’s an idea of what we’ve got left:
$10,000 – Safety
On-shore Support
$10,000 – Medical
Support
$12,000 – Remaining
Electronics
$6,000 – Other equipment
(life raft, ropes, and other unglamorous – live saving - stuff)
$4,000 - Satellite
Phone Minutes (in order to engage students and get routing updates)
With your help, we can
make this real!  And, there’s some cool
stuff that you, as an empowered environmental supporter and supporter of
women in the outdoors, can get for taking part. 


IMPACT
At least a million
people will get involved in the ocean-conservation conversation through our
media platforms.
More than 30,000
volunteer service hours will be donated toward environmental preservation
through the Ocean Ambassadors program.
Scientists and ocean
studies students around the world will gain access to the data collected,
impacting our knowledge of climate change in our oceans.More positive representation of powerful women in the media - another win for women's empowerment.

Ocean Ambassador Extras
Even if you don’t have
the funds to support this program monetarily, you can still be a direct
supporter!

Follow us on Instagram/Twitter/Facebook at Epoch
     Expedition to get updates on the journey and other ways to help

Become an Ocean Ambassador and become a part of the
     collective good! Donate hours of service in the environment toward
     matching my miles rowed as either an individual or as a group.

Keep track and send me messages at http://ExpeditionPacific.com

You’d be surprised, but it can get very
monotonous spending months by yourself out in the big blue.  Positive thoughts and energy make every day
better!

story:
Short Summary

Hi, This is Bob from Escarpment Biosphere Conservancy.  Escarpment Biosphere Conservancy (EBC) is a charity founded in 1997 to create nature reserves and provide opportunities for the public to learn from untouched nature. Over the last 15 years, we have created 120 reserves, protecting 9,000 acres along Ontario’s Niagara Escarpment, the Lake Huron shoreline and on the world’s largest fresh-water island, Manitoulin. We have created 11 hiking trails, 7 official Niagara Escarpment parks and provided hiking on seven properties for other organizations.

Today, we are here to ask for your help to protect this piece of gorgeous land, located right beside the famous Misery Bay Provincial Park and another EBC reserve, and which is now at risk of being logged or turned into a hunt camp.  We have raised two-third of the funds and are only short $5000.  

The Campaign

Located adjacent to Ontario’s Misery Bay Provincial Park, the 25-acre property we are trying to save contains a creek and rock outcrop, as well as untouched mature moss-covered cedar trees.  (See map in the gallery to get a picture of how it fits together)

Based on our observations from land in similar parts of Manitoulin Island, this property, now for sale, is in danger of being turned into a hunt camp and the old cedar is a valuable target for logging companies.

Our goal is to prevent that from happening.

EBC has an accepted conditional offer to purchase this land and prevent the habitat within the land from being destroyed.

We have secured a grant from a friendly foundation for $10,000 of the $15,000 total cost.  All we need is the remaining $5,000 to pay the remainder of the purchase cost ($4,000) and the legal fees.

The property has not been touched for years with its mature moss-covered cedar trees; the only access is along a trail about a mile from the nearest drivable road. We can build a three kilometre (2 mile) long through this property and an adjacent EBC reserve to link up trails already established at Misery Bay which are used to visit the shoreline and globally-rare alvars (limestone pavement with rare plants). Our adjacent reserve (with our other three nearby reserves) will further protect the habitat and biodiversity of this special place.

We would appreciate it if you can donate a few dollars to help us protect this land for future generations to enjoy.  

Because we are a registered charity, we are able to issue an Income Tax Receipt upon request if you donate $10 or more (for Canadian donors only).  So every $10 you donate, you get approximately $5 back (how great is that?)!

*note: American Donors: Please contact us for more information regarding Income Tax Receipt. 

*note 2: If you wish to claim any of the perks, you cannot donate anonymously!  We must be able to have your info to send you the perks!  Alternatively, if you really wish to stay anonymous and want to claim a perk, please email me your details and we will sort it out (email underneath).   

Other Ways You Can Help

We appreciate your support even if you can't donate!

We are a charity and rely heavily on volunteers.  If you are passionate about conserving nature and wish to give some time to this beautiful cause, please email me (Bob), at rbarnett@escarpment.ca

story:
IN BRIEF

  1. This is an expedition run by Outlook Expeditions
  2. It is in the Summer of 2014 and is 21 days long
  3. I am working with an Amazonian community in Ecuador to help with their development, and visiting the Galapagos Islands
  4. THIS IS NOT A HOLIDAY - I will be sleeping in tents/hammocks, I will be bathing in rivers, I will be cooking on open fire, hiking and organising my own transport.
  5. I'll be in a small group, of around 12 pupils from my school
  6. IT COSTS £4125 - I am trying to fundraise as much of this as possible, seeing as it's just early stages, I haven't planned what methods I will use yet, I am starting off with getting sponsors.

More detail!

My name's Mathuri (don't bother on the pronunciation!). I'm a 15 year old girl from England. I've just signed up for an expedition to Ecuador and the Galapagos Islands!

This is honestly a once in a lifetime opportunity as I'll be living with an Amazonian tribe, for approximately a week, and working with them to help with the development of their community. This region has suffered from environmental damage which has then lead to setbacks for the communities in the area. This work is part of the Yanapuma NAPO project which aims to promote sustainable community development.

This is the main reason I'm going on this expedition. Not only will I be helping out this community, but this will also give boost my spirit, increase my confidence and change me for the better. It will give my life a bit more substance. I'll experience a completely different life to the materialistic one I take for granted right now! I'll also get an extraordinary opportunity to experience the culture of the community I'll be living with.

I will be visiting areas in Ecuador too, known for their stunning scenery and geological features, as well as the traditional market places and communities and I will be trekking in the Western Cordillera of the Andes.

I'll also be going to the Galapagos Islands, which Charles Darwin has famously visited. These islands are known for their amazing wildlife and healthy marine life. There are rare species on this island such as the giant tortoise, Galapagos Penguins, Land Iguanas etc.  Tourism in these islands is limited, in comparison to other places, due to the protection of the habitats. Again, this is a rare opportunity!

Why is it so expensive?

£4125 or $6237

This goes towards:

  • cost of transport (planes/boats)
  • training/preparation/courses before the expedition
  • food
  • kit and medical/first aid supplies/safety equipment
  • the planning team, safety and support network
  • equipment such as satellite phones and gps systems

ALL of the money I raise will go towards this trip. In the unlikely event that I raise more than I need, I will give it to a charity.

FINALLY

This trip will teach me real life skills, it will give me independence/self sufficiency, it will teach me to be less selfish, I will evolve as a person, I'll become more confident.

My life has been uninteresting so far and unfulfilling, just a cycle of sleep, eat, study. Yes I am still young, and I've still got my life ahead of me, but this is the first step to experiencing the extraordinary. It means so much to me that I go on this trip and I would be SO grateful if you sponsored me! I need £4125. My "goal" on here is £1000, though I'm not expecting to raise much online, maybe about £20. BUT IF 1 PERSON sponsors me £1, and 1000 people see this then I've reached my short term "goal"!

I'm also planning to get a part time job, sell many of my belongings, contribute money I receive on my birthday and Christmas to this trip, sell cakes/food and I still need to properly plan out what I am going to do. I have 1 year to do this.

 

 http://www.outlookexpeditions.com/destinations/...

story:
Localize This! Scholarships In A Nutshell

Join a cross-section of change makers striving to invigorate effective & creative activism and organizing for progressive values by supporting Localize This training camp!

Your support for travel & tuition scholarships makes it possible for change agents from frontline and impacted communities to particpate in the 5th annual Localize This! action camp.

Change agents are converging in northwest to inspire one-another with victory stories, amplify their organizing, and make their activism more effective, sustainable, creative, and fun. 

Fund Localize This! to ensure leaders at the forefront of progressive change and participants from diverse economic and cultural backgrounds can attend. WE DO NOT TURN ANYONE AWAY FOR LACK OF FUNDS, so contributing as generously as possible will ensure participants have the resources to travel to camp and make sure Localize This! can happen again next year.

50% of the funds raised will go to support travel for participants from especially impacted communities like Los Angeles Youth working to stop youth incarceration, the other 50% will go to support costs of putting on the camp - like food, travel costs and modest stipends for trainers, and renting the hostel the camp is conducted on. The full cost of producing Localize This!, including the final action, is $30,000.

 

More about Localize This!

Participants at Localize This! are working on issues like:

  • Economic Justice
  • Keeping fossil fuels in the ground
  • Making housing and education a human right
  • Moving to amend the constitution
  • Transitioning from a for-profit prison industrial complex to restorative justice and community reinvestment
  • Putting a stop to GMO foods
  • and much much more

We need your help to make sure as many people representing a diverse cross-section of movements make it to camp. 

Localize This! started 5 years ago when a community mobilized to stop a transnational corporation from trashing one of the gems of the Northwest. After a 10-year long legal and regulatory struggle, the traditional channels of public redress proved to be wholly innadequate. The community turned to Backbone Campaign for support and launched a action camp as a part of their campaign to defend their island and the Puget Sound. Today, what would have been turned into a gravel mine is now a public park containing an important estuary, home to salmon, orca whales, and more - now preserved for generations to come. Since then Localize This has become a tradition, nurturing effective organizing strategies and creative tactics.

Last year Localize This! designed many of the trainings and actions around supporting and strengthening a brand new volunteer-led eviction and foreclosure defense community organization. Now, less than a year later families are organizing themselves to successfully stop evictions by Wall Street banks. Moreover, they're building real community power and strengthening a social movement around ideas of mutual aid, housing as a human right, and universal principle reduction. This is just one of the many success stories from last year's camp.

About Backbone Campaign

Backbone Campaign has been criss-crossing the country for over 9 years doing progressive movement building work by inspiring and amplifying citizen engagement. Backbone Campaign is known for their use of creative imagery and spectacle, innovative messaging, and political theatre. Most of their work involves Artful Activism, in which they engage progressive activists and organizers in the strategic use of creative tactics such as festival arts, flash mobs, music and other theatrical forms of nonviolent direct action to make our shared values visible, earn media attention, and build power. Backbone Campaign offers workshops, trainings, consultation, and action support.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share, repost, tweet, and talk with your friends about Localize This! encouraging them to join if they want to amplify their activism, and contribute if they want to see vibrant and effective social movements. You can also donate frequent flier miles, and other skills or gifts you possess.

  • Join the Backbone Campaign email list for great photos of actions and updates
  • Like Backbone Campaign on Facebook
  • Share the link to Localize This!
  • Join the Backbone Campaign Lumbar club to become a pillar of support for the progressive movement!
  • Share the Localize This facebook event page
  • Invite Backbone Campaign to hold workshops, trainings, and do action support in your community on your own campaigns by visiting our workshop offerings page and emailing us!
  • We're looking for a minivan to transport large imagery for action support, send us an email (especially if you want to donate one with stow-and-go seats!).
  • Give us a ring if you think of other ways you'd like to get involved or support Localize This- 206-408-8058

Unleash the progressive movement's organizing potential by investing in Localize This!

FORWARD TOGETHER!

Unleash the progressive movement's organizing potential by investing in Localize This!



FORWARD TOGETHER!

story:
Our Story

We, Koko, Kevin and Agus, are three people wanting to share our passion for nature. We hope to develop a five-acre dry land on a karst hill in to an eco-lodge where nature lovers can have fun and share knowledge. This site is located in Gunung Kidul District of Special Province of Yogyakarta, Indonesia. 

Koko studied biology at Northern Arizona University (BS - 1994) and animal sciences at Colorado University (MS - 1999). He grew up in a small farm in Blora, a small town in Central Java province, and started hiking the mountains the island of Java in high school. Living in northern Arizona and Colorado, his love for nature only increased. Besides hiking and taking nature photography, he has come to love rock climbing and sailing.

Kevin is from Philadelphia. After spending years studying engineering, he decided that permaculture was his calling. He has been studying this discipline for the last two years in the New Mexico desert and western Oregon lush forests. Now he wants to apply this knowledge to start the practice of permaculture in this new place.

Agus is native to the area. He has a degree in accounting. However he is very passionate about nature and education. His family is well known in the area for promoting conservation. He has done some years of teaching in grade schools after graduating from college. His father, Mr. Sudarli, won the highest award for conservation from the Indonesian government in 2011 for his work in the forestation of the hills.

This eco-lodge is close to  beaches and sea cliffs, and surrounded by countless beautiful limestone hills where many farmers subsist. This facility will rely on what we grow in the farm using permaculture method. Being farm boys and nature lovers, we intend to use this facility to share knowledge about environmentally responsible practices not only to the surrounding people, but also to university students.

Yogyakarta is the largest college town in the country. There are countless universities in the area. The students of these colleges see the need to learn English to help their career in this globalized economy. We hope to use the facility to have camps (weekend or extended) to teach English to these students with the emphasis of nature education. Your contributions will provide an environmental education facility. Such a place is becoming more and more necessary, especially in Indonesia where industry and commerce are growing too fast and environmental concerns are often ignored.

Besides the garden and teaching the environment, we also hope to provide the visitors with other activities. This area is endowed with many natural wonders in the forms of a beautiful coastal line that contains secluded beaches and towering sea cliffs. These beaches have coral reefs and tide pools that people can explore during low tide. Some of the sea cliffs have been developed into climbing destinations, but there are more walls to be explored. The Indian ocean offers limitless potential for sailing and windsurfing.

What We Need & What You Get

We will need $10,000 to start with. We need the money to build the commons, three cabins, water tanks, two composting toilets, two shower facilities, trails, solar power system and promotional materials. The following figures are approximate expenditures for the items mainly because of the fluctuating currency exchange rate.

The first thing to be built is the water tank. This is a karst area, which means that rain water usually disappears almost immediately into subterranean rivers. The people in this area have adopted the skill to tap the rain water by using large brick-and-plaster water tanks (5000 liters). This structure will cost $1000. The commons which will serve as a dining hall and multipurpose building is in the size of 8x4 m2. It will require approximately $2000 to build. The cabins are in the size of 3x3 m2, and each will cost approximately $1000. We will employ composting toilets and regular shower facilities. These structures will cost $1000. The location of this on a hillside and away from the main road (http://www.panoramio.com/photo/91194986). We will need to build a hiking trail to the site. This trail will be no wider than 1 m. Lots of care has to be done so that the trail does not expose the hill to more erosion. We plan to manage the drainage with vegetations. This trail will cost us $1000. Since this site is out of the electricity grid, we want to install solar panels. We can use $1500 to set up the system. A $500 fund will be set aside to promote the business. We will start promoting the business as soon we start erecting the buildings.

We accept any amount of donations, but for $50 dollars, we will name a fruit tree after you. We plan to plant fruit (mango, guava, sawo, sirsak etc) and food (jackfruit, breadfruit, sukun etc) trees. There are already hardy trees like teak, mahogany, ironwood etc in the farm but we plan to add more. With a $100 donation, we will name one of these trees after you. Besides the plants, we have structures to be named as well and $500 will get you to name a hut or any other structure of your choice, except for the commons. We will surround the structures with gardens, and these gardens’s names are available for $500 as well.

If we do not reach our goal, we will use the fund that we recieve to build the trail and water tank, because they are essential infra structures to the facility. The other buildings can be added slowly while we work on the land and do further fundraising.

Our Goals

The conventional agriculture can be highly destructive, especially for a fragile environment like this area. An alternative method in land stewardship is permaculture. This practice ensures the sustainability of an agricultural operation because the extensive use of perennial plants allows a significant reduction of erosion. As mentioned earlier, the area consists of karst hills. Besides continuing the work that has been done by Mr. Sudarli in reforesting those hills, we also hope to build on it, not only to maintain the already established system of tree-planting, but also to further improve the lives of the subistent farmers by attracting eco-tourists.

Our final number of cabins is five. The cabins can hold up to four people. We hope to have no more than 30 people (guests and personnel) at an extended period of time (over three days) so as to not put too much pressure on the system. If this system succeeds, we plan to share this small scale operation with others.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to help us financially, we hope that you will help us by spreading the word about our endeavor.

Koko has some experience teaching climbing and English, Kevin is the land steward, and Agus is the bean counter. But neither of us has any experience in combining those skills. We are open to advice and suggestions on how to pursue this dream.

This a long term project, so we would also appreciate if you would follow our progress at http://lenggokofarm.wordpress.com/ .
story_txt:
Our Story
We, Koko, Kevin and Agus, are three people wanting to share our passion for nature. We hope to develop a five-acre dry land on a karst hill in to an eco-lodge where nature lovers can have fun and share knowledge. This site is located in Gunung Kidul District of Special Province of Yogyakarta, Indonesia. 
Koko studied biology at Northern Arizona University (BS - 1994) and animal sciences at Colorado University (MS - 1999). He grew up in a small farm in Blora, a small town in Central Java province, and started hiking the mountains the island of Java in high school. Living in northern Arizona and Colorado, his love for nature only increased. Besides hiking and taking nature photography, he has come to love rock climbing and sailing.
Kevin is from Philadelphia. After spending years studying engineering, he decided that permaculture was his calling. He has been studying this discipline for the last two years in the New Mexico desert and western Oregon lush forests. Now he wants to apply this knowledge to start the practice of permaculture in this new place.
Agus is native to the area. He has a degree in accounting. However he is very passionate about nature and education. His family is well known in the area for promoting conservation. He has done some years of teaching in grade schools after graduating from college. His father, Mr. Sudarli, won the highest award for conservation from the Indonesian government in 2011 for his work in the forestation of the hills.
This eco-lodge is close to  beaches and sea cliffs, and surrounded by countless beautiful limestone hills where many farmers subsist. This facility will rely on what we grow in the farm using permaculture method. Being farm boys and nature lovers, we intend to use this facility to share knowledge about environmentally responsible practices not only to the surrounding people, but also to university students.
Yogyakarta is the largest college town in the country. There are countless universities in the area. The students of these colleges see the need to learn English to help their career in this globalized economy. We hope to use the facility to have camps (weekend or extended) to teach English to these students with the emphasis of nature education. Your contributions will provide an environmental education facility. Such a place is becoming more and more necessary, especially in Indonesia where industry and commerce are growing too fast and environmental concerns are often ignored.
Besides the garden and teaching the environment, we also hope to provide the visitors with other activities. This area is endowed with many natural wonders in the forms of a beautiful coastal line that contains secluded beaches and towering sea cliffs. These beaches have coral reefs and tide pools that people can explore during low tide. Some of the sea cliffs have been developed into climbing destinations, but there are more walls to be explored. The Indian ocean offers limitless potential for sailing and windsurfing.
What We Need & What You Get
We will need $10,000 to start with. We need the money to build the commons, three cabins, water tanks, two composting toilets, two shower facilities, trails, solar power system and promotional materials. The following figures are approximate expenditures for the items mainly because of the fluctuating currency exchange rate.
The first thing to be built is the water tank. This is a karst area, which means that rain water usually disappears almost immediately into subterranean rivers. The people in this area have adopted the skill to tap the rain water by using large brick-and-plaster water tanks (5000 liters). This structure will cost $1000. The commons which will serve as a dining hall and multipurpose building is in the size of 8x4 m2. It will require approximately $2000 to build. The cabins are in the size of 3x3 m2, and each will cost approximately $1000. We will employ composting toilets and regular shower facilities. These structures will cost $1000. The location of this on a hillside and away from the main road (http://www.panoramio.com/photo/91194986). We will need to build a hiking trail to the site. This trail will be no wider than 1 m. Lots of care has to be done so that the trail does not expose the hill to more erosion. We plan to manage the drainage with vegetations. This trail will cost us $1000. Since this site is out of the electricity grid, we want to install solar panels. We can use $1500 to set up the system. A $500 fund will be set aside to promote the business. We will start promoting the business as soon we start erecting the buildings.
We accept any amount of donations, but for $50 dollars, we will name a fruit tree after you. We plan to plant fruit (mango, guava, sawo, sirsak etc) and food (jackfruit, breadfruit, sukun etc) trees. There are already hardy trees like teak, mahogany, ironwood etc in the farm but we plan to add more. With a $100 donation, we will name one of these trees after you. Besides the plants, we have structures to be named as well and $500 will get you to name a hut or any other structure of your choice, except for the commons. We will surround the structures with gardens, and these gardens’s names are available for $500 as well.
If we do not reach our goal, we will use the fund that we recieve to build the trail and water tank, because they are essential infra structures to the facility. The other buildings can be added slowly while we work on the land and do further fundraising.
Our Goals
The conventional agriculture can be highly destructive, especially for a fragile environment like this area. An alternative method in land stewardship is permaculture. This practice ensures the sustainability of an agricultural operation because the extensive use of perennial plants allows a significant reduction of erosion. As mentioned earlier, the area consists of karst hills. Besides continuing the work that has been done by Mr. Sudarli in reforesting those hills, we also hope to build on it, not only to maintain the already established system of tree-planting, but also to further improve the lives of the subistent farmers by attracting eco-tourists.
Our final number of cabins is five. The cabins can hold up to four people. We hope to have no more than 30 people (guests and personnel) at an extended period of time (over three days) so as to not put too much pressure on the system. If this system succeeds, we plan to share this small scale operation with others.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you are unable to help us financially, we hope that you will help us by spreading the word about our endeavor.
Koko has some experience teaching climbing and English, Kevin is the land steward, and Agus is the bean counter. But neither of us has any experience in combining those skills. We are open to advice and suggestions on how to pursue this dream.
This a long term project, so we would also appreciate if you would follow our progress at http://lenggokofarm.wordpress.com/ .

story:
Why do garden classes matter?

I'm a mom of six. My kids grew up on our small farm and played outdoors all year. Being in the garden was a natural. We like to see kids playing outside.  We also realize so many kids aren't able to get outdoors to dig or plant in a yard or garden. With online classes people can learn how to start a garden and grow something...even if it's a tiny potted garden on the windowsill!

With our new kid's class in the works, adults can learn basic garden skills along with their kids and will learn how to start an herb garden of their very own.

 

Will you help us keep going?

Even if you can't make a donation just helping to get the word out would be beyond terrific!

We have some fun perks and give aways for donors like watercolor notecards,

bookmarks and even handmade miniature fairy garden sets!

Visit here for a sneak peek of a few of our perks.

Thanks so much for your support,

 

Rhonda Daniels
