story:
My name is Gigi Rose and I am twelve years old from Temecula, Ca. I started my Slow Food Journey at the age of 6, and have since helped create local gardens. I have been chosen as the youngest delegate in history to participate in the Slow Food USA: Terra Madre project. I am the president of the Slow Food Hillcrest (my school), and I am very passionate about the importance of good, healthy food for kids and teens. I believe that everyone deserves to choose the food they eat, and with that- the RIGHT to nutritious foods!   I am raising money to fund my documentary, "Gigi's Road To Terra Madre."  This project is phase 1 of my documentary, "Cultivating The Food Culture." The trip to Terra Madre will take place in Turin, Italy.  I will have the opportunity to attend workshops,  and events that will further my education about the state of our food world, and what truly healthy food means. I will be representing the Southern California food community, allowing me to share the variety of agriculture So. California has to offer, and to continue my mission to fully ignite this conversation amongst the youth of our country.  

For more info on the Slow Food Movement, visit http://www.slowfoodusa.org/our country.  


What exactly is Terra Madre:  Terra Madre is a world summit- bringing together players in the food chain, school chain and education chain all that support sustainable agriculture fishing and breeding with the goal of preserving the taste and biodiversity.


I am a delegate- what does that mean?:   Each national association of Slow Food sends a delegation to represent their country at Terra Madre. In addition, Slow Food International selects individuals from 100+ other countries to attend. Slow Food USA delegates are chosen by regional selection committees focused on representing the human and cultural diversity of the food communities in that geographic area.

Slow Food USA has honored all selected delegates  with the responsibility of representing the United States of America at the 2014 Terra Madre / Salone del Gusto. By experiencing Terra Madre, delegates return to their home countries with an imperative to share with others what they have learned from and interacting with others around the world who care about Slow Food. The hope is that delegates will leave Turin inspired and empowered to enact the joy and justice of good, clean and fair food with their local communities.


The Funds:  By raising 7,500 dollars I will be able to attend Terra Madre, along with my fellow dedicated youth activist, Sofia Steckdaub.  The funds will allow us to document the trip through videos and photos, while attending the Terra Madre World Summit.  My idea is to come home and put all our footage together to help spread the word of Good, Clean Food.   It is important for other kids and youth activists to always strive for the truth within their quest to eat and promote healthy food.  Other costs include- perks  and editing both sound and picture, plus the cost difference of the Euro to the Dollar.  NOTE:  My momma is going as an adult  delegate and my chaperone- she is paying her own way.  Sofia Steckdaub is paying for her airfare and hotel.  A good friend of my moms- felt this was important to mention, so everyone knows where the funds are going.  THANK YOU EVERYONE!

Long Term Goals: 
  1. Create a worldwide movement towards improving school lunches.
  2. Cultivate relationships with food communities.
  3. Gather information to expand my mission, creating hubs of support in various communities locally and around the world.


The Crew:

Mum, Leah DiBernardo

My mom is the founder of E.A.T. Marketplace in Old Town, Temecula, and also a Southern California Slow Food leader.  Mom will be joining me as a So. Cal delegate, and my chaperone.  

Bestie, Sofia Steckdaub 

Sofia is a 17 year old senior at Vista Murrieta High School. Not only is she my sister from another mister, but she also shares the Slow Food passion. She will be coming along for the journey to take videos, pictures, and notes to document the experience.

Sofia is a 17 year old senior at Vista Murrieta High School. Not only is she my sister from another mister, but she also shares the Slow Food passion. She will be coming along for the journey to take videos, pictures, and notes to document the experience. 
Risks and Challenges:


Allow me to stand out amongst my peers, as someone that has a passion and drive to make a change in my community.


My grades! I say this because I truly believe that no matter what happens in Italy, I will come back with different perspective on culture and history. Don't worry Mrs. Miller, I'll be sure to take my math book along.


As a 12 year old, having the ability to be taken seriously.

story: Climate change is real and one of the ways to mitigate effects of climate change is through tree planting. Tree planted offset green house gases from the atmosphere. Each and every year, i join hundred of Kenyans in planting thousand of trees to heal the earth. Already this year, we have 15,000 trees in our nursery to be planted during earth day tree planting day. Your don't need to worry where to plant a tree that day. You can join my community through donating and your tree will be planted. Any donations will receive a certificate of tree planted and species planted for you. If you plant 1 tree you will be offsetting 23 kilograms of carbon. Each tree will cost $ 50cents to plant, this will include transportation to the planting sites. Any tree planted will be taken care until its well established, if that tree dries up, it will be replaced at our own cost. Don't sit down and let other people offset carbon for you. Participate in offsetting your own carbon and you will be HEALING THE EARTH.

Formiamo.de ist ein Startup Designbüro aus Braunschweig.
 

Eine Idee von Caspar Bögge (13, Sohn) von Reinhard Bögge,

 
Hier ein Beispiel: Werbestift aus einem Element - plus Mine
 
Werbung mal anders
Aussage: Wir produzieren keinen Müll.
 
Der umweltfreundliche recyclebare/kompostierbare Werbeträger mit der
Botschaft: "Wir denken an die Umwelt".
 
Einen Werbestift auf die wesentlichen Elemente reduzieren:
Minenhalter, Minenführung, Druckfeder, Rastung, Entsperrung, Halteclip, Werbefläche
alles aus einem Element aus recyclebarem/kompostierbarem Kunststoff auf Zucker oder Milch Basis.
 
Gesucht wird:
ein Designer zur Optimierung des Prototyps, (ca. 6000,- €)
Marketingexperten für Umweltprodukte,
Hersteller eines Modells (ca. 600,- €)
Hersteller eines Funktionsmodelles, (ca. 2000,- €)
Hersteller der ( klein ) Serie (ca. 10000,- €)
 

Sie möchten mein Projekt unterstützen? Klicken Sie hier - Danke
Sie können sich aber auch eine Dankeschön Gegenleistung (Perk) im Balken rechts aussuchen.

Anmerkung: Die bevormundende Vorbelegung mit 100, € ist dem amerikanischen CrowdFunding (Finanzierung durch die Kraft der Massen) System geschuldet!
Auch kleinere Beträge helfen - Danke Caspar & Reinhard Bögge
 

lange Version

 
Eine Idee von Caspar Bögge (13, Sohn) von Reinhard Bögge, Frührentner im Rollstuhl
Hier ein Beispiel: Werbestift aus einem Element - plus Mine
 
Werbung mal anders
Aussage: Wir produzieren keinen Müll.
 
Der umweltfreundliche recyclebare/kompostierbare Werbeträger mit der
Botschaft: "Wir denken an die Umwelt".
Der Stift hebt sich aus der Masse der Werbestifte als Besonderheit durch Aussage, Gestaltung und Funktion hervor.
Dadurch hat er eine längere Verweildauer beim Kunden und wird öfter als andere Stifte "herumgezeigt".
 
Einen Werbestift auf die wesentlichen Elemente reduzieren:
Minenhalter, Minenführung, Druckfeder, Rastung, Entsperrung, Halteclip, Werbefläche
alles aus einem Element aus recyclebarem/kompostierbarem Kunststoff auf Zucker oder Milch Basis.
 
Gesucht wird:
ein Designer zur Optimierung des Prototyps, (ca. 6000,- €)
Marketingexperten für Umweltprodukte,
Hersteller eines Modells (ca. 600,- €)
Hersteller eines Funktionsmodelles, (ca. 2000,- €)
Hersteller der ( klein ) Serie (ca. 10000,- €)
 
Keywords:
Werbung, Kugelschreiber, Unikat, Alleinstellungsmerkmal, besonders, Werbeträger, Werbegeschenk, Reminder, Werbestift
 

english

Formiamo.de is a startup design company from Brunswick (Germany)

The designer and engineer Reinhard Bögge is retirement in a wheelchair
(Multiple sclerosis), and yet full of fresh ideas.
With the help of his family and friends, he tries to be more creative.

He spends his time with the development of interesting ideas and innovations.

Here an example: Advertising Pen from an element - plus mine
An idea of Caspar Bögge (13, son)

Advertising times differently
Statement: We produce no waste.

The eco-friendly recyclable/biodegradable promotional items with the
Message: "we think of the environment".
The pen stands out from the mass of the promotional pens as a special feature by

statement, structure and function.

Thus, he has a longer residence time at the customer and more often than other pens 'see around".

Reduce a promotional pen on the essential elements:

mine operator, mine management, compression spring, locking, unlock, clip, advertising everything from an element plastic recyclable/kompostierbarem on sugar or milk based.

Looking for is:
a designer for the optimization of the prototype (approx. 6000,-€)
Marketing experts for environmental products,
Manufacturer of the model (approx. 600,-€)
Manufacturer of a function model, (approx. 2000,-€)
Manufacturer of the (small) series (approx. 10000,-€)

Keywords:
Advertising, pens, unique, unique selling proposition, especially advertising, giveaway, reminder


You like my Projekt ? Sign here - Thanks
At the right Side you can look for Perks

Caspar Bögge, (Sohn-13) Gesamtschule Querum

Reinhard Bögge, (60) Dipl.Ing.(TU), Dipl.-Des.(HBK)

Seit 1985 angestellt:Techex, Blaupunkt, Nixdorf (CAD), DSM (VideoBoard), TV38 (VideoSchnitt)

Seit 1990 freier Berater: E&S, VW, Ford, Fiat, Porsche, Philips, Nordica, ISRI, miro...

Seit 1993 Lehrtätigkeit: VHS, bfw, FH, HBK, RCA

Erfahrungen: CAD, Computergrafik, Computer Aided Industrial Design, Multimedia, Video, IMDS

Software: Euclid, Autocad, CDRS, Softimage, Flash, Dreamweaver, Photoshop, IMDS, Wordpress

Seit 2005: Frührentner, MS, Rollstuhl

story:
This Campaign's Story    

Hello!

My name is Robert Pohl and I am the Executive Director of CleanEnergy4All. 

Clean Energy4All is a non-profit organization that provides solar systems for charities who help at risk individuals to succeed. These systems help cut energy costs for the charities in a major way. 

This campaign is to install a solar system for East End Community Services (EECS), a foundation that has the potential to "break" the pattern of poverty for children in East Dayton, Ohio. It oversees an early childhood program in inner city schools, putting these students well above average reading levels for their age, and providing them with skills to help them excel later in life. In addition, it constructs energy efficient homes for families in need. 


Being a resident of Dayton, Ohio myself and having worked in education for years, this project is particularly important to me. 

If this project is funded, it is estimated to create savings in utility costs of over $225,000 for EECS in the next 20 years. And you can help! 


What We Need & Where It Will Go

We need $20,000 to complete the funding process for this project (a $100,000 venture in total), and this is where it will lead: 

  • CE4A, in concert with Chapel Electric, will oversee the installation of a world class solar system at an EECS building in East Dayton.

  • A renowned public relations firm will conduct a publicity campaign that will enable EECS to significantly market this cutting edge solar system. This will in turn enhance EECS's national and local reputation. 

  • The solar system will reduce East End’s carbon footprint

  • A family in need will receive an energy efficient home complete with a full solar system. 

The Impact

In the past, CleanEnergy4All has helped multiple organizations, such as Teen Challenge and an inner city Boys and Girls Club, to reach similar fundraising goals. These organizations have benefitted greatly long-term in two ways:

1) By saving a significant amount of money on power

2) By promoting their charitable reputations through environmental protection

If charities around the nation and eventually the globe can start adopting this trend, carbon emissions will be significantly reduced. And the foundations will save a significant amount of money that can be used toward helping those in need. 


A look into the C4A's mission, and a succesful past project (the installation of solar panels on a parking structure for Teen Challenge in California):



    If You Cannot Donate - Help Get The Word Out

    I know realistically you cannot all contribute, but you can still get the word out! Everything counts.

    Use the social media buttons at the bottom of this page to access information about EECS, and share it on Facebook or Twitter. Or send out info from our website and social media sites right here: 


    Website -     http://www.cleanenergy4all.org/

    Twitter   -     https://twitter.com/CE4AFoundation

    Facebook -  https://www.facebook.com/cleanenergy4all


    From the website of EECS:

story:
Nature in the City: Turn the concrete into jungle

"Who knew that seemingly simple tasks of moving soil and transplanting plants could be super fun–made more special because our two teams got to spend time getting to know each other better."

Nancy Fong, Wells Fargo Home Mortgage


Nature in the City is San Francisco's first organization wholly dedicated to eco-literacy, conservation, restoration, and stewardship of San Francisco's wild places. 

From now until the end of the year, a group of generous supporters have pledged to match up to $15,000 of the funds we raise by the end of the year, meaning that your contribution will make twice the impact. 

Our work would not be possible without you! 

A renewed commitment to Nature in the City makes all this possible:

  • Science Saturdays: every Saturday in 2015 will feature nature walks and talks, plant sales, citizen science projects, and public art–lead by passionate local naturalists. Science Saturdays will be brought to you in partnership with the Bay Institute, Presidio Trust, Tree Frog Treks, and Nature in the City. 
  • Green Hairstreak Corridor: This year, we planted over 1200 butterfly-friendly plants and restored 6000 square feet of habitat. Students at San Francisco State University are entering their 3rd year of corridor assessment and butterfly monitoring. Your contributions will help us buy plants, equipment, secure volunteers, and put out educational signage in the 12 sites we care for. 
  • Market Street Prototyping Festival: April 9th to 11th, Market Street will come alive with 50 of the most exciting ideas for San Francisco's main thoroughfare. With your support, Nature in the City will assure that butterflies, healthy native nectar flowers, and true urban wildlife corridors will have a prominent role! 

Now is the time to take part in our dream of eco-literacy for all San Franciscans. Give to Nature in the City today, and renew your commitment to local nature! Our work would not be possible without your financial support. 

What you get! 

All contributors will get a special gift to commemorate their generosity. 

Packet of California native seeds

Wanted Weeds poster

Vintage Earth Day t-shirt

Urban Hedgerow habitat magnet


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, there are many ways you can help. 

  • Get the word out, and share this campaign with others, and help us reach our goal of eco-literacy for all San Franciscans. 
  • Sign up for our e-newsletter at http://www.natureinthecity.org/
  • Join our Meetup Group, and volunteer at our monthly workdays http://www.meetup.com/Nature-in-the-City/

story:
My name is Drew.  I'm a 23 year old web developer.  I'm planning to thru-hike the Appalachian Trail.  For those of you who may not be familiar, the Appalachian Trail runs continually all the way from Georgia to Maine, approximately 2,185 miles.  On average it takes between 5 and 6 months.  I hope to embark on this journey on March 28th. 

Along the way, I will cross paths with black bears and rattle snakes, below freezing and triple digit temperatures, and a high probability of injury and illness.  And as crazy as this may sound, I can't wait!! 

Growing up, I lived in the woods.  All the free time I had was spent hiking, exploring, building forts, kayaking, just doing anything outdoors.  It's been a dream of mine since I was a kid to take a break from life, travel, explore, and truly experience nature. So, hiking the AT has been a life-long dream.  I started my career as a web developer right out of high school, and most weeks I spend 80 hours or so in front of my computer working.  Hiking the AT will be my chance to finally disconnect and have a break from this unhealthy lifestyle.  If I don't do this now, I fear I won't ever have the chance to again.

Since this experience will be so important and life-changing to me, I want to share it fully with all of my supporters.  I'll be blogging about my trip so everyone can follow and be a part of this journey with me.  In addition, I'd love to send postcards, letters, and emails to people who support me and want to live this experience with me.

To give back to the hiking community, I've been working with Zach Davis (AppalachianTrials.com) to build web apps for hikers.  The first project is one that allows hikers to update their location while hiking, whether for family or for their own record.  I'm going to continue to give back by doing this.

While I'm doing my best to save the money on my own for this, most of my waking hours are spent working on a startup that makes no money. It's on average $2/per mile to hike the trail plus all the gear I need to buy for it.  Expenses on the trail include things such as: food, supplies, room/board (to have a place to shower and rest), and so forth.  In addition, I'll need things like a backpack, a tent, sleeping bag, shoes, etc. 

I need your support.

A rough breakdown of the costs looks like:

Food, supplies, places to stay: ~$4400 

Hiking Gear: ~$1500

Without any outside help, this dream will remain exactly that.  No donation is too small.

Thank you for your time and support.  I very much look forward to taking you on this journey along with me.

story:
BETTER THAN NEW. Creating an emporium of reuse, repair, and reimagination in Geelong

Reuse is a key part of a more sustainable future.  Incredible re-makers already exist across the world, who are making wonderful Better Than New goods from reclaimed items.  The problem is there are very few places for customers to easily find their work.  18 months ago we set up a small hub for amazing reimagined goods in central Geelong, Victoria.  Now we need your help to transition this boutique into a grand emporium for collaboration, creation and showcasing of reimagined wares.

What we do now

In 2018 we opened the doors to a tiny retail space for reclaimed furniture and vintage bluetooth speakers in Geelong. The products we made were as good as new, without being new.  We realised quickly that there was nowhere around where you could easily find and purchase quality reclaimed goods.  This lead to a move to a proper little shopfront in the heart of Geelong, where we began stocking other incredible re-makers alongside our own work.  18 months on, our social enterprise now supports over a dozen re-creatives from across Australia.  Our store showcases incredible reclaimed jewellery, homewares and children's-wares, furniture, bicycles and electronics.  We have given the community a place that they can come to be inspired to reuse what already exists, and, in some cases, where they can organise their old goods to be reimagined into something perfect for their new lifestyle.

We have had a great response from the community to this concept, and have been lucky enough to run it in the heart of Geelong thanks to Renew Geelong and Market Square Shopping Centre.  This has allowed us to show that reclaimed goods can be just as desireable as new if presented in the same manner.  It has also allowed us to identify the desires of so many in the community to find ways to repair or reuse what they already have instead of being forced to buy new. 

Since opening we have saved over 2 tonnes of materials from landfill by returning them to use, and developed some wonderful relationships with re-makers and the community.  2 tonnes of materials is the tip of the waste iceberg.  Our learnings have helped us to shape our design for a community focused hub for repair and reimagination in Geelong.  Up until now we have self funded our social enterprise.   Now we are asking for your help to get to the next level and make our vision for an emporium of reuse and reimagination a reality.

Our vision

Picture yourself walking into a beautiful emporium filled with quality goods at accessible prices. The smell of fresh coffee and chai wafts from one corner, with beautiful colours and textures filling the space.  The bespoke products that surround you are so good that you may not even realise that they are all reused in one form or another.  That coffee that you smell is ethically sourced and is paired with delicious sustainable food.  The retail space leads through to a workshop, where makers and repairers come to produce incredible items from waste or to assist customers with repairing or repurposing their treasured possessions.  This is our vision.

We have the makers, we have the incredible reimagined goods, we have access to the wholesome cafe fare, and we have the team to bring it all together, but we need your help giving it all a home.  Your assistance will help us establish ourselves in a long term space.  It will go towards renting and fitting out a shop front where we can operate our emporium of reimagination.

The details

 

A hub for reuse and reimagination requires a place to sit and imagine, a place to buy, and a place to make.  To bring these elements together we will lease a 300+sqm space close to Geelong, with easy road and public transport access.  At the entrance to the space will sit an ethical cafe, serving simple, quality, sustainable food and drink, where you can sit, dream, and collaborate on incredible reuse projects.  The next section of the space will be filled with the best reclaimed and reimagined goods around, ready to take home and enjoy.  Towards the back there will be a simple workshop where repair cafes can operate, and individual makers can offer their services in repair or reimagination.

Based on the current rental market we're expecting to spend around $60,000/year on rent for a suitable space.  Our $35,000 goal will allow us to establish the business without a rental overhead for 6 months, with the remainder going towards fitout.  We aim to match that with government funding to stretch our rent-free period to 12 months, allowing us greater opportunity to become self sustaining.

Our why and our impact

The average Australian uses 35 tonnes of natural resouces a year.  If all of the world used the same amount of resources as Australia we would need 5.2 planet earths to survive.  As Australians we throw away 67 million tonnes of solid waste every year.  This cannot continue, and one of the best ways we can change this is by reusing what we already have.

We have a 2 year old daughter and another child on the way.  Many of our friends have young children as well.  We want our kids to be able to grow up in a world at least as clean and as natural as the one we grew up in.  For this to happen, change needs to occur.  Many people campaign for change, for governments to make policy, for people to change their ways, for big businesses to reduce their impacts.  We're taking a different approach.  Instead of telling people to change, we want to facilitate their change.  We want to make reclaimed goods a viable alternative to new by making them accessible.  We want to give people somewhere to go when they want to repair what they already have. We want to prove to people that second hand isn't second best. 

This is why we launched The Reimaginarium, and this is why we are now asking for your assistance in taking reuse to the next level.  ReTuna in Eskilstuna Sweden has generated 50 jobs in their community by making reuse accessible, imagine what we can do here in Geelong Australia with your help.

Why we need your help

Would you love to see a hub for reuse in Geelong?  We have poured our time, passion and savings into getting The Reimaginarium to where it is today, but we need your help to bring retail, food and workshop together, and make an even bigger impact with reuse.  We are asking the community for your support in making this next chapter in reuse a success.  We want this to be your project as much as ours, and we are calling on your help to make it a reality. 

If you're not in a position to assist us financially we would love your help with any of the following:

  • Spreading the word about our work and this campaign to all of your friends and anyone you think would be interested in our endeavour
  • Letting any professionals or politicians who may be able to assist us know about what we're up to
  • Helping us find and negotiate a lease on a suitable property
  • Helping out with fitout and materials.

Where your donations will go

All funds raised in this campaign will help us find a long term home for our Better Than New emporium in Geelong.

We are targeting $35,000 in this campaign, which will give us enough money to undertake a sustainable fitout of our new space, and cover 6 months rent to allow us to establish the emporium in a suiable location.  

Anything less than $35,000 will still be used carefully to continue and grow The Reimaginarium, we just will not be able to include some features such as the reuse workshop.  If fundraising exceeds $35,000 we won't be throwing the money in the air and celebrating, we will be putting it to good use to make our emporium even better for the reuse community.

  • $50k raised will provide a 6 month rent free period, allow us to fit out our retail and workshop spaces, and take ownership of our cafe fitout
  • $75k raised will allow us to do all of the above with at least 12 months rent free to establish ourselves
  • $100k raised will allow us to take on a larger premisis and look at incorporating community resources such as a tool library
  • $250k raised will allow us to take on a bigger premisis again and look at bringing other sustainable businesses under the one roof to create an entire sustainable shopping ecosystem
  • $1m+ raised would probably make us collapse in gratitude, but it would also allow us to buy our reuse emporium a forever home.

Are we mad to list stretch goals so far past our initial ask? Probably, but we believe in a more sustainable future, and we are working hard to make that a reality.

    Timeline

    Our current shop front is not going to be available indefinitely, so we are already searching for the perfect location for the next phase of our reuse journey.  Location and building layout are critical to the success of our reuse hub, so we intend to move quickly when the perfect space becomes available.  Our aim is to be operational in our improved format before the end of 2020.

    The future

    Our little hub of reimagination will not solve all of Australia's waste problems, but it is a start.  With time we hope it will grow to support more and more makers, and that once the model is optimised we will be able to roll it out in other cities within Australia, or even around the world.  As re-makers grow their abilities and ranges, hopefully they will reach the point where they can open their own retail spaces, and our reimagined department stores can make way for reimagined shopping centres. How amazing would that be!

    What’s in it for you (perks)

    For those of you who are based in Australia, hopefully you will feel that the biggest perk of all for supporting this campaign is being able to enjoy reimagination emporium yourself.  For the makers it will provide a convenient central outlet and exposure for your work.  For the buyers it will provide a centralised physical and online retail space for the best available reused goods.  We also hope that doing your little bit to change the world will give you some pretty good feels.  If that's not enough, then check out the wonderful perks to the right of your screen.

    Summing up

    We believe the future is sustainable, for our kids, for yours, and for all creatures great and small.  We believe that reuse will play a big part in a more sustainable future.  Plenty of clever people are already having an impact by making amazing reused goods, and we working to amplify this by making their wares accessible.  To have a bigger impact, we need to go bigger.  We need to provide a hub for people to imagine, purchase and create quality, long lasting, reused goods, and we need your help to do it.  So please, support us in creating a more sustainable future for everyone.

    Who we are

    Ryan - I've been involved in reuse for as long as I can remember.  In Primary School I would take bicycles from the hard rubbish and repair them or turn them into unique creations.  At the end of high school I handpainted suit jackets and sold them in markets.  My reimagining of old motorcycles has won awards, and while I have studied and worked in designing new products, my passion has always been for seeing the potential in used.  After working outside of business hours for many years making and creating with used goods, two years ago I took the leap with the birth of my daughter to take on Reuse full time.  The development of my Vintage Bluetooth Speaker range lead to the founding of The Reimaginarium, and I can't wait to take it to the next level and make it a truly special part of the reuse ecosystem.

    Theresa - I have always been a bit of a sentimentalist. When visiting my grandparents' house, I used to marvel at the stories behind their pieces of furniture, wonder at the pictures on the wall, and delight in the leather bound books on their bookshelf.  For our first date, Ryan took me to the vintage markets around Melbourne where we perused all the old and dusty items for sale creatively reimagining how we could turn old chandeliers into hat stands, and vintage chests into coffee tables. With the Reimaginarium opening in Geelong, we have successfully shared this enthusiasm with the community and have worked with so many wonderful creative remakers. I am very excited to see how far we can take this concept as we expand our reach and make even more of an impact with reuse. 

    As we grow - Each of us bring our own unique passions and talents to The Reimaginarium, and as it grows, so too will the team.  We have some incredibly talented friends, each with their own refined reuse skills in diverse and complimentary areas. As the business grows they will become a part of our team and of our success.

The smell of fresh coffee and chai wafts from one corner, with beautiful colours and textures filling the space.  The bespoke products that surround you are so good that you may not even realise that they are all reused in one form or another.  That coffee that you smell is ethically sourced and is paired with delicious sustainable food.  The retail space leads through to a workshop, where makers and repairers come to produce incredible items from waste or to assist customers with repairing or repurposing their treasured possessions.  This is our vision.We have the makers, we have the incredible reimagined goods, we have access to the wholesome cafe fare, and we have the team to bring it all together, but we need your help giving it all a home.  Your assistance will help us establish ourselves in a long term space.  It will go towards renting and fitting out a shop front where we can operate our emporium of reimagination.The details
 


A hub for reuse and reimagination requires a place to sit and imagine, a place to buy, and a place to make.  To bring these elements together we will lease a 300+sqm space close to Geelong, with easy road and public transport access.  At the entrance to the space will sit an ethical cafe, serving simple, quality, sustainable food and drink, where you can sit, dream, and collaborate on incredible reuse projects.  The next section of the space will be filled with the best reclaimed and reimagined goods around, ready to take home and enjoy.  Towards the back there will be a simple workshop where repair cafes can operate, and individual makers can offer their services in repair or reimagination.
Based on the current rental market we're expecting to spend around $60,000/year on rent for a suitable space.  Our $35,000 goal will allow us to establish the business without a rental overhead for 6 months, with the remainder going towards fitout.  We aim to match that with government funding to stretch our rent-free period to 12 months, allowing us greater opportunity to become self sustaining.Our why and our impactThe average Australian uses 35 tonnes of natural resouces a year.  If all of the world used the same amount of resources as Australia we would need 5.2 planet earths to survive.  As Australians we throw away 67 million tonnes of solid waste every year.  This cannot continue, and one of the best ways we can change this is by reusing what we already have.We have a 2 year old daughter and another child on the way.  Many of our friends have young children as well.  We want our kids to be able to grow up in a world at least as clean and as natural as the one we grew up in.  For this to happen, change needs to occur.  Many people campaign for change, for governments to make policy, for people to change their ways, for big businesses to reduce their impacts.  We're taking a different approach.  Instead of telling people to change, we want to facilitate their change.  We want to make reclaimed goods a viable alternative to new by making them accessible.  We want to give people somewhere to go when they want to repair what they already have. We want to prove to people that second hand isn't second best. This is why we launched The Reimaginarium, and this is why we are now asking for your assistance in taking reuse to the next level.  ReTuna in Eskilstuna Sweden has generated 50 jobs in their community by making reuse accessible, imagine what we can do here in Geelong Australia with your help.Why we need your helpWould you love to see a hub for reuse in Geelong?  We have poured our time, passion and savings into getting The Reimaginarium to where it is today, but we need your help to bring retail, food and workshop together, and make an even bigger impact with reuse.  We are asking the community for your support in making this next chapter in reuse a success.  We want this to be your project as much as ours, and we are calling on your help to make it a reality. If you're not in a position to assist us financially we would love your help with any of the following:
Spreading the word about our work and this campaign to all of your friends and anyone you think would be interested in our endeavour
Letting any professionals or politicians who may be able to assist us know about what we're up to
Helping us find and negotiate a lease on a suitable property
Helping out with fitout and materials.
Where your donations will goAll funds raised in this campaign will help us find a long term home for our Better Than New emporium in Geelong.We are targeting $35,000 in this campaign, which will give us enough money to undertake a sustainable fitout of our new space, and cover 6 months rent to allow us to establish the emporium in a suiable location.  Anything less than $35,000 will still be used carefully to continue and grow The Reimaginarium, we just will not be able to include some features such as the reuse workshop.  If fundraising exceeds $35,000 we won't be throwing the money in the air and celebrating, we will be putting it to good use to make our emporium even better for the reuse community.
$50k raised will provide a 6 month rent free period, allow us to fit out our retail and workshop spaces, and take ownership of our cafe fitout
$75k raised will allow us to do all of the above with at least 12 months rent free to establish ourselves
$100k raised will allow us to take on a larger premisis and look at incorporating community resources such as a tool library
$250k raised will allow us to take on a bigger premisis again and look at bringing other sustainable businesses under the one roof to create an entire sustainable shopping ecosystem
$1m+ raised would probably make us collapse in gratitude, but it would also allow us to buy our reuse emporium a forever home.
Are we mad to list stretch goals so far past our initial ask? Probably, but we believe in a more sustainable future, and we are working hard to make that a reality.TimelineOur current shop front is not going to be available indefinitely, so we are already searching for the perfect location for the next phase of our reuse journey.  Location and building layout are critical to the success of our reuse hub, so we intend to move quickly when the perfect space becomes available.  Our aim is to be operational in our improved format before the end of 2020.The futureOur little hub of reimagination will not solve all of Australia's waste problems, but it is a start.  With time we hope it will grow to support more and more makers, and that once the model is optimised we will be able to roll it out in other cities within Australia, or even around the world.  As re-makers grow their abilities and ranges, hopefully they will reach the point where they can open their own retail spaces, and our reimagined department stores can make way for reimagined shopping centres. How amazing would that be!What’s in it for you (perks)For those of you who are based in Australia, hopefully you will feel that the biggest perk of all for supporting this campaign is being able to enjoy reimagination emporium yourself.  For the makers it will provide a convenient central outlet and exposure for your work.  For the buyers it will provide a centralised physical and online retail space for the best available reused goods.  We also hope that doing your little bit to change the world will give you some pretty good feels.  If that's not enough, then check out the wonderful perks to the right of your screen.Summing upWe believe the future is sustainable, for our kids, for yours, and for all creatures great and small.  We believe that reuse will play a big part in a more sustainable future.  Plenty of clever people are already having an impact by making amazing reused goods, and we working to amplify this by making their wares accessible.  To have a bigger impact, we need to go bigger.  We need to provide a hub for people to imagine, purchase and create quality, long lasting, reused goods, and we need your help to do it.  So please, support us in creating a more sustainable future for everyone.Who we areRyan - I've been involved in reuse for as long as I can remember.  In Primary School I would take bicycles from the hard rubbish and repair them or turn them into unique creations.  At the end of high school I handpainted suit jackets and sold them in markets.  My reimagining of old motorcycles has won awards, and while I have studied and worked in designing new products, my passion has always been for seeing the potential in used.  After working outside of business hours for many years making and creating with used goods, two years ago I took the leap with the birth of my daughter to take on Reuse full time.  The development of my Vintage Bluetooth Speaker range lead to the founding of The Reimaginarium, and I can't wait to take it to the next level and make it a truly special part of the reuse ecosystem.Theresa - I have always been a bit of a sentimentalist. When visiting my grandparents' house, I used to marvel at the stories behind their pieces of furniture, wonder at the pictures on the wall, and delight in the leather bound books on their bookshelf.  For our first date, Ryan took me to the vintage markets around Melbourne where we perused all the old and dusty items for sale creatively reimagining how we could turn old chandeliers into hat stands, and vintage chests into coffee tables. With the Reimaginarium opening in Geelong, we have successfully shared this enthusiasm with the community and have worked with so many wonderful creative remakers. I am very excited to see how far we can take this concept as we expand our reach and make even more of an impact with reuse. As we grow - Each of us bring our own unique passions and talents to The Reimaginarium, and as it grows, so too will the team.  We have some incredibly talented friends, each with their own refined reuse skills in diverse and complimentary areas. As the business grows they will become a part of our team and of our success.

story:
This March, we (Thompson and Alex) will be competing the Elk Mountain Grand Traverse to raise money for the Aspen Center for Environmental Studies (ACES_www.aspennature.org). 

The traverse is a 42-mile unsupported backcountry ski race from Crested Butte to Aspen, Colorado. As a team racing for charity, we have committed ourselves to raise $1500 for ACES, an Aspen based non-profit organization that fosters an appreciation and understanding for the environment through education, conservation, and community.  Their programs and efforts include environmental education classes for kids, naturalist led hikes for adults, evening speaker series, birding, conservation and restoration work, the Hallam lake nature preserve, Rock Bottom Ranch, and a continued effort to facilitate a connection between people and the natural world. 

To help ACES continue in all the great work they do, we will be racing through night of March 28th and day of March 29th, climbing nearly 8000 vertical ft over more than 40-miles, traversing the impressive Elk Mountains of Central Colorado. 

Please help us reach our goal and support this great non-profit organization. 

"For the Green Wolf" _ Our team name in honor of Aldo Leopold and the green fire that forever altered his view of nature's majesty.

As a team racing for charity, we have committed ourselves to raise $1500 for ACES, an Aspen based non-profit organization that fosters an appreciation and understanding for the environment through education, conservation, and community.  Their programs and efforts include environmental education classes for kids, naturalist led hikes for adults, evening speaker series, birding, conservation and restoration work, the Hallam lake nature preserve, Rock Bottom Ranch, and a continued effort to facilitate a connection between people and the natural world. To help ACES continue in all the great work they do, we will be racing through night of March 28th and day of March 29th, climbing nearly 8000 vertical ft over more than 40-miles, traversing the impressive Elk Mountains of Central Colorado. Please help us reach our goal and support this great non-profit organization. "For the Green Wolf" _ Our team name in honor of Aldo Leopold and the green fire that forever altered his view of nature's majesty.

story:
Shahana is 27. She lives in a small village in South-West Bangladesh.  Two years ago she began to notice black spots on her palms.

Like many others in her community, doctors diagnosed her with arsenicosis, a skin disease which typically occurs when people have frequent contact with arsenic-contaminated water.  Very often it is a precursor to skin cancer.

Shahana had been drinking water from a contaminated well for more than 10 years.


Up to half the population of Bangladesh has been exposed to arsenic contamination through its drinking water. 

The World Health Organisation has called it:

    "The single worst case of mass poisoning in human history".

Many thousands - perhaps millions - are being slowly affected by arsenic poisoning, or arsenicosis, which causes cancers, kidney and heart failures, and long-term lung problems.

1 in 5 current deaths in Bangladesh are as a result of arsenicosis.

We can stop this

Help us to raise enough money to protect 10 villages in South-West Bangladesh from arsenic-contaminated water.

Our campaign goal is £55,000. But whatever we raise, we will be able to protect people in direct, practical ways from arsenic contamination.

TAKE PART IN OUR CAMPAIGN and participate in a small but achievable step to deal with a vast and deadly problem.



Why is this happening?

The tube-wells were constructed in the 1970s and 80s by aid agencies who were acting to eliminate the many diseases, such as cholera, typhoid, and TB, which were spread by the use of untreated surface water. In this, they were largely successful.


What was not understood at the time was the risk of groundwater contamination by arsenic, which occurs naturally within the earth in high levels throughout the Ganges Delta.

About 1 in 5 of the tube-wells constructed have been found to be contaminated by arsenic. In the early 1990s, the first signs of arsenic poisoning appeared among people using the tube-wells.


    - Watch Prof. Andrew Meharg, a world expert on arsenic contamination, talk about the problem

    - Read the WHO report and about the more recent Lancet report

    - More questions? Read our Frequently Asked Questions  about arsenic contamination in Bangladesh and this campaign.


The SONO Arsenic Filter

There is currently no complete or long-term solution to the problem - but there are effective solutions which can be implemented at a local level.

The SONO Arsenic Filter is being used by thousands of families and communities in Bangladesh, and has been proven to eliminate arsenic contamination and to provide safe drinking and cooking water. 

The Filter - which consists of two buckets containing porous iron, charcoal, sand and bits of brick - filters nearly all of the arsenic from well water.

The SONO Arsenic Filter was invented in 2006 by Abul Hussam, a Bangladeshi who is chemistry professor at George Mason University (GMU) in Fairfax, Virginia. Hussam developed his filter after years of testing hundreds of prototypes. The Filter was awarded the prestigious Grainger Challenge Prize for Sustainability by the US National Academy of Engineering.


What's the point of this crowdfunding campaign?

The scale of the problem of arsenic contamination is vast. It is also a problem which is largely ignored. And while it is ignored, huge numbers of people are suffering slow, painful and unnecessary deaths - deaths which relatively simple, low-cost interventions could prevent.


The objectives of this campaign are:

story:
Kill the Cup is a startup nonprofit that encourages people to bring a reusable cup when they get coffee. Did you know that 100 BILLION disposable cups are sent to U.S. landfills each year?


Most coffee cups are coated with plastic and can't be recycled. Plastic creates toxic pollution at every stage of its existence: manufacture, use, and disposal.

But what incentives are in place to encourage change? Ten cent discounts are insufficient, and most people grow tired of direct environmental messaging.

At Kill the Cup, we make it FUN for people to bring reusable cups. When it comes to environmental behavior change, research shows that consumers are most likely to respond to social norms messaging.


After buying their morning coffee, we encourage people to upload photos with their reusable cups. Each photo serves as entry into weekly and grand prize raffles! These photos help establish the social norms that prove so effective.

Successful pilot programs on college campuses have generated a 25% increase in the rate at which people bring reusable cups when they buy coffee -- in just 4 weeks! And get this: the coffee shops were more profitable. So what's next?

Kill the Cup is raising funds to support a multi-university "$10,000 Reusable Cup Challenge" that will allow university student organizations to compete with one another to create the most environmental impact on campus. 

Think of it as March Madness -- but for student associations that are competing to have the greatest environmental impact. We have already receive interest from universities in Chicago, Boston, Washington, D.C., Los Angeles, and San Diego.

We need your help to make it happen! Kill the Cup has partnered with a number of forward-thinking companies to offer exciting perks in exchange for your contributions.



The reusable mugs and eco-friendly t-shirts will be ordered at the end of the Indiegogo campaign, so it may take until August to receive your perks. We hope you don't mind!

Thanks to our friends at Causora, we are able to offer One-for-One rewards. You can receive Thank You Credits that are redeemable at a growing number of socially conscious merchants, including TOMS, Lyft, and Zipcar.

$10,000 will be used towards prize money for the Reusable Cup Challenge! These funds will be redistributed to student organizations to help them further environmental initiatives at their own campus.

We'll also invest $7,500 in a technology platform that will streamline many of the manual processes that make our campaigns "go." And the remaining funds will be used to co-brand all of the perks for the Indiegogo campaign.


Drew Beal and Mike Taylor, Kill the Cup's co-founders, met in 2011 when they started grad school at UC San Diego's Rady School of Management. They launched Kill the Cup as their MBA capstone project in April 2013.

Testimonial

"This phenomenal team developed their first social venture project, Kill the Cup, in my class at the Rady School of Management. They were exceptional students - among the hardest working and most focused in the class. They learned, listened, persevered and made a real impact at UCSD in reducing the use of paper coffee cups and generating excitement around sustainability and corporate social responsibility."

Georgetown (Fall 2013)


Last Fall, we teamed up with The Students of Georgetown, Inc. to run a Kill the Cup campaign at the D.C.-based university. They ran the program for four weeks, and replicated the success of our pilot campaign.

Testimonial

“We’re really hoping that members of the Georgetown community will become aware of how wasteful coffee cups are. We’re hoping to run it every year and to get people excited about it and thinking about sustainability.”

Stanford Demo Day


Testimonial

“Kill the Cup is driven by their passion for environmental impact and they impressed investors, partners and companies during our Demo Days across the country. Kill the Cup won the crowd vote for "Best Pitch" and "Most Impactful" at the event on Stanford University's campus - the first time this has happened!"

story:
Short Summary

My name is Odette Curtis and I am a passionate conservation ecologist, obsessed and in love with one of the most threatened, neglected, poorly-understood and bio-diverse habitats on planet earth: Renosterveld. This special habitat is part of the smallest and richest Plant Kingdom: the Fynbos Biome.

Renosterveld is the richest bulb habitat in the world and is most renowned for its extraordinary displays of spring (August/September) flowers which result in a grassy-shrubland habitat transforming into a wonderland filled with botanical gems. The Overberg's renosterveld is full of endemic species and we are only beginning to appreciate the richness of this incredible system, having already found six new species in this habitat over the last two years. However, this precious ecosystem is severely threatened, as more than 95% of it has been ploughed up for agriculture over the last 200 years, rendering it Critically Endangered and thus facing a very real risk of extinction in the not-too-distant future.  Although these remnants have been on the conservation-planning radar for a few decades already, very little action has been taken to ensure that they are afforded formal protection of any sort. I started the Overberg Lowlands Conservation Trust (an NPO) two years ago, because I realised that if we don't act now, we may lose this ecosystem forever.

We have several objectives as a Trust and they are all centred on working with private landowners and communities to improve our understanding of this habitat, while working together to find solutions for its long-term conservation. To learn more about our NGO, please visit www.overbergrenosterveld.org.za and also watch our promotional movie on http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LNDMYQYNeQc to learn more about the Overberg Lowlands Conservation Trust and our broader objectives.

Of critical importance here is that we have a base where landowners, tourists, farm- workers, school children, scientists and ecology students can come together and learn more about the ecosystem that we are trying to save.

With this particular campaign, we are aiming to set up a Visitor & Research Centre in the heart of the largest remaining area of lowland renosterveld in the Overberg and in fact, the world! This will be a gigantic step forward for renosterveld conservation, as it will not only provide a base for further research by students and ecologists; it will also give renosterveld conservation a 'home' within one of the richest and most intact remaining remnants. We believe that the positive knock-on effects of creating such a presence in this highly transformed landscape will be significant. I am very excited as we have the opportunity to create a conservation legacy here!

What We Need & What You Get

We already have the land and infrastructure: In a collaborative project, WWF-SA recently purchased the farm Haarwegskloof (500 ha renosterveld) and we (the Overberg Lowlands conservation Trust) have been awarded the honour of becoming the Management Authority on this for the next 30 years.

We are looking to raise funds to complete the building renovations (on the existing house) and set the centre up to: accommodate students and visiting scientists, facilitate and provide lectures, generate herbariums from local species, generate field guides for landowners, establish a small library, etc. We will also use a small proportion of the funds raised here for an opening event, whereby we hope to attract more interest in the centre, as well as future collaborative eco-tourism opportunities.

Irrespective of whether or not we reach our funding goal, we will use any monies raised here towards kick-starting this initiative.

Perks for you as a donor

As our way of thanking you for your pledges, we will be sending you renosterveld memorobelia in the form of photographs of rare and threatened species taken in renosterveld, our annual report, opportunities to name a room in the centre after you or your business, and more (depending on what you pledge). 

The Impact

The Overberg Lowlands Conservation Trust is completely committed to long-term conservation of renosterveld in the Overberg. We are guided by a small, but high-calibre Board of very passionate individuals and our Chairperson is a farmer himself! I have a PhD in renosterveld management and have been passionate about this vegetation type and its conservation for almost 10 years. I am responsible for fundraising, working with landowners, continuing my own research while attracting students to grow our research capabilities, building relationships with our partners and finding innovative ways to conserve renosterveld for all to enjoy into the future.

Ultimately, we aim to build relationships across the Overberg's wheat-belt in a way that ensures the long-term preservation of these systems within a productive landscape. We want to ensure that landscapes are LIVING LANDSCAPES and that conservation and agriculture CAN thrive side-by-side.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot make a financial contribution to this campaign, you can still contribute by spreading the word - tell all your friends and colleagues about this exciting initiative! Please share this in any way that you see fit - Facebook, Twitter, Email - every little bit counts and the more people that know about this, the more we can do for renosterveld! And don't forget to make use of the Indiegogo Share Tools. We also welcome any donations in the form of furniture and equipment for the centre.

The Overberg's renosterveld is full of endemic species and we are only beginning to appreciate the richness of this incredible system, having already found six new species in this habitat over the last two years. However, this precious ecosystem is severely threatened, as more than 95% of it has been ploughed up for agriculture over the last 200 years, rendering it Critically Endangered and thus facing a very real risk of extinction in the not-too-distant future.  Although these remnants have been on the conservation-planning radar for a few decades already, very little action has been taken to ensure that they are afforded formal protection of any sort. I started the Overberg Lowlands Conservation Trust (an NPO) two years ago, because I realised that if we don't act now, we may lose this ecosystem forever.We have several objectives as a Trust and they are all centred on working with private landowners and communities to improve our understanding of this habitat, while working together to find solutions for its long-term conservation. To learn more about our NGO, please visit www.overbergrenosterveld.org.za and also watch our promotional movie on http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LNDMYQYNeQc
to learn more about the Overberg Lowlands Conservation Trust and our broader objectives. 
 Of critical importance here is that we have a base where landowners, tourists, farm- workers, school children, scientists and ecology students can come together and learn more about the ecosystem that we are trying to save. 
With this particular campaign, we are aiming to set up a Visitor & Research Centre in the heart of the largest remaining area of lowland renosterveld in the Overberg and in fact, the world! This will be a gigantic step forward for renosterveld conservation, as it will not only provide a base for further research by students and ecologists; it will also give renosterveld conservation a 'home' within one of the richest and most intact remaining remnants. We believe that the positive knock-on effects of creating such a presence in this highly transformed landscape will be significant. I am very excited as we have the opportunity to create a conservation legacy here! What We Need & What You GetWe already have the land and infrastructure: In a collaborative project, WWF-SA recently purchased the farm Haarwegskloof (500 ha renosterveld) and we (the Overberg Lowlands conservation Trust) have been awarded the honour of becoming the Management Authority on this for the next 30 years.We are looking to raise funds to complete the building renovations (on the existing house) and set the centre up to: accommodate students and visiting scientists, facilitate and provide lectures, generate herbariums from local species, generate field guides for landowners, establish a small library, etc. We will also use a small proportion of the funds raised here for an opening event, whereby we hope to attract more interest in the centre, as well as future collaborative eco-tourism opportunities. Irrespective of whether or not we reach our funding goal, we will use any monies raised here towards kick-starting this initiative. Perks for you as a donorAs our way of thanking you for your pledges, we will be sending you renosterveld memorobelia in the form of photographs of rare and threatened species taken in renosterveld, our annual report, opportunities to name a room in the centre after you or your business, and more (depending on what you pledge). The ImpactThe Overberg Lowlands Conservation Trust is completely committed to long-term conservation of renosterveld in the Overberg. We are guided by a small, but high-calibre Board of very passionate individuals and our Chairperson is a farmer himself! I have a PhD in renosterveld management and have been passionate about this vegetation type and its conservation for almost 10 years. I am responsible for fundraising, working with landowners, continuing my own research while attracting students to grow our research capabilities, building relationships with our partners and finding innovative ways to conserve renosterveld for all to enjoy into the future. Ultimately, we aim to build relationships across the Overberg's wheat-belt in a way that ensures the long-term preservation of these systems within a productive landscape. We want to ensure that landscapes are LIVING LANDSCAPES and that conservation and agriculture CAN thrive side-by-side. Other Ways You Can HelpIf you cannot make a financial contribution to this campaign, you can still contribute by spreading the word - tell all your friends and colleagues about this exciting initiative! Please share this in any way that you see fit - Facebook, Twitter, Email - every little bit counts and the more people that know about this, the more we can do for renosterveld! And don't forget to make use of the Indiegogo Share Tools. We also welcome any donations in the form of furniture and equipment for the centre.

story:
Who are we?

We are a group of youth leaders from various universities in NYC (New School, Fordham, Columbia, NYU) passionate about social justice and a beautiful future. We think climate justice is the highest form of social justice, as we're fighting for the right of every single beings on Earth to enjoy a clean, just, and wonderful future. But we are also young, many of us lack training, and as students, we are... well, also broke. 

What is Power Shift?

Power Shift 13 is a national conference that takes place in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, where 10,000 youth leaders will converge to address the climate crisis. We will be armed with the knowledge and skills to fight against fossil fuel and towards a clean, just world. Power Shift 2013 will be the conference that defines and inspires a new generation of activists. We are united, we defend the future, we believe everyone is entitled to a clean and just society!

That sounds amazing, doesn't it! At Power Shift we’ll spend the weekend training on effective strategies, sharing solutions, networking, and taking action to make sure our voices are heard. NYC YOUTH LEADERS WANTS TO BE THERE! But we have to get there first, and we need your help!

What We Need & What You Get

We are striving to bring at least 100 students from NYC passionate about our cause to Power Shift, so they can come back empowered, inspired, and ready to take on today's biggest issues. We know many students want to come, but face great financial constraint. Registration cost $65 and housing cost at least $30 per day, so we're trying to raise $3000 to provide them with free transportation and ease the pain on our chip-bag pocket (because contents are mostly air).

We are getting there by two buses - the cheapest option we have. WE DON'T CARE IF IT'S UNCOMFORTABLE, WE JUST REALLY WANT TO GET THERE! If we reach our goal, Power Shift will be made accessible to so many students with financial constraints! Help us bring aspiring youth leaders to Power Shift! 

Please help us achieve our goal by donating any amount you can. Also for a donation of $25 you will receive a box of 10 homemade, luscious, chocolate-filled, love-infused cookies as our thank you gift! Don't worry, we test taste every batch to make sure they are nothing but perfection.

Can't donate? No worries, please help us spread the word by telling EVERYONE you know about our campaign. And once again, THANK YOU SO MUCH! WE CAN'T DO THIS WITHOUT YOUR HELP!

story:
Who is SIBAT?

Starting out as a farmer’s advocacy coalition in 1984 that promoted appropriate technology (AT), SIBAT has a long history of  empowering rural communities by using sound science to achieve community goals.  Its AT niches are the following:

  •   Sustainable agriculture
  •   Renewable energy
  •   Water resources development
  •   Community adaptation to climate change in agriculture
  •   Training of farmers, women and other rural sectors

Over the past 30 years, SIBAT has grown to address another needs, such as the power and water rehabilitation in Typhoon Haiyan affected areas.

SIBAT has been to at least 500 Filipino communities, and held more than 700 sustainable agriculture trainings for more than 20000 farmers (including women and indigenous people). These trainings are mostly held in the farming communities, with a subset taking place at our 1.3 hectare organic farm and training center in Capas, Tarlac. 

Today, we need your help to further our mission of reaching as many people and communities as possible. Our farmer training facility is no longer sufficient to meet our growing needs, and we need funding to make it bigger, sturdier and more efficient. Sustainable agriculture techniques will be spread to an even larger number of Filipino farmers through regularly held seminars and outreach activities in this Sustainable Agriculture Training Center (SATC). 

What We Need & What You Get

All of the money you donate will be used directly for the refurbishment of the Sustainable Agriculture Training Center. Currently, the training house roof is made of native materials (bamboo), and is badly in need of repair and improvement.  This is our number one priority. 

Based on our previous building experience, we estimate that $5,000 (P225,000) will be needed for repairing the native roofing and adding an additional layer of steel sheeting that will make the roof more reliably leak-proof. The native thatched roofing allows for ventilation, so by keeping it in place we will still enjoy its benefits during the hot summer.

In the Philippines, labor and materials are relatively inexpensive, so your money can go a lot further toward making a significant impact! Here are some examples of what you can buy with just $5:

  • Lunch for 5 people
  • A 25 kg sac of cement
  • A 3'x6' sheet of steel roofing
  • 2 peices of coco lumber (2" x 3" x 12")
  • 28 concrete hollow blocks, size 4
If we are unable to reach our target goal of $5,000, your donation will still be put toward the eventual improvement of this training center. We will ensure that this project reaches completion by continuing to apply for grants and other funding opportunities. If we exceed our funding expectations, all additional funds will be used toward our next construction goal, cottages on the farm for farmers and guests to use during multi-day trainings and expansion of the size of the training center.
The Impact

Once the training center is running all year-round, we will be able to reach more farmers. This will benefit:

  • The environment. Every farmer that switches to organic methods reduces the number of toxic pesticides being introduced into the soil and water of the Philippines.
  • The economy. Farmers can sell organic produce for a higher profit, especially with all the money they save when they stop buying imported pesticides and seeds. 
  • THE FARMERS! Our main goal at SIBAT is to empower farmers.   Through sustainable agriculture, they can play a vital role in protecting their health, their families, the environment and their land. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    We know that not everyone is able to contribute financially. Firstly, we want you to know that even the smallest donation makes a big difference in helping us reach our goals. If you want to help our campaign in other ways, we encourage you to please share this page within your networks. 

    If you would like to make a donation of building materials or construction services, please send us a message and we can discuss those possibilities.

story:
Let's Build a Whale to Save Whales!

Mz Blue - our traveling inflatable Blue Whale

The Great Whale Conservancy has shown Mz Blue, our life-size 90 foot blue whale all over the country, from Washington, DC to Santa Barbara, California.  Wherever she goes, she raises awareness and political pressure to try and move commercial shipping lanes further from critical blue whale habitat and stop the deadly collisions between whales and ships.


Mz Blue needs a Baby Blue!

The demand for Mz Blue to make appearances has become too great for the Great Whale Conservancy to transport her to every possible location.  GWC needs a Baby Blue to reach out to many, many more people before more blue whales are killed.


A life-size 22-foot Baby Blue whale will be easier to inflate, cheaper to transport and require a smaller crew.  She can join more parades, host more political events and visit more schools to meet future whale caretakers.  She'll carry the message of protecting blue whales to an ever larger audience, increasing support for protecting whales wherever she goes.


Blue Whales - the greatest of the Great Whales

The whaling industry almost killed them all...


Endangered blue whales are barely hanging on!

Why don’t the whales swim away from the ships?  No one knows.  They may be distracted while feeding… or… the noise pollution in our oceans may keep them from hearing approaching ships.

Why can’t the ships steer away from the whales?  These giant ships are too big and take too long to turn.


Why Baby Blue?

Mz Blue has proven to be an effective spokes-whale, raising awareness of the critical issues around the safety and security of blue whales.  But at 90- feet long and weighing almost 250 pounds, she requires a large truck and a big crew for every event!  It takes almost two hours to inflate or deflate Mz Blue.  At 30 pounds, Baby Blue will be transportable in the trunk of a car and only require a team of two at every inflation.  And Baby Blue inflates in only 15 minutes!

We Appreciate All You Do For Us!

The Great Whale Conservancy exists because of your support.  And we want to reward the people that support us with amazing perks:

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t afford a donation to help create Baby Blue, there are many other ways to help.  Go to our website, www.greatwhaleconservancy.org where you can sign our on-line petition, get the addresses and phone numbers of administration officials who need to hear from people like you, and leave messages for us with ideas of where to hold an event, or tell us if your school would like us to come and spend a day talking about whales! 

And please help spread the word about this campaign and GWC’s work through your social media contacts. 

Thanks!
The Great Whale Conservancy
