story:
Here is what it is all about

The HOPE project is all about promoting highly efficient solar water lifting devices with a network of drip irrigation systems for enhanced horticultural production in order to reduce drudgery and increase household income for poor rural women in the Gambia.  


The project was conceived by poor rural communities themselves, made real by your generous contributions, rejoiced and celebrated by vulnerable women, girls and children out there in the rural communities of the Gambia. 

 What is the problem about?

Rural communities in the Gambia are grabbling with low agricultural productivity, compounded by limited off – farm economic opportunities. Women, girls and children are bearing the brunt of the consequences of this situation by engaging in tedious and time consuming activities such as scavenging post harvest losses of groundnuts/coos, involving in charcoal burning, fuel wood selling to raise income for family survival. This has had a negative bearing on the health status of women, and as well as on the academic performance of school girls in the rural communities.

 It is on this premise that this campaign is launched with a goal to raise $25, 000 to pilot this highly efficient solar water lifting devices in two rural communities.  The funds among other things will set up a well protected one hectare perimeter garden with high tech – irrigation system in two communities. It will also help build capacities of 555 vegetable growers on best horticultural production practices including mentoring and coaching for increased yields. 


Significance of your contributions

The penny you contribute towards this project will bring about a significant turning point on the lives and livelihoods of these vulnerable women, girls and children in the rural communities of the Gambia. Through your generous contributions, the project will be actualized and will lead to reducing drudgery on women and girls in their vegetable production efforts. It will equally increase household income and as well as increase nutritional status of people, especially women and children. With reduced drudgery, performance of girls in schools will significantly increase. In short, your contributions will inject a renewed sense of confidence and self esteem in women and girls – hence ensure a more empowered and economically vibrant society. 


Who are we?

We are a registered local NGO working with the ruralpoor to help address social and economic imbalances in the rural communities of the Gambia.  The organization, Future In our Hands The Gambia (FIOHTG) is working in partnership with a Swedish- Gambian based International NGO called Future In Our Hands – Sweden.  This local organization is under the stewardship of Mr. Yahya Sanyang, who has vast knowledge and experience in the field of development and had worked with highly reputable organizations such as Action Aid International – The Gambia, Concern Universal an International NGO in the Gambia and Save the Children USA as Country Director, Program Coordinator and ProgramManager/ Acting Field Office Directorrespectively. 


 Who can support this cause?

Everyone is herein solicited to support this cause. If you are personate about the welfare of women, girls and children, if you are personate about the environment and if you are personate about supporting and improving rural conditions, this is an opportunity to demonstrate your gesture.  There is nothing more gratifying, rewarding and self fulfilling than lifting someone out of poverty, deprivation and disempowerment.  Therefore your contributions, small or big will make a huge difference! 

However, it is important to note that support isn’t only about sending money. There are so many ways you can provide support to this noble cause. One of the things you can do to support this cause is to get the word out there as much as possible. Share the link with your family, loved ones, friends, well wishers, philanthropists, charities etc, on Facebook, Instagram, Blogs, and Twitter. The success of this endeavor is strongly hinged on the exposure of the project, and Indiegogo has amazing tools to help you share!

Meanwhile, there are amazing perks that we are offering at almost all price levels. For example there will be the following perks for the following range of donations:

$1 - $49 = Card with picture of the product of the project

$50 - $99 = Picture Card + Seasons’ greetings

$100 - $199 = Picture Card + short progress report

$ 200 – above = Picture Card + annual Progress report

In addition to this, the highest two contributors, will have the two facilities named after them or a name of their choice. If you want to donate but  don't want a perk, we will still send you a hand written note for your time and contribution. We will also make sure that your contributions are communicated to all the beneficiaries of this project accordingly. 

Risk and challenges

There is a chance that some people might not find this cause worthy of their time and money. Yes! But this is not stopping us from trying - as the cause is as important to others as it is to us as an organization.  There will be ups and downs along the way, we are prepared to withstand these challenges as and when they cross our way.  However, in the event we do not meet our goal, we won’t give up our drive to continue raising more funds through other means, as we are resolute in finding a solution for women, girls and children in the rural communities of the Gambia.

We thank you very much in advance for your kind support and/or contributions.

story:
A good story can change the world.

Loam's mission is to seed joy, hope, and action in our community through creative and collaborative storytelling. Reawakening Resilience  embodies our belief that the capacity to bounce back from adversity is interwoven into our DNA. As the climate crisis escalates each day, tapping into our inner stores of resilience will help us not only survive but also to thrive during these unprecedented times. 

As the Founder and Creative Director of Loam, I've spent the last two years collaborating with and learning from trailblazing environmental educators, artists, and activists who are working to inspire ecological regeneration and social resilience. My experiences have shown me that storytelling—through the art we make, the meals we cook, the words we write, and the collaborations we create—is  a truly vital and valuable tool for transforming our communities and nourishing narratives of regeneration. 

When you support Reawakening Resilience,  you support artists, activists, and educators who are working to heal our world. You'll help our community publish a carbon neutral print publication that shares tangible strategies for cultivating ecological and social resilience with our 22,000 readers as well as nourish Loam's capacity to support artists and activists working at the intersections of social justice and earth care. 

To bring Reawakening Resilience into being costs $10,000. This helps us to fund printing costs, compensate our contributors, support our gifted graphic designer Giorgia Sage, and ensure that a percentage of profits from every issue of Reawakening Resilience sold helps to nurture reforestation projects. We are proud to print with Hemlock Printers, the most sustainable printer in North America, as well as to mail our magazines in biodegradable mailers with compostable tape. Although ensuring the ecological integrity of our production and distribution process isn’t cheap,  it's a non-negotiable. 

Our choice to print this publication is rooted in our deep belief that our world needs more opportunities to touch, to engage, and to hold. During an era when so many of us are losing hours each day to screen time, our hope is for Reawakening Resilience to be a tangible antidote to disconnection and isolation. We want to provide our readers with a vibrant print publication that you can thumb through again and again to find resources for resilience, luminous art, and inspiring stories to turn to as you navigate a climate changed world. And we want to offer a series of in-person workshops throughout the fall of 2018 that will work in conversation with this publication to connect our readers to the vibrant Loam community. This workshop series will be an opportunity for our readers to explore strategies for ecological, social, and spiritual resilience. 

Reawakening Resilience is our most ambitious project yet. We are so excited to dig into this project with our incredible community and can't wait to share this resource-rich guide to cultivating resilience, nourishing regeneration, and fostering intersectionality across movements with you all. Our (growing!) list of contributors includes:

  • Illustrator Madeleine Welsch
  • Ecologist Sue Pierre of Belowground Activity
  • Artist Laura Dudek
  • Activist Amirio Freeman of Being Green While Black
  • Photographer Aeran Squires of Wild Acorn
  • Artist and Educator Brontë Velez of Lead to Life

Even if you can't contribute to this campaign, we are grateful for your support in so many other ways. You can contribute to Loam (we will be accepting submissions for Reawakening Resilience through April 15th and would love to hear from you all!); you can attend our workshops on low-waste living, resilience, and rituals for regeneration in California, Colorado, Oregon, and New York throughout 2018; and you can share the Loam love with friends by following us on social media where we strive to share inspiring and illuminating stories every week.

With gratitude & love,

Kate

story:
Short Summary

Green Shorts is an International Film Festival showcasing independent films that promote environmental awareness. The festival's origins are rooted in Santa Barbara, CA and have been an important part of the Earth Day celebration since 2008.

The 6th annual Green Shorts Film Festival will be held in Santa Barbara, CA at the historic Arlington Theater. The event will take place on April 24th 2014 in conjunction with Earth Day.

What We Need & What You Get

The Green Shorts Film Festival is a Film Positive production. Film Positive is an organization that brings awareness to environmental and social issues though the medium of film. One hundred percent of the money raised will go toward festival cost and filmmaker prizes and comes entirely from sponsors and donors. We have some awesome perks including; event tickets, VIP seating, tickets to the after party and reusable goodie bags filled with all kinds of cool environmentally friendly items.

The Impact

The idea for Earth Day came from founder Gaylord Nelson, a U.S. Senator from Wisconsin, after witnessing the ravages of the 1969 massive oil spill in Santa Barbara, California. Inspired by the student anti-war movement, he realized that if he could infuse that energy with an emerging public consciousness about air and water pollution, it would force environmental protection onto the national political agenda. Senator Nelson announced the idea for a “national teach-in on the environment” to the media; persuaded Pete McCloskey, a conservation-minded Republican Congressman, to serve as his co-chair; and recruited Denis Hayes as national coordinator. Hayes built a staff of 85 to promote events across the land. As a result, on the 22nd of April, 20 million Americans took to the streets, parks, and auditoriums to demonstrate for a healthy, sustainable environment in massive coast-to-coast rallies. Thousands of colleges and universities organized protests against the deterioration of the environment. Groups that had been fighting against oil spills, polluting factories and power plants, raw sewage, toxic dumps, pesticides, freeways, the loss of wilderness, and the extinction of wildlife suddenly realized they shared common values. http://www.earthday.org

In 2008, Traffic Solutions and Community Environmental Council (CEC) created this film festival so that people passionate about the environment and filmmaking could make and showcase films that offer creative solutions to current problems. This year Film Positive & Film Skillet joined Traffic Solutions and CEC to help take the Green Shorts Film Festival to the next level. Environmental issues and climate change are global threats and must be addressed on multiple fronts.

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you may not be able to contribute that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Help us spread the word by posting our campaign on your social media pages. Invite friends to help us share about the Green Shorts Film Festival by liking our Facebook, following our Twitter and reading our blogs.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to help spread the word! You can make a difference!

story:
The Video above call to action was recycled from v3.0; nevertheless, the goals, programs, and need remain the same.

Please use the Share This Campaign Tools link via e-mail, Like via FB or Google+, or Tweet directly above to spread the word and expand to your network.

COMMUNITY | SUSTAINABILITY | ENVIRONMENT |  ARTS . . .

Through application of these core concepts I will continue to build upon a pilot project launched in 2011 by planning and leading a hands-on long-term community development effort to alleviate poverty, food insecurity and environmental degradation in the rural areas of Takeo Province, Cambodia.  We aim bolster the viability of a rural population disenfranchised by rapid shifts towards modernization.

This fourth campaign (version 3.1) will allow me to go back to Cambodia to serve the Wat Opot Children's Community (WOCC), the people in the rural villages surrounding WOCC, focus on building farmer training centers in adjacent villages, and - this time around - conduct eco-projects as part of a rural village music festival put on by WOCC . This will be conducted within a 3 week timeframe starting early to the end of December 2014.  Previous fundraising campaigns (version 1.0, version 2.0, and version 3.0) results and progress may be viewed via my blog at http://briancambodiasustainability.tumblr.com/. 

I will continue to conduct two specific, on-going, long-term programs and launch one new program:

  1. Sustainable Agriculture and Food Security Training and Education benefiting ~30 adult village leaders and educators living with HIV/AIDS and in poverty
  2. Eco-Projects presented at the WOCC Music Festival on 12/22/2014 engaging the now captivated community by highlighting cultural resource mapping projects and composting demonstrations
  3. Dance (Hip-Hop, Break-dancing, Jazz, Contemporary, etc.) Competition benefiting children and teens (K-12) of WOCC and the surrounding villages living with HIV/AIDS and in poverty

The three programs were developed after a needs assessment and follow-up performed in 2011 -2012 (v1.0),  2013 (v2.0), and early 2014 (v3.0) bolstering this region by:

  • Providing training for the rural communities to adopt small-scale subsistence sustainable agricultural techniques and knowledge sharing forum to share best practices; hence, alleviating food insecurity and achieving food sovereignty free from external conventional agriculture forces (i.e. multi-national corporate chemical and/or GMO seed companies)
  • Engaging the youth of the rural communities through the arts (dance) and crafts (fun environmental related acitivities), which not only makes them stewards of their communities in the near term, but, also, provides leadership, planning and organizational skills supplementing their primary and secondary education, all of which is necessary for their success in the medium and long-term

In other words, together we can and are "CHANGING THE COURSE"

FUNDING AND TRANSPARENCY

FOR AS LITTLE AS $10 YOU COULD FUND:

  • 1 Adult Cambodian Community Leader impacted by HIV/AIDS and malnutrition to attend a Sustainable Agriculture and Food Security Training
  • 7 Cambodian Children/Teens to learn about life-long Sustainability and  Environment principles to conserve their resources as well as provide necessary Leadership Skills
  • 60 Children/Teens impacted by HIV/AIDS and Poverty to value community as well as learn about life long group dynamics and leadership skills, all of which builds confidence through the art of dance and healthy competition

There are THREE fundraising benchmarks to achieve:

  1. Raise $1,300 to run all three programs, provide my room and board, food, and the transportation costs to conduct farmer outreach work
  2. Anything raised above benchmark #1 up to about $3,500 via online and offline (events in San Francisco) would go to my travel to and from Cambodia as well as other costs to conduct my work for WOCC and the surrounding villages
  3. To-date I have raised $1,400 and need to raise $2,100 more


By donating you will be updated and will remain informed about the spending of the funds, which may slightly change pending on the need when I am on the ground . . . in-country.

*100% of donations will go towards bolstering the community; myself nor anyone else stand to make NO income or receive administrative fees (in-fact I'll take a salary hit, but, no worries I do this for the love of this community).

WHAT YOU GET FOR YOUR DONATION

Should you choose to receive a gift for your donation, I will personally shop for gifts as described in the perks section at the local markets in Phnom Penh.  Perks will be mailed or personally given to you once I return from Cambodia.  You may also opt not to collect a gift.  If you didn't collect from the last campaign, you may still contact me to collect, the perks are still sitting in a box under my bed! :).

*4 Percent of the donations will be collected by Indiegogo for running this service and platform.

OTHER INFORMATION

For more information on key partners click the following links:

  • Brian Reyes (me) - Planner, Organizer, Overseer of the entire project whom fundraises, plans and executes all programs for WOCC and the surrounding community
  • Wat Opot Children's Community (WOCC) - provides access to existing target beneficiaries and the central location of trainings, conferences, dancing competions, and/or meetings
  • Centre d'Etude et de Développement Agricole Cambodgien (CEDAC) - provides Cambodian Sustainable Agriculture training and resources, which is consistent with the values of this project
  • Global Service Corps - U.S. based non-profit responsible for initiating the pilot project and contributing resources

For more information about the Sustainable Agriculture techniques used:

  • Typical Biointensive Agriculture concepts via John Jeavons' GROWBIOINTENSIVE movement or Wikipedia

  • Techniques & Concepts used during v1.0, v2.0, and v3.0 via my blog at http://briancambodiasustainability.tumblr.com/


Remember to please spread the word by using the "Share This Campaign Tools" link below the initial photo/video above to spread the word.  Also, post and re-post this campaign on Twitter, Facebook, You Tube, LinkedIn, blogs, etc.  It would be much appreciated if you could ask your friends and family to help donate by directly contacting them.  If anyone has any questions, comments or just want to chat feel free to call me anytime at 415-730-8153 or email me at brian5368@gmail.com
story_txt:
The Video above call to action was recycled from v3.0; nevertheless, the goals, programs, and need remain the same.Please use the Share This Campaign Tools link via e-mail, Like via FB or Google+, or Tweet directly above to spread the word and expand to your network.
COMMUNITY | SUSTAINABILITY | ENVIRONMENT |  ARTS . . .Through application of these core concepts I will continue to build upon a pilot project launched in 2011 by planning and leading a hands-on long-term community development effort to alleviate poverty, food insecurity and environmental degradation in the rural areas of Takeo Province, Cambodia.  We aim bolster the viability of a rural population disenfranchised by rapid shifts towards modernization.This fourth campaign (version 3.1) will allow me to go back to Cambodia to serve the Wat Opot Children's Community (WOCC), the people in the rural villages surrounding WOCC, focus on building farmer training centers in adjacent villages, and - this time around - conduct eco-projects as part of a rural village music festival put on by WOCC . This will be conducted within a 3 week timeframe starting early to the end of December 2014.  Previous fundraising campaigns (version 1.0, version 2.0, and version 3.0) results and progress may be viewed via my blog at http://briancambodiasustainability.tumblr.com/. I will continue to conduct two specific, on-going, long-term programs and launch one new program:
Sustainable Agriculture and Food Security Training and Education benefiting ~30 adult village leaders and educators living with HIV/AIDS and in poverty
Eco-Projects presented at the WOCC Music Festival on 12/22/2014 engaging the now captivated community by highlighting cultural resource mapping projects and composting demonstrations
Dance (Hip-Hop, Break-dancing, Jazz, Contemporary, etc.) Competition benefiting children and teens (K-12) of WOCC and the surrounding villages living with HIV/AIDS and in poverty

The three programs were developed after a needs assessment and follow-up performed in 2011 -2012 (v1.0),  2013 (v2.0), and early 2014 (v3.0) bolstering this region by:Providing training for the rural communities to adopt small-scale subsistence sustainable agricultural techniques and knowledge sharing forum to share best practices; hence, alleviating food insecurity and achieving food sovereignty free from external conventional agriculture forces (i.e. multi-national corporate chemical and/or GMO seed companies)Engaging the youth of the rural communities through the arts (dance) and crafts (fun environmental related acitivities), which not only makes them stewards of their communities in the near term, but, also, provides leadership, planning and organizational skills supplementing their primary and secondary education, all of which is necessary for their success in the medium and long-termIn other words, together we can and are "CHANGING THE COURSE"FUNDING AND TRANSPARENCYFOR AS LITTLE AS $10 YOU COULD FUND:
1 Adult Cambodian Community Leader impacted by HIV/AIDS and malnutrition to attend a Sustainable Agriculture and Food Security Training
7 Cambodian Children/Teens to learn about life-long Sustainability and  Environment principles to conserve their resources as well as provide necessary Leadership Skills
60 Children/Teens impacted by HIV/AIDS and Poverty to value community as well as learn about life long group dynamics and leadership skills, all of which builds confidence through the art of dance and healthy competition

Raise $1,300 to run all three programs, provide my room and board, food, and the transportation costs to conduct farmer outreach work
Anything raised above benchmark #1 up to about $3,500 via online and offline (events in San Francisco) would go to my travel to and from Cambodia as well as other costs to conduct my work for WOCC and the surrounding villages

Wat Opot Children's Community (WOCC) - provides access to existing target beneficiaries and the central location of trainings, conferences, dancing competions, and/or meetings

Centre d'Etude et de Développement Agricole Cambodgien (CEDAC) - provides Cambodian Sustainable Agriculture training and resources, which is consistent with the values of this project

Global Service Corps - U.S. based non-profit responsible for initiating the pilot project and contributing resources

story:
Who We Are

Students for Sustainability was formed at Port Townsend High School in 2012 after studying climate change in our 10th grade science class.  We are a student-run organization! After spending the past two years working on lowering the carbon footprint at our school, we have realized we need to do more if we are going to have a sustainable and livable future.

Our mission now is to take action to mitigate climate change not only at our school and in our community, but at a national level.

Our story is already gaining local acclaim, and has been covered by the Port Townsend Leader and the Peninsula Daily News

We have been meeting with state and national legislators in our area, and now we are taking our message across the nation.

Why Urgent Action on Climate Change is So Important

The facts are sobering:

- the 10 hottest recorded years in history have been within the past 16

- we have reached a level of 400 parts per million of CO2 in our atmosphere, a level which has not been seen in 800,000 years. We know that more CO2 means a warmer planet and a warmer planet means an increase in severe weather

- 2013 set a new global record for billion-dollar weather disasters with 41 disasters like Hurricane Sandy, which caused $68,000,000,000 in damage

As the generation that will inherit this crisis, we can’t wait any longer for politicians to argue the facts.  As President Obama said in his State of the Union Address this year, “the debate is settled. Climate change is a fact.” We need solutions NOW!

Therefore, as passionate and dedicated citizens of planet Earth, we will travel by public transportation from our small town in western Washington to the ‘other’ Washington to bring our message of hope and plea for action to our leaders.

We Will Create a Wave of Student Voices Across Our Nation!

To provide a voice for our fellow concerned students, we will be contacting schools along the train route from Seattle to D.C. (55 stops through 12 states!) and picking up petitions from students as we go (see Updates to download) or sign our national online petition.  Around the clock, we will meet energized young adults across America and bring their concerns with us as we generate a wave of hope for our leaders to do the right thing - for us and for generations to come!

We Need Help to Fund Our Travel Costs - we leave on March 27th!

To keep a low carbon footprint, public transportation will be taken all the way there and back, including 7 days on the train round-trip!  We are staying at the youth hostel to support more 'green', sustainable and affordable accommodations.

For each student (there are 15 students on this life-changing journey!)

$ 1,500 = total cost of trip including travel, lodging, and meals

 $ 503 = one coach train ticket; round trip; 7 days on the train!

 $ 172 = lodging/breakfast at the hostel for 4 days

 $ 43 = lodging/breakfast at the hostel for 1 day

 $ 25 = one dinner on the train

Your financial support is critical, but we also need your moral and social support. Please share this with your friends and spread the word. The more people that support us, the closer we get to our goal. If you want to stay informed about what we’re doing, you can like our page on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, or follow our blog.

We are trying our best to make a difference.

Accomplishments:

• we are a student run organization which has taken innovative steps to reduce the carbon footprint at our school by:

 - restructuring and restarting the 'broken' recycling program

 - conducting an energy and waste audit to reduce the amount of garbage at the school

 - creating a business plan to show the cafeteria that they can

   save about $10,000 per year if they switch to reusable dishes and trays instead of disposable ones

 - switching to paperless bulletins, homework and assignments saving 30-100 reams of paper each year

 - recruited another 25 students making us the largest club on campus!

Awards:

1) The Students for Sustainability have just received a prestigious honor for our groundbreaking work in our community.  The Environmental Protection Agency has awarded certificates of recognition to each of us for our work on sustainability issues, both at our high school and in the work we are doing with the Northwest Watershed Institute and the Jefferson Land Trust.  

The citation reads:

The United States Environmental Protection Agency, through the President's Environmental Youth Awards Program, congratulates the students involved in the 'Students for Sustainability' project.

The United States Environmental Protection Agency is pleased to present this Presidential recognition to the Students for Sustainability and those who supported and assisted in the project.  You have all made an important contribution to the environmental resources of Washington.

Congratulations to you all.

Each certificate is signed by President Obama and carries the presidential seal along with a student's name.

This certification allows us to compete with students from Washington, Alaska, Idaho and Oregon, for the award winner to represent the EPA's Region 10.  If we win this award, we will move on to a national competition.


2) The president of Students for Sustainability, Ewan Shortess, was selected as a 2013 K-12 Student Environmental Leader at the annual E3 Washington Green Apple Awards on June 27, 2013.  He was recognized for his leadership as president of the Students For Sustainability at the high school, as well as his role as a member of the city and county Climate Action Committee.

What you will receive

We need over $25,000 for our dedicated group to travel the 3,000 miles to D.C. and stay at the hostel.  We will be deeply appreciative of any support you can provide. It all adds up!!

All contributions are tax deductible donations to Port Townsend School District #50.  If you would like a letter for tax purposes, please send a request to the Student for Sustainability at sfspths@gmail.com.

Please note - Donors who donate anonymously will by default not have their name listed on our website. If you are an anonymous donor, but would like your name listed on our website, please e-mail sfspths@gmail.com.

To show our appreciation, we are offering these perks:

Limited time perks - Ending February 7  - 10 available

$1,000 - your name on a new recycling bin including photo of your bin with Students for Sustainability members

$10 – Supporter

You get a personalized hand-written thank you note and your name listed on the donors section of our blog.

$25 – Enthusiast

You get a photo of our group meeting with an influential leader in Washington, D.C., a personalized hand-written thank you note, and your name listed on the donors section of our blog.

$50 – Cheerleader for the Planet

A tree planted in your name in critical salmon habitat, preserved by a conservation easement for perpetuity and a photo included with all the perks from the Enthusiast level. This tree will sequester 2 tons of carbon during its lifetime, the equivalent of a cross-country plane trip.

$100 – Stop Talking, Start Planting

Three trees planted in your name in critical salmon habitat, preserved by a conservation easement for perpetuity and a photo included with all the perks from the Enthusiast level. These trees will sequester 6 tons of carbon during their combined lifetimes, the equivalent of traveling 15,000 miles by car.

$500 – Game Changer – 30 available

We will include a video shout-out to you in our video blog from the train station closest to your home. If you meet us at the station, you'll be in the video! You also receive all the perks from the Stop Talking, Start Planting level.

$1,000 – Tipping Point Level – 20 available

You get a 30 minute video conference via Skype or Google Hangouts with the members of Students for Sustainability, as well as all the perks from the Game Changer level.

$2,000 – Planet-Saver Level – 10 available

You get a full hour long video conference via Skype or Google Hangouts with the members of Students for Sustainability, as well as all the perks from the Game Changer level.

story:
The Opportunity Has Arrived!

Years ago we conjured a pipe-dream to start a residential corps program that would not only improve natural spaces, community health, and sustainability in the region, but would also give young adults the opportunity to gain meaningful life and career skills while giving back to their communities. It would be a way to do great things, while empowering the leaders of tomorrow.

At the time this seemed impossible. The goal was too lofty, we were too young, the economy was too poor, the world was too callous, and a thousand other excuses which cause so many good ideas to fall by the wayside.

But our youthful optimism was too strong; the idea would not go away. That voice of intuition told us to take a chance and try something great, no matter the obstacles.

Now, whether by dumb luck or the power of tenacity and good intentions we were given opportunity after opportunity until the incredible happened...

The papers have been signed, making the Smoky Mountain Corps an official program of the Conservation Legacy. After decades of dreaming, years of planning, and months of preparation the Smoky Mountain Corps is now a reality. Help us bring the very first residential corps program to the southeast United States!

It has been a joyous scramble here to get everything started and the progress is astounding. Every day we are forging partnerships, completing projects, and working in the surrounding community to get the program off the ground. Every day that goes by it becomes more evident that the program is going to be a success and that the time for making the world a better place one project at a time is now!


OUR VISION

The Smoky Mountain Corps will be a residential youth development program located adjacent to Great Smoky Mountains National Park in eastern Tennessee. Starting in summer 2015, corps members between ages 18-25 will work together to complete conservation and sustainability projects in both urban and natural spaces.

  • Members are offered a variety of technical and leadership trainings during an extensive initial training period, and intermittently throughout the six month season
  • During the duration of the work season, crews of 6-8 members rotate between a wide array of project “hitches” which seek to improve environmental, economic, and social sustainability throughout the region.
  •  Potential projects include: trail construction and maintenance, bridge and structure construction, habitat improvement, invasive management, surveying/GIS, water quality improvement, historical restoration, solar installation, weatherization, community gardens and food education, farmer training, and environmental education
  • In addition, the residential site will function as a venue for projects and education for the corps and surrounding community by featuring an education center, model organic farm, sustainable energy systems, and other initiatives
  • Unless working remotely during project hitches, members will live on-site in a communal facility and participate in communal activities.  A goal of the program is to provide members with an opportunity to foster an ethic of personal responsibility and cooperation by developing an inclusive residential community.
  • Members receive a bi-weekly living stipend, as well as room and board. In addition, they will receive an AmeriCorps education award upon successful completion of the program.

What We Have, What WE Need & What You Get

We have: a beautiful 35 acre property with 15 acres of fields, 20 acres of forests, and a large furnished crew house 

We need: 

  • Farm equipment and supplies
  • Tools (chainsaws, hand tools, rigging equipment, power tools, generator)
  • Camping Gear (Tents, stoves, water filters, etc.) for a 20 member crew
  • Crew vans 
  • Office supplies 
  • Building Materials 

You get:

  • $10 donation: thank you shout out on our facebook page, a virtual hug, and updates on our progress!
  • $25 donation: Personal thank you message and updates on our progress! 
  • $50 donation: Personal thank you message, and we will make you an engraved wooden pendent!
  • $100 donation: A snazzy Smoky Mountain Corps T-shirt, a personal thank you, and a shout out on our FB page!
  • $500 donation: A jar of homemade blackberry jam fresh from our farm and a SMC T-shirt!
  • $1000 donation: SMOKIES VACATION!!! We invite you and your family to tour and stay at the beautiful SMC property at the foot of the Great Smoky Mountain National Park for a long weekend (visit our facebook page for pictures)! You will also receive a SMC T-Shirt and a huge thank you!!!
  • $5000 donation: ALL PREVIOUS GIFTS! And we will dedicate a building project on site in your name.  You will also receive an ENORMOUS thank you!!!

*Your donation is tax deductible*

The Impact

Tennessee and North Carolina alone have over five million acres of public land with only a few small emerging programs operating in the region. 

  • SMC members will help improve the natural environment in the region, which provides communities more opportunities to experience the outdoors and engage in physical activity. 
  • In addition, the program will work to host volunteer events and educational programs to engage local communities in conservation and to provide technical and leadership training to residents.

Eastern TN and the surrounding region lack access to affordable, healthy food: Blount County (where SMC is based) and Knox County (within 1 hour) are both considered food desert areas by the USDA, based on household income and distance to grocery stores.

  • SMC will assist the region in establishing food independence through education, garden installation, and support for local farmers markets

Partially due to high energy usage (average consumption for TN households is among the nations highest), the region is heavily impacted by air pollution (Knoxville is ranked 34th in air pollution rates among US cities)

  • SMC seeks to address poverty and environment health in this region through education and assistance in improving sustainable energy systems for residents

Other Ways You Can Help

  • We will also except donations of building materials, tools, farm equipment, camping gear, and office supplies.  Please let us know if you have any of these things to offer!
  • Please take a minute to spread the word! Share and email this page to your friends!
  • LIKE and SHARE our facebook page!
  •  Check out our blog for updates!

THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR YOUR SUPPORT! WE COULDN'T DO IT WITHOUT YOU!

We have: a beautiful
35 acre property with 15 acres of fields, 20 acres of forests, and a large
furnished crew house 
We need: 

Farm equipment and supplies
Tools (chainsaws, hand tools, rigging equipment, power tools, generator)
Camping Gear (Tents, stoves, water filters, etc.) for a
     20 member crew
Crew vans 
Office supplies 
Building Materials 
You get:


$10 donation: thank
     you shout out on our facebook page, a virtual hug, and updates on our
     progress!

$25 donation: Personal
     thank you message and updates on our progress! 

$50 donation: Personal
     thank you message, and we will make you an engraved wooden pendent!

$100 donation: A snazzy
     Smoky Mountain Corps T-shirt, a personal thank you, and a shout out on our
     FB page!
 

$500 donation: A jar of homemade blackberry jam
     fresh from our farm and a SMC T-shirt!
 

$1000 donation: SMOKIES
     VACATION!!! We invite you and your family to tour and stay at the
     beautiful SMC property at the foot of the Great Smoky Mountain National
     Park for a long weekend (visit our facebook page for pictures)! You will
     also receive a SMC T-Shirt and a huge thank you!!!

$5000 donation: ALL
     PREVIOUS GIFTS! And we will dedicate a building project on site in your
     name.  You will also receive an ENORMOUS thank you!!!
*Your donation is tax deductible*The Impact
Tennessee
and North Carolina alone have over five million acres of public land with only
a few small emerging programs operating in the region.  
SMC
members will help improve the natural environment in the region, which provides
communities more opportunities to experience the outdoors and engage in
physical activity. In
addition, the program will work to host volunteer events and educational
programs to engage local communities in conservation and to provide technical
and leadership training to residents.
Eastern TN and the surrounding region lack access to affordable,
healthy food: Blount County (where SMC is based) and Knox County (within 1
hour) are both considered food desert areas by the USDA, based on household income
and distance to grocery stores.
SMC
will assist the region in establishing food independence through education,
garden installation, and support for local farmers markets

Partially
due to high energy usage (average consumption for TN households is among the
nations highest), the region is heavily impacted by air pollution (Knoxville is
ranked 34th in air pollution rates among US cities)

SMC
seeks to address poverty and environment health in this region through
education and assistance in improving sustainable energy systems for residents

Other Ways You Can Help

We will also except donations of building materials,
     tools, farm equipment, camping gear, and office supplies.  Please let us know if you have any of
     these things to offer!
Please take a minute to spread the word! Share and
     email this page to your friends!
LIKE and SHARE our facebook page!
 Check out our
     blog for updates!
THANK
YOU SO MUCH FOR YOUR SUPPORT! WE COULDN'T DO IT WITHOUT YOU!

story:
Support Alverno College Students as they Study Cities on the Baltic Sea

Beginning May 22nd students from Alverno College will be traveling to the Baltic Sea to study coastal cities. Students have been studying Milwaukee as a coastal city in the spring of 2014 and will compare Milwaukee with Gdansk, Poland, Kalmar and Malmö, Sweden, and Copenhagen, Denmark. 

Students have volunteered to climb the tower at the Church of Our Saviour in Copenhagen, Denmark if we are able to raise $1000.00 for our trip. If we are able to get a few $50.00 and $100.00 donations, we guarantee some of our students will make the trek to the top.

Please see the video below for a sense of the harrowing trip students will make!



What we need!

$1000.00 for students to participate in environmental and urban adventures about Coastal Cities.

What you will receive!

If we meet our $1000.00 goal, you'll see a friend or loved one conquer their fear of heights by climbing the Church of Our Saviour in Copenhagen!

At the $25.00 level, you'll receive a postcard from the Baltic Sea

At the $50.00 level, you'll receive a digital photograph of student climbers from the top of the steeple at the Church of Our Saviour.

At the $100.00 level, you'll receive a personalized video greeting from a climber of your choice from the top of the steeple.

* Address and email address required for those who would like one of our perks.

* If there is severe weather, the steeple will be closed to tourists. In the event we are not permitted to climb, we will find an alternative challenge for participants.

Follow our adventure via our class blog at 

http://ccbalticsea.wordpress.com/

story:
No Big Dig

Hahamongna is a precious environmental treasure in the Arroyo Seco, a branch of the Los Angeles River and a rare alluvial canyon that links the San Gabriel Mountains to downtown Los Angeles. 


Image courtesy of Dorothy Wong

Pasadena Audubon Society and the Arroyo Seco Foundation are working together to protect and restore the stream habitat and wildlife along the Arroyo Seco River. We filed a lawsuit to stop the LA County Flood Control District's $100 million Big Dig program to truck sediment from Hahamongna Watershed Park in Pasadena to landfills 25 miles away.

The Big Dig program will have horrendous impacts on habitat and wildlife in Hahamongna and on the neighboring communities. The District is pushing ahead with it's program, claiming that their Big Dig is the only way to protect downstream communities from flood threats. In their push, they have ignored clear alternate proposals from our organizations, community members, and the City of Pasadena. The alternate proposals lay out methods to achieve needed flood protection without such significant impacts. The Flood Control District claims these alternatives would not provide protection but have given no indication of how much more protection their destructive project will provide. They are simultaneously moving forward with similar programs at other large dams in LA County – which will add up to an enormous amount of money, air pollution, and waste.

Image courtesy of Dorothy Wong
We filed this lawsuit to force the agency to manage the Devil's Gate Dam reservoir in a way that not only preserves flood protections provided by the dam and its reservoir, but also considers traffic, air quality, natural communities, and water resources to create an integrated and sustainable approach that will benefit all residents of Los Angeles County. Now we need funds to successfully press this lawsuit, to prove that the agency cannot simply proceed while ignoring the needs of the community.

Their Big Dig:

  • $100 million for a quick fix, temporary solution
  • 425 trucks a day adding to traffic, noise, and air pollution
  • 150,000 trucks for this reservoir alone – an unknown number for all their reservoirs
  • No clear goal for reservoir capacity – but a minimum of 2.4 million cubic yards of soil and vegetation removed from Hahamongna in under 5 years
  • Destroy 71 acres of established stream side habitat, a state wide resource, and riversidean alluvial fan sage scrub – a rare habitat nearly extirpated in Los Angeles County

The Pasadena Alternative:

  • 120 trucks a day, maximum
  • Require trucks to meet at least 2010 EPA emissions standards, reducing NOx emissions
  • Set a clear goal of reservoir capacity, work slowly to get there over 10 years
  • MAINTAIN that level of capacity every year to avoid a future 'crisis'
  • Limit the project to a 40 acre footprint
  • Preserve key areas, including stream-side habitat and riversidean alluvial fan sage scrub
  • Maintain a pool of water near the dam to increase water conservation and provide habitat for birds, fish, frogs and more

Image Courtesy of M. Fellows/NASA

What We Need & What You Get 

  • Perks are all about helping you show your support for this effort! Wear your shirts and buttons with pride, use them to open conversations with people in your communities about this devastating project - and let them know how they can help!
  • Pasadena and the community have worked to make Hahamongna Watershed Park a model of environmental sustainability for over 30 years to preserve this rare, unique spot. We cannot allow it to simply be destroyed by the County's bulldozers and trucks.
  • You can change how LA County treats its streams and rivers. We can't let them be wasted resources anymore, we need to value them for their water and the recreational opportunities that they offer. 
  • This fundraiser will give us the tools to get started.
  • The Arroyo Seco Foundation, Pasadena Audubon members, volunteers, and the hundreds of people who took time to read through and submit comments on the Draft and Final Environmental Impact Reports have put in hundreds of hours on this campaign. Those hours laid the foundation for a solid case against the County, and now we need to back up all that effort with a serious legal effort.
  • The LA River Restoration program requires sediment for success this is an opportunity to change the way we can't just dam up streams and rivers and put them in sterile concrete channels we need living rivers

The Impact

If we win this fight, it will mean an improved project at Devil's Gate Dam:

  • Diesel trucks that meet current EPA standards and lower NOx emissions.
  • Fewer trucks on neighborhood roads, passing by schools, each day of the project.
  • Preservation and replanting of more forest and wetland within the park.
  • A clear plan to use the dam for water conservation and infiltration of water into the Raymond Basin aquifer underground. 
  • A model for dam and reservoir maintenance for all other projects the LA County Flood Control District operates - over 80 other facilities. 
  • A sustainable management plan for the reservoir that ensures the safety of the dam and downstream residents while incorporating concerns about traffic, air quality, nature and water.

Image courtesy of Dorothy Wong

Risks & Challenges

We tried to work with the Flood Control District, but they didn't consider proposed alternatives. The CIty of Pasadena proposed a plan that would have 1/4 of the impacts of the District's project, but they did not listen. 

  • Our legal team is experienced in CEQA suits and understands the challenges as well as the necessary steps to succeed.
  • Pasadena Audubon and Arroyo Seco Foundation are prepared to continue with the lawsuit to reach a positive outcome, and are developing other funding sources in addition to this campaign. 



Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, you can still help:

  • Lead a coffee session to inform people about the proposed project
  • Become a neighborhood chief and help your neighbors understand what's at stake
  • Host an event at your home to help raise funds
  • And don't forget to share this campaign to your networks!


The Perks

No Big Dig Supporter - $10 

Supporters choosing this perk will receive a No Big Dig button to show everyone their support for the fight, and still get a great big virtual high five! Your name will be added to our list of supporters and you will begin receiving our newsletter with updates on the fight.

The Beauty of Hahamongna - $25 and above

Supporters choosing this perk will receive a No Big Dig button to show everyone your support for the fight and a 4" x 6" print of the beautiful Hahamongna Watershed Park you are helping to preserve. Your name will be added to our list of supporters and you will begin receiving our newsletter with updates on the fight.



No Big Dig Team - $50 and above

Supporters choosing this perk will receive The Save Hahamongna shirt, a local icon. Wear it proudly and be amazed how many conversations it will start. The graphic was created by a local artist and features local wildlife and native plants, graphically represented in a shape of a stop sign.


Hahamongna Highlights - $100 and above

Supporters choosing this perk will receive the Hahamongna Highlights DVD. The DVD features the films below and more. exploring the beauty of this location while reviewing several of the issues that have threatened this natural gem over the past decade. Supporters also receive a Tshirt, button, and print.

Hahamongna Coyote - $125 - 25 available

Coyotes thrive in Hahamongna and inspire artist and wildlife lover alike. With this donation, you’ll receive 3 note cards featuring interpretations of “Hahamongna Coyote,” created by Pasadena artist, activist and fierce defender of Hahamongna, Dianne Patrizzi.


Birds of Hahamongna - $250 - 25 available

Six note cards, each printed with a different Bird Of Hahamongna as photographed by Pasadena Audubon Society member Darren Dowell.


Visions of Hahamongna - $500

Supporters choosing this perk will receive one of a limited run of a framed print of this scene in Hahamongna as captured by writer, actor and photographer Petrea Burchard. You will also receive the No Big Dig button, Save Hahamongna Tshirt, and 4x6 print.

Image courtesy of Petrea Burchard

Hahamongna Interpreted - $1,000

Supporters at this level will receive a canvas print of local artist Karen Winters' 'Reflections of Springtime'. Karen Winters is a native Californian, for whom art and the love of nature have been lifelong passions. Through group and solo shows, her work has been exhibited at the Autry National Center, the Bowers Museum of Cultural Art, the Riverside Museum of Art, the San Luis Obispo Art Museum, the Santa Paula Art Museum, the Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels in LA, and is in the collection of the Huntington Library. She is a member of Oil Painters of America and the American Impressionist Society, a juried member of Watercolor West and an Artist member of the California Art Club.


Arroyo Tour - $2,500

Supporters at this level have the opportunity to have lunch with us in the Arroyo, and then let us take you on a tour of Hahamongna and the Arroyo Seco. This will be a lovely afternoon with local history, flora and fauna explained by experts from both Pasadena Audubon and Arroyo Seco Foundation. You will also receive a Tshirt, button, and 4" x 6" print.

Hahamongna Coyote oil painting - $3,000

Supporter at this level will receive an oil painting on canvas of interpretive version of Hahamongna Coyote by Pasadena artist Dianne Patrizzi. Pigments used in oil paintings are made from the sands and minerals found in Hahamongna and collected especially by a gentle hand. 

Engelmann Oak planting - $5,000

In honor of your commitment to the preservation of our community, we will plant a native Engelmann oak in the Arroyo Seco and dedicate it with a plaque bearing your name for supporters choosing this perk. You will also receive a Save Hahamongna Tshirt, No Big Dig button, and 4" x 6" print of Hahamongna. To ensure the health of the oak, we will plant the seedling next winter.

story:
Short Summary

City Park For Everyone Coalition is the alliance of New Orleanians working together to halt the development of the new golf course while preserving the park's continued open access of green spaces and the abundance of wildlife by providing sustainable, non privatized, alternative revenue methods and gaining greater transparency and accountability from City Park Leadership.

Our campaign is build to bring awareness to the destruction of the wild space that is currently happening, and to help fund the injunction we have filed to stop the work. City Park Board has not been transparent about this process, and have not taken public consideration of the use of land. 

It was a golf course, pre Katrina, but afterward it had been allowed to grow back into a natural state and be repopulated by many species of bids and plants.

With your contribution we will be able to pay our legal fees associated with the federal injunction we have filed.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $20000 for legal fees, and other costs that may come up for events that we have building awareness of the park, 

Our perks are all built around New Orleans culture, photos and postacrds, different items of art that are centric to the beauty of City Park. 

Even if we don't reach our entire goal, all the funds will be going to our legal team. Any extra funds that may come will go to a local charity.

The Impact

If we are successful the wild space in City Park will stay wild, which leaves a space for thousands of people to come and relieve stress of their daily lives. It gives room for people to exprience nature that they can't find within the city limits of New Orleans. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you want to get involved you can send us an email at cityparkforeveryonecoalition@gmail.com!

story:
Short Summary

We are a couple that wants to do something about the climate crisis. We believe that many small actions can achieve as much (or even more) than one big action. So, we want to start small by planting trees. Planting a tree has a lot of benefits for the ecosystem.

We talked to a reforestation company and they gave us about 60.000 trees to plant, and we found 3 places in Colombia to do it.

Now we need your help to plant them! We want to dedicate ourselves to being really good at this simple yet complex task.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to cover the expenses of the workers that will do the planting, create a good camping facility to them, with food and a place to rest.

Yes, we could do this with volunteers, but we think this is an opportunity to also create work for people in these rural areas. This way we make an even bigger impact.

If we don't make our goal, we will plant as many trees as we can with the collected money, but we want to keep doing this on the long term, so after the campaign is over we will open our web site for everyone who wants to keep donating. T-shirts, mugs or other collectibles are only available to contributors of this campaign.

The Impact

Planting trees has a huge impact in the environment. There are some studies than show that trees could make a difference if they're planted in the tropic (http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/science/nature/6184577.stm) and this is key for us, that's why we selected Colombia as our target.

Also keep in mind that:

  • Forest regulate the climate in a global scale
  • Forests can cool the planet by absorbing the greenhouse gas carbon dioxide during photosynthesis.
  • Trees can also have a warming effect because they are dark and absorb a lot of sunlight, holding heat near ground level

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Get out and make noise about our campaing! Share with your friends and family, help us make this a reallity.

story:
BUILDING A STRONGER TOMORROW

 

The Kupu Green Job Training Center Vision

Transform the concrete-n-beams “net shed” into a LEED-certified green jobs training center and garden that trains Pacific Rim youth for the future.

What it is

This will be a “piko” (center) for hundreds of Kupu youth volunteers to learn skills for Hawaii’s fast-growing green economy - such as farming, entrepreneurship, solar installation, ecology, and reforestation - and to support these activities with Kupu’s core values of Conservation, Cultivation, Cooperation, and Character.

What we have

An incredible site, right on the water in downtown Honolulu

With your help...

We are creating a gathering place for the community to come together and in this vision, we want to show the power of a community-based crowdfunding campaign to raise $10,000 to purchase a gigantic refrigerator as part of the larger Kupu Capital Campaign.  The Capital Campaign needs $2.75 Million to realize a vision of renovating the net shed and this crowdfunding effort will allow us to make a significant contribution towards this goal.

Imagine a Sustainable Concession Stand at the site of the Net Shed in Kewalo Basin, where youth can learn to prepare "farm to table" agriculture and aquaponics.  The commercial kitchen (with its huge refrigerator, thanks to this crowdfunding effort!) and concession stand would be both a micro-enterprise for Kupu youth and a way to help educate the public about local agriculture.  

No matter how big, or how small a donation, we need your commitment, your support, and your help to spread the word to create a brighter future.

 

  

What Kupu means...

John Leong
Executive Director
Kupu Hawaii

"Kupu is helping young adults to get their hands, heads, and hearts engaged in service so that they actively make the world a better place.  Hawaii's communities statewide are benefiting from Kupu with over 11,000 volunteers engaged and close to 250,000 service hours provided each year.  More than 250 youth of Hawaii participate in Kupu programs annually, gaining life skills, job training, education, and the opportunity to make a difference.    

This Kupu Green Job Training Center will amplify what Kupu is doing--please partner with us in making this center a reality!"   

 

Leland Akau
Kupu Hawaii Youth Conservation Corps (HYCC) Extended Internship Program Member

"This program is helping me learn things I've never learned before.  This program can teach people on keeping the environment clean, but not only that, it can help people by keeping them away from any kind of trouble and having them do something better with their lives.  When we come in we are broken, but the program slowly heals us to teach us humility and to serve our community."

 
 

Kanekoa Shultz
Executive Director
Kako'o 'Ōiwi

"Kupu’s program has continued to be a strong supporter and workforce for Kāko’o Ōiwi and our mission to provide a place where communities can thrive and produce for their families, preserve and practice the culture of our ancestors Hawaii, and sustain and restore our people and our resources."

 

Keli'i Kotubetey
Founder and Assistant Executive Director
Paepae o He'eia 

"Kupu's Hawaii Youth Conservation Corps (HYCC) has been coming to He'eia Fishpond, every summer for the past 11 years, and we look forward to many more years of working with the HYCC.  The HYCC participants help us out at the fishpond through various work projects including invasive algae removal, invasive mangrove removal, fishpond wall restoration and native fish cultivation."

 

Syd Kawahakui
Department of Land and Natural Resources
Current Program Site Manager & Former Participant

"Hawaii Youth Conservation Corps and Kupu is a good kahua (foundation) on which we can firmly stand upon to help malama and aloha aina (care for and love of the land), as well as perpetuate the ways of our kupuna (elders)."

 

More than just a coconut.

To honor the importance of your donation to Kupu’s crowdfunding efforts for a huge industrial refrigerator we have signified different levels of contributions by some of the different "canoe plants" brought along in the Polynesians' voyages to Hawaii.  Early Polynesian voyagers set sail in double hull canoes across the Pacific, traveling thousands of miles to inhabit islands across 16 million square miles of ocean from New Zealand in the West, Rapa Nui in the East and Hawaii in the North.           

A large reason for the success of the Polynesians' voyages was because they brought certain plants along for the voyage.  These "canoe plants", as they are called in Hawaii, had many different uses including food, tools, clothing, and fire to help them thrive.  In the same way, we hope the sustainable commercial kitchen will bring food and sustenance to our community. 

 

Please join us.  Mahalo.

  

Together we can create a green future.  One step at a time.  One dollar at a time.

Together we can add up to much more than a bunch of individuals; we can forge a new path to develop the next generation of leaders. This Kupu Green Job Training Center will provide opportunities for training, education, and mentoring for a more sustainable future.

Together we can leave the world a better place.

story:
2020 Plans

We're kicking off our annual fundraiser with this campaign. We still have our survey going in Cambodia's Virachey National Park, and we are seeking to start another in the region, the details of which we cannot make public at the moment (but which can be shared via email: greg.mccann1@gmail.com ). For those who haven't seen our work before, allow us to summarize what we do:

  • We work in currently neglected/underpriotized protected areas in Southeast Asia that the bigger conservation NGOs, for whatever reason, don't want to touch.
  • We conduct camera-trap surveys to uncover globally important wildlife populations and use that data to encourage larger NGOs and the government to invest in long-term conservation programs. We have already achieved success in this regard in our project in Sumatra's Hadabuan Hills, bringing in the esteemed PRCF, and also in Cambodia's Virachey NP, where negotiations are currently underway for NGOs to make an entry, and where our work resulted in the rediscovery of a breeding population of Asian elephants. 
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

For those who prefer to donate via PayPal, you can use this link. 

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • We are shooting for $6,000 to pay for camera traps, protective metal casings, lithium batteries, SD cards, food and provisions, and daily supply allowances for local staff on expeditions and camera checks. 
  • Everyone who donates will get exclusive digital copies of camera trap images, and those who donate $250 or more will recieve actual prints in the mail. 
  • If we don't reach our fundraising goal, the projects still go on, and whatever we bring in goes straight to the field.

The Impact

We work in places that other conservation NGOs largely consider to be too risky or too difficult. We see these factors as opportunities to explore. Here is what we bring to the table:

  • Indisputable photographic evidence that globally important species persist in currently neglected refugia and which need urgent conservation investment. Species we've found so far include: tigers, Malayan tapirs, Asian elephants, clouded leopards, dholes, pangolins, helmeted hornbills, and many others species. 
  • We're basically 2/2 with our projects so far, with the missions accomplished of bringing in larger, better-monied organizations who have the funding to carry out long-term management strategies.
  • We are not a cut-and-run team and we are commited to the locations and local people where we work for the long haul. This is evidenced by our multi-year engagements in Cambodia and Indonesia. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you prefer not to make a direct financial contribution but would like to help out in other ways, you can:

  • Mail us supplies in the United States (email for more info: greg.mccann1@gmail.com )
  • Share this Indiegogo link on your social media pages!

story:
HERE&NOW FUEL CELL FUNDRAISING CAMPAIGN

Help us build a new prototype model for safe, clean and sustainable energy generation at Nowhere festival + beyond, brought to you by the Here&Now Camp.

THE PLAN

We think it just makes sense to develop cleaner, more sustainable energy infrastructure at Nowhere (and indeed the world). This year for the inaugural Here&Now Camp at the Nowhere festival in Monegros, Spain, we want to build a sustainable fuel cell system that is SILENT, CHEAP TO RUN, CLEAN and most importantly - FREAKIN’ COOL.

We’ve already been allocated a 400€ Innovation Grant from the Nowhere Board, and the camp has been actively fundraising with events in Barcelona. But we’re going to need at least 1600€ more to build the fuel cell itself and get the other components we need to create a complete energy system. And if we meet this goal ahead of time, we have a stretch goal of 500€ more - to provide Nowhere with its very first Oxygen Bar!

Andrea will give a workshop on the project at this year’s Nowhere and will provide detailed open source schematics of the fuel cell system for anyone interested in building their own. It’s not just a better battery - it’s a positive step forward for the whole community. After Nowhere the plan is to use the fuel cell to help power ConnectHORT, a community garden project in Barcelona.

THE FUEL CELL

The main component of the system will by an HHO fuel cell, designed by Andrea Gini (a longtime Burner and ex-Navy engineer). Using solar panels to provide energy to the fuel cell, it will initiate an electrolysis reaction of the water inside, producing hydrogen and oxygen gases.

     


Using special laser-cut membranes, we will separate these gases and store the hydrogen in a tank during the day to provide fuel for a  fuel cell stack during the night, which will power the camp’s electricity needs.

This system could be developed further to provide an effective energy alternative for other barrios in future, and help us collectively transition to more sustainable energy generation at the festival.

THE OXYGEN BAR

If we can, we want to go further than just building the fuel cell. Because the electrolysis process produces oxygen as well as hydrogen, if we can raise enough for the extra pump and filters we would need to supply it, we’ll be able to make Nowhere’s very first Oxygen Bar! Oxygenating the human system can have a range of benefits, from increased energy levels to increased concentration. Help us reach our stretch goal of 2100€ so we can bring a healthy and fun pick-me-up to the dusty chaos of Nowhere!

BUDGET

To build the system we will need:
- Solar panels: 700€
- HHO Fuel cell (materials + fabrication): 400€
- Hydrogen tank: 100€
- Connectors (gas + electricity): 100€
- Fuel cell stack: 400€
- Campaign perks: 300€
TOTAL: 2000€
                  -400€ Nowhere Innovation Grant
GOAL:    1600€

Stretch goal:
- Oxygen Bar (materials + fabrication): 500€

HERE & NOW CAMP 2015

This will be the inaugural year for the Here & Now Camp at Nowhere. Inspired by our experiences with yoga, meditation, merrymaking, and other transformational practices, as well as camps such as Sacred Spaces at Burning Man and retreat centres around the world, we wanted to create a space that would facilitate these sorts of experiences for the inhabitants of Nowhere.

Through exploration of the body, emotions, mind, and spirit we will seek to inquire into the deeper questions of our existence, as living beings, as human beings, as a community and as part of the evolution of all the cosmos. Our focus will be on providing a forum for educational sessions by and for everyone. Leveraging the wealth of knowledge of the Nowhere community we will offer a wide range of effective personal practices known to facilitate transformation in every aspect of our lives.

Yoga will be expressed not only as a physical practice suitable for a bendy few, but an integrated discipline accessible to all in daily classes and workshops, supporting more vibrant health, greater physical capability, clarity of mind, and increased interpersonal awareness. Meditation will be practiced in many forms, personal and guided, still and dynamic, silent and sounded. Artistic expression in all its forms will be celebrated, and we will offer daily talks on health, lifestyle design, diet, philosophy, spiritual practice, and how we can clarify the concept of "sustainability" in many aspects of our life.

Through these many different aspects we want to ask the question of ourselves and the festival as a whole: how can we meet our own needs, and once we have, how can we really be of service to each other, and the world at large? We welcome transformative workshops, yoga, meditation, panel discussions, ceremonies, seminars, dance, live art creation, music and any other experiences that will inspire our Nowhere community. If you would like to collaborate with content, please sign up here: https://goo.gl/VxsXic

This clean energy project is another facet of the camp’s vision for creating a space that inspires and empowers us to evolve, both personally and collectively!

HOW YOU CAN HELP

We need the help of the Nowhere, and the wider Burn community, to make this happen and to do it right. We think this could be an important step forward to creating a more sustainable energy environment at Nowhere and help the Nowhere/Burn community as a whole develop better tools for generating and storing electricity for camps. We will be offering guided tours and workshops on the fuel cell technology for anyone interested!

Check out the perks in the right sidebar - we are offering detailed schematics and mentorship to build your own fuel cell, limited edition Here&Now schwag and private therapies with some of our members! But most of all, the satisfaction of knowing you are part of a team working to make our environment cleaner!

If you support the project, please let others who may be interested in it know about it too, and if you have any questions or feedback please don't hesitate to get in touch with us at hereandnowcamp(at)gmail.com or our Here&Now FB community page. And for those of you coming to this year's Nowhere... see you in the dust!

story:
Our Story

Did you know that the typical American family generates 4,320 pieces of trash annually during lunchtime? We are ECOlunchboxes, a small business specializing in waste-free lunchware. 

Our dream is to teach children about lunch waste in a fun way and empower them to green their lunchtime habits. How do we want to do this? By developing a smart phone game.

Imagine lunch trash flying in air. The object is to quickly swipe trash into one of 3 cans: recycling, compost & trash. If the trash goes into the correct bin, the bin lights up and blinks. If the trash misses the bin or goes into the wrong bin, it explodes and splats in a pile on the lunchroom floor. Each round has a timer and point threshold to beat. 

Correctly sorted trash wins! 


The Impact

Our landfills and oceans are filling up with trash. Lunchtime provides an opportunity for children to take change into their own hands and green their habits. A study completed by ECOlunchboxes has shown that the typical American family generates 4,320 pieces of trash just during lunchtime! (Study results here http://www.ecolunchboxes.com/learn_study.html)

By recycling and adopting sustainable habits at lunchtime, families can dramatically reduce their environmental footprint. 


What We Need & What You Get

We are raising funds to hire a developer to create this smart phone app teaching about lunch waste and recycling. 100% of the funds will go towards programming, creative and other project costs. 


Other Ways You Can Help

HERE’S HOW YOU CAN HELP SPREAD THE WORD:

 

1.    Tweet about it! We’re http://twitter.com/#!/ecolunchboxes. Here are some sample tweets that you can copy and paste (or change to make your own or whatever) to make it extra quick and easy for you:

 

@ecolunchboxes is making an #eco #app for #green kids! Help us obliterate waste & #recycle lunchtime on @indiegogo: http://tinyurl.com/3sczlx3

 

Fun flying #lunch trash! @ecolunchboxes needs help to make an #eco #app for #green #kids. Crowd funding at @indiegogo: http://tinyurl.com/3sczlx3

 

I’m helping @ecolunchboxes make an #eco #app about lunch waste #Green game teaches #recycling and #zerowaste @indiegogo http://tinyurl.com/3sczlx3

 

2.  Post on Facebook! We are http://www.facebook.com/ecolunchboxes Use messages we suggest here or make your own!


Join us in helping @ecolunchboxes make a lunch trash game for kids! This FREE smart phone app called Green Trash Ninja will be fun for kids and teach them about reducing lunchtime waste. DONATE to the cause and win PRIZES. http://www.indiegogo.com/Green-Trash-Ninja-Crowd-Fundraising-for-Eco-Game-App


Check out this crowd funding campaign by our friends at @ecolunchboxes! They want to make a smart phone game for kids to teach about reducing waste and lunchtime and recycling. They're offering PRIZES to donors who help them develop this project. http://www.indiegogo.com/Green-Trash-Ninja-Crowd-Fundraising-for-Eco-Game-App

 

3.    Post a badge on your blog or your website telling the world that you’re supporting our eco educational project! You can right click and save the badges below to use them. Link the badges back to this page at http://www.indiegogo.com/Green-Trash-Ninja-Crowd-Fundraising-for-Eco-Game-App so more people can learn all about it!  :-)


To download a badge, go to: http://www.ecolunchboxes.com/lunchgame/

          


***INTERNATIONAL BACKERS***

Please add a bit extra to your pledge to cover shipping costs! I appreciate it, and I would ship them for free if I could! :)

Here's the breakdown:

For pledges:

$1 - $24: Please add $2.00

$25 - $74: Please add $4.00

$75 - $149: Please add $14.00

$150 - $249: Please add $16.00

$250 - $499: Please add $28.00

$500 - $999: Please add $50.00

$1000 - $2499: Please add $100.00

$2500 - $4999: Please add $150.00

$5000 and above: Please add $200.00

object is to quickly swipe trash into one of 3 cans: recycling, compost &
trash. If the trash goes into the correct bin, the bin lights up and blinks. If
the trash misses the bin or goes into the wrong bin, it explodes and splats in
a pile on the lunchroom floor. Each round has a timer and point threshold to
beat. 
Correctly sorted trash wins! 



The Impact
Our landfills and oceans are filling up with trash. Lunchtime provides an opportunity for children to take change into their own hands and green their habits. A study completed by ECOlunchboxes has shown that the typical American family generates 4,320 pieces of trash just during lunchtime! (Study results here http://www.ecolunchboxes.com/learn_study.html)
By recycling and adopting sustainable habits at lunchtime, families can dramatically reduce their environmental footprint. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are raising funds to hire a developer to create this smart phone app teaching about lunch waste and recycling. 100% of the funds will go towards programming, creative and other project costs. 


Other Ways You Can Help

HERE’S HOW YOU CAN HELP SPREAD THE WORD:

 
1.    Tweet about it! We’re http://twitter.com/#!/ecolunchboxes. Here are some sample tweets that you can copy and
paste (or change to make your own or whatever) to make it extra quick and easy
for you:

 
@ecolunchboxes is making an #eco #app for #green kids! Help us obliterate waste & #recycle lunchtime on @indiegogo: http://tinyurl.com/3sczlx3

 
Fun flying #lunch trash! @ecolunchboxes needs help to make an #eco #app for #green #kids. Crowd funding at @indiegogo: http://tinyurl.com/3sczlx3

 
I’m helping @ecolunchboxes make an #eco #app about lunch
waste #Green game
teaches #recycling and #zerowaste @indiegogo http://tinyurl.com/3sczlx3

 
2.  Post on Facebook! We are http://www.facebook.com/ecolunchboxes Use messages we suggest here or make your own!

Join us in helping @ecolunchboxes make a lunch trash game for kids! This FREE smart phone app called Green Trash Ninja will be fun for kids and teach them about reducing lunchtime waste. DONATE to the cause and win PRIZES. http://www.indiegogo.com/Green-Trash-Ninja-Crowd-Fundraising-for-Eco-Game-App

Check out this crowd funding campaign by our friends at @ecolunchboxes! They want to make a smart phone game for kids to teach about reducing waste and lunchtime and recycling. They're offering PRIZES to donors who help them develop this project. http://www.indiegogo.com/Green-Trash-Ninja-Crowd-Fundraising-for-Eco-Game-App
 
3.    Post a badge on
your blog or your website telling the world that you’re supporting our eco
educational project! You can right click and save the badges below to use them. Link the badges back to this page at http://www.indiegogo.com/Green-Trash-Ninja-Crowd-Fundraising-for-Eco-Game-App so more people can learn all about it!  :-)

To download a badge, go to: http://www.ecolunchboxes.com/lunchgame/
