Carl has a Master of Science degree from
Stockholm School of Economics and started his career as management consultant
at McKinsey & Co. Since 2004 he has been an independent trainer and
consultant focusing on inspiring purpose driven and sustainable leadership in
organizations. Carl is also a trained permaculture designer and applies a
system perspective on how we can make our soil more alive and fertile since
this is the foundation for everything at an organic farm. One of Carl’s
long-term aspirations is to be able to show how human systems and organizations can learn from
natural systems, and to arrange workshops and conferences on how we can build richer ecosystems for the future.You can read more about us and our farm adventure at our website Lindeborgs Gård.

Ready to Go

We cannot wait to push the go-button to realize the
Eco Barn Project, a unique 1100 square meter learning and inspiration center. We have worked hard during one and a half year together with White Arkitekter, our architects. Now all the drawings are complete, the building permit is in place, we have harvested
and sawed the wood needed and we have done loads of
research to make sure we integrate the most promising and innovative sustainable technologies (read more about them at the end of this page).We believe the Eco Barn is truly unique, as it will house a multitude of different functions all supporting each other. There will be carbon negative production of electricity, a processing chain for old Swedish heritage grains and other farm produce such as honey. As a guest you will be able to eat delicious organic food in our farm restaurant, and stay in rooms made out of the wood from our forest, all designed and furnished with natural organic materials. You will be able to go to classes or have meetings in the the classroom overlooking the lake. And you will be able to recharge in the sauna, the winter garden or by the naturally clear pond. You will be able to experience all systems in action, connecting you with nature, a living soil and the origins of food. You will be in the middle of it all. 

What We Need to Get Going
The challenge for us is that the scope of our holistic project is large and that innovative sustainable solutions are costly. We can finance part of the investment ourselves
through savings and loans, the Swedish Environmental Protection Agency will support part of the investment in the energy solutions, but we still need additional funding to get going. The
crowdfunding campaign plays a critical role here. We would love to have you onboard this exciting journey and your support will help us bring the Eco Barn vision to life. The funds from the crowdfunding will go to four important parts of this project: 


The Creative Farm Dojo ($100 000)With a stunning view over the lake and the fields where the veggies for
today’s meals may just be harvested, the farm dojo will be a special place, the most
important one at the farm. Dojo means a place for studies and this is where
trainings, workshops and creative meetings will take place. Here people with different backgrounds and perspectives will meet to learn and to explore how we practically can build a better, more sustainable world. In the ceiling you
see the original wooden framework of the barn and the wooden floors will be made
with new timber from our forest. This will be a place for both stillness and
creativity, a place for big thoughts, deep insight and conversations that make a difference.


The Winter Garden Learning Space ($100 000)To make the barn into a real living ecosystem itself, we will integrate
a combined winter garden and green house. Here people can get the benefits of green
plant presence also in winter and we can produce delicious green leaves and
vegetables for the farm to table kitchen, all year round. This space will be a
green room for learning and relaxation and also the perfect place to experience
delicious organic food from the surrounding farm ecosystem.


Nature in the walls – wool and linen insulation ($30 000)A healthy and sustainable building is made by natural and renewable
materials. We will need 400 cubic meters of wonderful wool and linen insulation
to make the barn warm, cozy and energy efficient.


Releasing Plant Power – an innovative water cleaning system ($30 000)The water cleaning system will be biological, using a new technology that
fulfills the strictest rules and regulations by using a mix of plants to clean
all the waste water from the building. The solution includes a unique phosphor trap to prevent leakage and to make it possible to reuse these nutrients.


If this project can attract more funds than the requested $260 000 we would be absolutely thrilled. This would help us fund:
The Eco Barn Farm to Table Restaurant and Cooking Studio ($150 000)A creative restaurant where you see the chefs in action or participate yourself in the cooking experience is one of the best ways to help people connect to the origins of food and the quality of sustainable farming. Working with a skilled kitchen consultant and chef, we have planned for a wonderful, open restaurant kitchen in the Eco Barn designed for our guests to really get engaged in the processing, cooking and savoring of the farm's organic produce. A unique feature is the attached Winter Garden where green leaves and vegetables will be produced all year round. A wood stove used for cooking will also be integrated in the kitchen.
Our Sister Campaign - The
Carbon Negative ProjectThe Eco Barn will be a demonstration site for a truly unique combination
of energy solutions, using solar power, biochar and sterling engines. These solutions
will make the carbon footprint of the building negative which means that the
more we use the building the less CO2 in the atmosphere and the more we help to
reverse global warming. We believe that these solutions, that we want to help to test, demonstrate and spread, make up a big part of the solution for the climate challenge that we
together face. To be able to share the whole story around these amazing technologies we created a separate crowd funding campaign called The Carbon Negative Project.
How We Can Give Back
We are truly grateful if you would like to join us and help us make the Eco Barn vision possible. As a way to acknowledge
your support we have developed a number of exciting ways to say thank you and give value back to you. The Pioneer Discount!We would love to meet you at the Eco Barn the day we open and are happy to offer  a 25% pioneer discount on your first Eco Barn experiences. This is valid to anyone contributing with $50 or more, and applies to everything at the farm including farm stays, tours, classes, conferences and workshops, our organic products, restaurant meals and so on. The discount extends one year from the day we open the Eco Barn on purchases up to a total value of $10 000. The Eco Barn Friends SignboardWhen you support the campaign, you and everybody else that contributed, will be thanked by having your names and countries appear on a large beautiful signboard near the Eco Barn entrance (unless you prefer to remain anonymous of course).Here is a summary of the Perk Packages:

Eco Barn Friend


"Greener" - E-book or Printed Copy 

Tree Supporter

Organic Illustrations


Lamb Supporter

Scything Course

Bee Supporter

Farm Visit VIP Package
Main Sponsor of the Ecobarn
Water Renewal Champion

Sustainable Learning Champion
Green Power Champion
These perks are detailed to the right of the page. You can also read more about some of them below."Greener" - Creating a Farm Sanctuary Together With NatureDuring the four years that we have been working to
improve and develop the ecosystems around the farm, we have learnt a lot. In
this book you will visit the farm and see how far we have come up until today. We also share many useful
ways to enrich any ecosystem, whether it is a balcony, a small villa garden or a large
farm. The 70-page book is designed to be a source of inspiration with lots of photos
and wonderful illustrations made by our talented gardener Sina.We are really happy that we can share the farm adventure with you in this way. The book is available as E-book and in a printed copy.  We will start sending out the e-book by email from May 15 and the printed version from May 25.

A Chance to Share Your Inspiration - Adopting a TreeTrees are the tallest, most proud green presences in the ecosystem, benefitting both humans, birds and insects with their flowers and fruits. As a way to say thank for adopting one of the fruit trees, that are to be planted in Eco Barn orchard, this tree will have your name and your favorite inspirational quote on a badge hanging from one of the branches, inspiring all the Eco Barn visitors winding down and contemplating in the orchard.A Chance to get Creative - Naming the Bees and the LambsBoth our newly born lambs and our honeybees are highly valued at the farm. You can leave an imprint by supporting them and help us naming either a lamb or a bee hive. You will see the result through a high quality digital photo and a film shot.Organic illustrations of the beauty of the plant worldSina who has been working with us for two years at the farm is a truly gifted illustrator. One of her specialities is capturing the beauty of the plant world.In a limited edition we have printed two wonderful illustrations, "Edible Flowers" and Saving Your Own Tomato Seeds", that you could receive, depicting aspects of the rich farm ecosystem. The prints are professionally made on high quality paper and ready to be framed. The size is 210 × 297 millimetre. The prints are numbered and of course signed by Sina. You can check out more of her work at Instagram "Three Hazels"."Edible Flowers"
"Saving your own tomato seeds"
Leaving a Legacy - Champions and Main SponsorsWe really believe the Eco Barn is a unique project that will make a significant positive contribution to the world beyond the farm borders. We we would love to long-term team up with a number of people and organizations that share our values and beliefs and that would like to get involved with financial support and potentially also with other forms of collaboration. You will be the Champions of the Eco Barn Project and our Main Sponsors. In the perks presentation to the right we describe the different roles and some ways we can give back in exchange for your very important and generous support. We are also very open to your own ideas on how we can create a long-term win-win collaboration centering around sustainability, learning and innovation.What happens with the contributions if the funding target is not met?If the crowdfunding target is not met fully, your contribution to this
campaign will still be used for the Eco Barn Project. Either we will be able to
realize the full vision by finding complementing sources of financing, or we
will kick in the persistant part of ourselves and start with part of the project, realizing the full vision step by step
over time.

The Impact
We cannot wait to get going! We wish to put all the planning
and preparations done so far into action as soon as possible, aiming to open the Eco Barn in 2017. Your support will help enable this project and the
surrounding ecosystems to make a significant positive impact in several areas:


New ideas, perspectives and
inspiration that improves societyThe world needs more meeting places where human systems connect with natural systems, meeting places where different perspectives meet and new positive ideas arise to be spread and put into action. The Eco Barn is designed in every detail to enable this kind of meetings, courses and conversations.
Sustainable and
thriving people and organizationsThe Eco Barn will be a unique farm sanctuary enabling people to get in contact with nature and themselves. To be able to thrive in our fast paced society we believe that people, teams and organizations need space to breathe every now and then. We all need space to lift the gaze, to renew ourselves, to recharge. We need to distance ourselves from the action every now and then to be able to see the whole picture, make better choices and come back with more and energy and stronger intent.
Spreading of brand new green
technologies for a sustainable futureWe want the Eco Barn to be a unique building that tells stories of hope and possibility. One really important story will be around the green technologies, a story that we believe will spread and help make many more building much more green, benefitting both people and environment.

Climate change reversal by
creating one of the worlds first carbon negative buildingsThe building will be self sufficient when it comes to energy production based on technology that help us store carbon in the soil. The more we use  the building, the better for the climate and the generations to come.



Thank You for Joining Us!We hope that you have become as excited about the Eco Barn Project as we are. We are truly grateful if you would like to join us and contribute to making this project happen. It would mean a lot to us and make a real difference.You can also make an impact by helping us to spread the word to as many people as possible that you think would find the project exciting. Two great ways are of course sharing this campaign on your favorite social media using the Indiegogo sharing tools and sending an email to people you believe would be particularly interested.Please also stay in touch and follow us through the farm's website, facebook page, instagram flow and blog. At the website you can also sign up for our newsletter.Thank You Again! Julia & Carl





Read More About Our Green Solutions
Part of the vision is that this will become a unique
demonstration building that contributes positively to surrounding ecosystems.
We believe it is possible to design systems in a way that the more a building
is used the better for the environment. The barn will become such a building.
We hope that the solutions and systems that we put in place also can inspire
many other to choose more green technologies and materials when building. Below
are some of the most important sustainable solutions.


The barn
will be rebuilt using our own timber from the forest. The logs have been pulled
out by horse to avoid ground damage and converted into construction wood and
planks by a local saw mill. Using a lot of wood in the building makes the
building itself a carbon sink, storing carbon dioxide (CO2).


In
addition to wood we will use as much other renewable and natural materials as
possible. The insulation in the walls and in the ceiling will be made out of
sheep wool and linen and the insulation in the foundation will consist of
recycled glass that is puffed up with air.


The
water cleaning system will be biological. We use a new technology that fulfills
the strictest rules and regulations while still using plants to clean all the
grey and black water from the building.


The
organically certified farm to table restaurant will use absolutely fresh and
local products from the farm. We will have a big focus on high quality plant
based food. There will be a processing chain in the barn to make fresh flour
from the grains we produce and a green house attached to the kitchen so green
produce will always be available to the chefs, even in the wintertime.

The heating system will be carbon dioxide negative, which is quite unique in the world. This means that the more we heat the building, the less CO2 in the atmosphere. This is done through a process called pyrolysis, in which organic matter, such as oat shells from the fields and wood chippings from the forest, are decoupled into heat gas and biochar. Biochar is basically what you use in the grill in the summer. The heat gas heats water that will circulate through a radiator system warming up the whole building. The biochar contains all the CO2 from the wood. So instead of releasing it back to the atmosphere, which is normally what happens when you burn wood, we can now add it back to the soil. The soil then stores the CO2 for hundreds to thousands of years while new trees grow up in the forest absorbing more CO2 from the atmosphere. Learn more at The Carbon Negative Project Campaign.
The barn will have its own electricity production, partly using solar power and partly using sterling engines. The sterling engines run on the heat gases from the pyrolysis process. They have a maximum effect of 10000 watt per engine and are able to power the whole farm operation. 


Some more images from the farm:

story:
Our Project

Four Girl Scouts from troop 43125 are earning our Bronze Award, the highest award that a Girl Scout Junior can earn. To do so, we need to plan and create a community service project that will have a lasting impact for years to come. We decided to plant a wildlife garden in an suburban area to attract brids and insects as they migrate or live locally. With the increase of construction and urbanization, we want to ensure that our wildlife freinds have places to rest and find haven.

Please help us raise the money we need to purchase plants and supplies to create our wildlife garden!

Thank you!

story:
Your support will help the Hawai'i Forest Institute to accomplish its 2015 goal of planting 4,000 seedlings while engaging 1,800 volunteers in forest stewardship learning activities across Hawai'i! 

At only $2.50 per planting, your contribution will secure culturally rich planting experiences and help foster a respect for the land as we MAHALO 'AINA: GIVE BACK TO THE FORESTS OF HAWAI'I! 

          

Uniqueness of the 'Aina (Land)

When many think of Hawai'i, its likely they imagine mild, sub-tropical weather. In fact, the Hawaiian islands also host climates that rival the harshest places on earth! From Alpine snow to black sand beaches and spanning desert-like sand and deep, lush rainforests, Hawaii's ecosystems are unparalleled in both their beauty and uniqueness. They also require dedicated protection to preserve this distinction.

Who We Are- Hawai'i Forest Institute (HFI)

The mission of the Hawai'i Forest Institute (HFI) is to promote the health and productivity of Hawaii’s forests through forest restoration, educational programs, information dissemination, and support for scientific research. HFI is now launching 40 DAYS FOR HAWAII'S FORESTS to promote our new MAHALO 'AINA: Give Back to the Forest program, which seeks to expand our community partnerships in order to gain support for the protection and perpetuation of Hawaii’s forest resources.  

Proven Success in Forestry Stewardship

Over the past 11 years, HFI has served over 3,400 individuals annually through our various forest restoration and educational projects programs, engaging:

• 500-600 youth and 200 adults through native forest restoration and education at three dryland forest sites in West Hawaii 

• 600 attendees to outreach events, including Grow Hawaiian Festival, Dryland Forest Symposium, Kuhio Day Festival

• 800 students in online learning lessons, 100 educational workshop attendants

• 450 volunteers at the Pana'ewa Zoo Discovery Forest, Keauhou Bird Conservation Center Discovery Forest, and Aina Mauna Christmas Tree Demonstration Project 

• 15 partners and 10 volunteers through the Hawaii Island Native Seed Bank

• An estimated readership of 1,000 students, educators, woodworkers, foresters, scientists and others through the Hawaii Forest Journal and HFIA newsletters

• Visitors worldwide through HFI’s and partner Ka' Ahahui o ka Nahelehele’s websites, with dryland forest lesson plans and other resources

HFI has supported efforts to restore over 45 acres of forest habitat and outplant over 9,000 seedlings.  40 DAYS FOR HAWAII'S FORESTS helps continue this path.

Hawaii's 'Aina Needs Our Protection

Many of Hawaii’s ecosystems are among the most endangered in the world. Over 95% of Hawaii’s dry forests have disappeared and over 25% of the endangered species in the Hawaiian flora are from dry forests. To protect these rare and special places, HFI asks supporters to give during the 40 DAYS TO HAWAII'S FORESTS to help us raise $10,000 to support our forest restoration and education projects! 

Reforesting Hawai'i With Your Support

With your contribution, we can reach our goal for 2015! Your donation will help finance the planting of 4,000 seedlings, while engaging 1,800 volunteers in forest stewardship learning activities at our forest restoration and demonstration sites throughout the state.  We'd love to have you, if you'd like to become involved! 

If we reach this goal, these 4,000 seedlings will be planted at the incredibly low cost of $2.50 a seedling, which includes the unique educational, environmental and cultural experience provided for the planters.  Your money goes directly into program operational costs and will help us to achieve a huge planting goal for 2015!

How You Can Help Protect Hawaii's Forests HERE and NOW

1.  Explore our awesome, original perks, all designed and crafted within Hawai'i!

2.  If you're interested, see our 15 reforestation and education projects across the islands. Learn about all the good work we've been doing since 2003!

3.  Choose a perk or a project at a level where you'd like to donate. (Wow, thanks!)

4.  If you're feeling generous, HELP SPREAD THE WORD via social media, email, snail mail, singing, dancing, shouting or whatever suits your fancy!

5.  Pat yourself on the back for supporting the future of Hawaii's forests!

MAHALO 'AINA Supports 15 Projects Statewide

MAHALO ‘AINA is not simply a tree planting program! While that's an important part of what we do, MAHALO ‘AINA also helps to support total ecosystem management while providing forest stewardship opportunities and educational programs for 15 different forestry projects throughout the state. 

Learn more about these 15 exciting reforestation and education projects at:

40 DAYS FOR HAWAII'S FORESTS: MAHALO 'AINA


Ways We Mahalo Our Donors! 

We're offering many beautiful, handcrafted and locally designed perks to choose from, but here are just a few of our favorite ways to say Mahalo for your Support!

$20 Apokolani Digital Album Download and Artwork

Listen here to Apokolani Hawaiian Jazz 


$25 MAHALO 'AINA Canvas Grocery Bag (or T-shirt!) with Logo


$50 Yoga for 2 in the Forest on O'ahu with Steph & Maya 

Get into your Tree Pose at Yoga Hawai'i!


$60 Handcrafted Hawaiian Koa Wood Lifetime Desk Pen Dunn Gallery


$150 Engraved Hawaiian Islands Set of Four Acryllic Coasters 

Choice of petroglyph or sea life coasters with islands engraved!

   

$120 Endemic Koa Wood-Inlay Sterling Silver Bangle Bracelet
Visit Komo Koa Hawaiian Koa Wood Rings!

$150 Endemic Koa Wood-Crafted Sterling Silver Earrings on Silver Hoops

Visit Komo Koa Hawaiian Koa Wood Rings!

$300 Invitation for 2 - Exclusive 2015 Hawaii's Woodshow Opening Reception 

Learn more about the incredible Hawaii's Woodshow, held annually on O'ahu! 
Visit Hawaii’s Woodshow, Na La‘au o Hawai‘i

$500- $1,500 Exclusive, Deep Forest Adventures for Five Guests + Lunch

WILL YOU HELP US PRESERVE HAWAII'S 'AINA BY DONATING DURING 40 DAYS FOR HAWAII'S FORESTS?  MAHALO FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

Special thanks to our supporters who provided campaign photos! Photo Credit to:
J.B. Friday, Kapapala Forest
Mike Robinson; Puu Oo Naio, Pii Honua Mauka Hike, Land of 1000 Ghosts, Mauna Kea
Yvonne Yarber Carter:
Kanu O Ka Aina Charter School with Keoki Carter, HFI Cultural Educator

40 DAYS FOR HAWAII'S FORESTS: MAHALO 'AINA

story:
NATURE’S LITTLE RECYCLERS: We need one van to help save the planet

Help save the planet by attacking the problems of soil depletion and excessive waste through supporting the cause of recycling organic waste by feeding Ed’s worms.

Ed needs a van.

Actually, his worms do. Nature’s Little Recyclers, based in Chicago, is on a mission to recycle organic waste, such as coffee grounds and chaff, paper products, household greens – and feed them to earthworms back at The Plant to create high-quality fertilizer.

Ed makes some of the world’s finest compost, and his suppliers include Chicago-area businesses and coffee shops, such as Intelligentsia. Luckily, Chicago is America’s largest sustainable community and plenty of people want to help! But, in order to handle the increasing volume, Ed needs reliable transportation. This is where the van comes in – and that’s where you come in!

The worms need more food.

Our staff is made up of earthworms, whose only goal in life is to eat and be happy while creating world-saving products. The worms eat through organic waste to turn it into vermicasts – excellent, nutrient-rich organic fertilizer – which Nature’s Little Recyclers can produce products that feed plants, including fruits, vegetables, lawns, and even trees throughout the Chicagoland area to support urban farms, community gardens, among other health plants.

With your help we will continue to expand, eliminating more waste and producing healthy compost, as well as feeding large numbers of useful, happy earthworms. Now that Nature’s Little Recyclers has grown to hundreds of pounds of earthworms, we need more materials.

More food for the worms means less waste for local businesses.

Nature’s Little Recyclers helps coffee shops and roasters come closer to net-zero waste by using coffee grounds and filters, which we collect from local coffee shops. In Chicago alone, these coffee shops produce more than 40 tons a week of grounds and potential waste that could be eliminated through our process.

Together, we can lower the amount of waste headed to landfills and turn it into nutrient-rich soil, leading to the growth of even more plants in Chicago for an ultimately greener future.

Help Ed help the worms to help local businesses in Chicago save the planet.

Since its founding in October 2012, Nature’s Little Recyclers has relied on friends, volunteers and rentals to pick up materials. With more businesses willing to donate organic material than ever, it has become difficult to depend solely on our network of volunteers. We need a dedicated vehicle to be able to reliably pick up materials, eliminating them from landfills, and getting them back to our facilities. 

In order to be able to continue to grow, the only missing link is a dedicated vehicle. By reaching our goal of $10,000 we can get a dedicated van which will allow us to expand pickup to several more sites per day and meet our goals of taking several tons of waste a week out of the waste stream and return it to the earth as exceptional quality fertilizer.

Exceeding our goal will allow us to also cover operating costs, and continue to expand into additional locations. It costs us approximately $50 per location to provide food-grade buckets and bins to store organic materials.

Help us make a significant impact to a major problem.


Perks

$5 – Friend of the Worms Certificate – We will send you a PDF certificate, espousing your praises by Nature’s Little Recyclers as a friend. Every little bit helps, and as the worms can tell you, enough small actions lead to great success. We will send one to everyone who supports a perk.

$15 - Friend of the Worms Coffee Cup - We will send you a great coffee cup, with our green recycle symbol, and our appreciation. Know drinking your coffee, our earthworms are working to make coffee greener.

$20 –Bag Caviar Compost – We will give you a two-pound bag of Caviar Compost,our finest vermicasts, to give your plants a boost. We’ll also include a collection of promotional postcards. 

$35 - Heirloom Tomato Seeds & Compost Starter - Share in a Collection of  5 Types of Heirloom Tomato Seeds ready for starting. We include two bags of our finest caviar compost to start the seeds in time for spring.

$50 – Private Earth Day Tour – On April 22nd, We will give you a private tour of The Plant, Chicago which is home to our facilities, as well as other local organizations making a difference in the environment. For reference, The Plant is a new kind of organization in a very old building. It is part vertical farm, part food-business incubator, part research and education space – and it will be entirely off the grid. Light refreshments will also be provided on the tour.

·$100 – Gift certificates – We will give you gift certificates for our Pop Up Farming Store. This will include Nature’s Little Recyclers Composts, Worms, and other products. Over the next year we will be adding more items needed for green urban growth.

$250 – Become a Worm – Our Artist will illustrate you or any description as a worm in your honor that will join our worm family. Depending on description or image desired, we will have our artist draw an original art, which we will send the Illustration to you. We will also scan and add it to our Nature’s Little Recyclers Family of Worms, used in our various educational and public campaigns. 


Get your logo on the Van: Since we will be driving this all over Chicago, you can get your logo, company or group name, NASCAR style on our van. This will allow your business, NFP, or cause seen almost daily, all over the city. We are offering four sizes.

            o  $40.00 Business Card Image 2" by 3.5"

            o  $200 5" by 5" Image

            o  $500 9" by 9" Image

            o  $1000 12" by 12" Image


The Impact of Your Help
Your help with providing us with a van, and support our collection efforts, we will be able to reduce wastes, turn them into soil assets, and make our city greener.  We are focused on providing products to as many gardens, farms, and growers as we can, and this will allow us to move actively in that direction.
story_txt:
NATURE’S LITTLE RECYCLERS: We need
one van to help save the planet
Help save
the planet by attacking the problems of soil depletion and excessive waste
through supporting the cause of recycling organic waste by feeding Ed’s worms. 
Ed needs a
van. 
Actually,
his worms do. Nature’s Little Recyclers, based in Chicago, is on a mission to recycle
organic waste, such as coffee grounds and chaff, paper products, household
greens – and feed them to earthworms back at The Plant to
create high-quality fertilizer. 
Ed makes
some of the world’s finest compost, and his suppliers include Chicago-area
businesses and coffee shops, such as Intelligentsia. Luckily, Chicago is
America’s largest sustainable community and plenty of people want to help! But,
in order to handle the increasing volume, Ed needs reliable transportation.
This is where the van comes in – and that’s where you come in!
The worms need
more food.
Our staff is
made up of earthworms, whose only goal in life is to eat and be happy while
creating world-saving products. The worms eat through organic waste to turn it
into vermicasts – excellent, nutrient-rich organic fertilizer – which Nature’s
Little Recyclers can produce products that feed plants, including fruits,
vegetables, lawns, and even trees throughout the Chicagoland area to support
urban farms, community gardens, among other health plants. 
With your
help we will continue to expand, eliminating more waste and producing healthy
compost, as well as feeding large numbers of useful, happy earthworms. Now that
Nature’s Little Recyclers has grown to hundreds of pounds of earthworms, we
need more materials.
More food
for the worms means less waste for local businesses.
Nature’s
Little Recyclers helps coffee shops and roasters come closer to net-zero waste
by using coffee grounds and filters, which we collect from local coffee shops.
In Chicago alone, these coffee shops produce more than 40 tons a week of
grounds and potential waste that could be eliminated through our process. 
Together, we
can lower the amount of waste headed to landfills and turn it into
nutrient-rich soil, leading to the growth of even more plants in Chicago for an ultimately greener future. 
Help Ed help
the worms to help local businesses in Chicago save the planet.
Since its
founding in October 2012, Nature’s Little Recyclers has relied on friends,
volunteers and rentals to pick up materials. With more businesses willing to
donate organic material than ever, it has become difficult to depend solely on
our network of volunteers. We need a dedicated vehicle to be able to reliably
pick up materials, eliminating them from landfills, and getting them back to
our facilities.  
In order to
be able to continue to grow, the only missing link is a dedicated vehicle. By
reaching our goal of $10,000 we can get a dedicated van which will allow us to
expand pickup to several more sites per day and meet our goals of taking
several tons of waste a week out of the waste stream and return it to the earth
as exceptional quality fertilizer. 
Exceeding
our goal will allow us to also cover operating costs, and continue to expand
into additional locations. It costs us approximately $50 per location to
provide food-grade buckets and bins to store organic materials. 
Help us make
a significant impact to a major problem.
Perks
$5 – Friend of the Worms Certificate – We
will send you a PDF certificate, espousing your praises by Nature’s Little
Recyclers as a friend. Every little bit helps, and as the worms can tell you,
enough small actions lead to great success. We will send one to everyone who
supports a perk. 

$15 - Friend of the Worms Coffee Cup - We will send you a great coffee cup, with our green recycle symbol, and our appreciation. Know drinking your coffee, our earthworms are working to make coffee greener. $20 –Bag Caviar
Compost – We will give you a two-pound bag of Caviar Compost,our finest vermicasts, to give your
plants a boost. We’ll also include a collection of promotional postcards.  
$35 - Heirloom Tomato Seeds & Compost Starter - Share in a Collection of  5 Types of Heirloom Tomato Seeds ready for starting. We include two bags of our finest caviar compost to start the seeds in time for spring.$50 – Private Earth Day Tour – On April 22nd, We will give you a private tour of
The Plant, Chicago which is home to our facilities, as well as other local
organizations making a difference in the environment. For reference, The Plant
is a new kind of organization in a very old building. It is part vertical farm,
part food-business incubator, part research and education space – and it will
be entirely off the grid. Light
refreshments will also be provided on the tour.


·$100 – Gift certificates – We will give you gift certificates for our Pop Up Farming Store. This will include
Nature’s Little Recyclers Composts, Worms, and other products. Over the next
year we will be adding more items needed for green urban growth. $250 – Become a Worm – Our Artist will illustrate you or any description as a worm in your
honor that will join our worm family. Depending on description or image
desired, we will have our artist draw an original art, which we will send the Illustration to
you. We will also scan and add it to our Nature’s Little Recyclers Family of
Worms, used in our various educational and public campaigns. 

Get your logo on the Van: Since we will be driving this all over
Chicago, you can get your logo,
company or group name, NASCAR style on our van. This will allow your business,
NFP, or cause seen almost daily, all over the city. We are offering four sizes.

5" by 5" Image

story:
The Final Countdown- 12/28/2014

What an incredible journey this crowd-funding pursuit has been. I never imagined this heartwarming and supportive response from my fellow community members. You have made it possible for me to answer research questions that are critical to the future protection of pacific-slope flycatchers. Now that I can successfully analyze all of the feathers for hydrogen isotope ratios (an intrinsic marker of breeding origin), I will be able to determine where the birds began their migration. This research will be used to make necessary wildlife management recommendations to organizations such as The San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory.      

But, with only 5 days left to my fundraising campaign, I am still $1,165 away from meeting my stretch goal and acquiring the remaining funds necessary to complete my thesis research. The additional carbon and nitrogen isotope analyses I need to conduct will help me better understand what the flycatchers were eating when they began their migration, a component necessary for future protection of declining songbirds.  

Please help me spread the word in these final days and help me succeed in this one last push for avian conservation! 

Project Update - 11/28/2014

Indeed it has been a Happy Thanksgiving! As of this morning, Operation Feather Quest met its initial fundraising goal of $3,949. I am so thankful for all of the incredible support; you've made it possible for my research to successfully take flight! I can now analyze 180 samples for the first of two tests I need to conduct -- hydrogen isotope ratios. 

But this is just the beginning of my feather quest. To answer all of my research questions regarding the migratory whereabouts of pacific-slope flycatchers, I need to conduct additional analyses. Not only do I want to determine where pacific-slope flycatchers begin their migration, but I want to determine what the birds were eating. A second test -- for carbon-nitrogen ratios -- will help me understand that.

The U.C. Davis Stable Isotope Facility charges $8/sample for a single carbon and nitrogen isotope laboratory analysis. I have 180 samples that need to be analyzed, and U.C. Davis recommends that every 12 samples are repeated for accuracy. 

So, I need an additional $1,560 to pay for these services. Additionally, my original promise to the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory was to donate 15% of the contributions raised to their organization. I would like to be able to do more than that.    

If I can raise an additional $2,500, I will not only cover the additional services needed to complete my Master's thesis research, but I will be able to make a significant contribution to the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory. Please help me reach this new goal and further contribute to avian conservation. Thank you so much for participating in Operation Feather Quest.   

The Thesis Project

The Feather Quest  was a book written in 1992 by Pete Dunne, father of the "World Series of Birding" challenges. Mr. Dunne sought to foster environmental awareness among readers through his year-long birding expedition. The motivation behind my own feather quest for research that will complete my Master's degree thesis is the same.     

Pacific-slope flycatcher (Empidonax difficilis) populations as well as many other neotropical migrant songbirds are declining throughout North America. 

Wildlife managers cannot pinpoint the direct causes of mortality because there is a lack of understanding of the relationship between individual songbirds and their geographic locations throughout migration. Advances in biogeochemical analyses have found that stable isotope ratios in the feathers of birds correlate with stable isotope ratios of breeding ground precipitation. The food that birds eat in their native breeding grounds has a weight of hydrogen, carbon, and nitrogen isotopes that is unique to the specific area. The feathers these birds grow contain such isotope ratios, providing researchers with invaluable information about their origins

Operation Feather Quest will examine the feathers of 180 migrating pacific-slope flycatchers captured in Santa Clara County, CA. The data from these feathers will reveal critical migratory information on the birds' origins necessary to protect populations from further declining. 

Why I need your support

The use of intrinsic markers is a practical and feasible method to determine breeding origins of migrating songbirds. By sampling feather specimens from pacific-slope flycatchers, stable isotope analysis establishes the origin of that specific feather.   

I have spent the past six months collaborating with a non-profit scientific organization, the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory, at the Coyote Creek Field Station, a federal bird banding operation in Milpitas, CA. At this station we used non-invasive mist nest techniques to capture migrating pacific-slope flycatchers and carefully sampled their tail feathers before releasing the birds back into the wild. Then, the feather samples were prepared in a laboratory at San Jose State University. 

Up until this point all of the field and laboratory preparation equipment has been paid for, but I need your support to help me pay for the analytical services. 

The U.C. Davis Stable Isotope Facility charges $17/sample for a single stable isotope laboratory analysis. I have 180 samples that need to be analyzed, and U.C. Davis recommends that every 8 samples are repeated for accuracy. 

So, I need $3,434 to pay for these services.     

Additionally, 15% of the donations received will be given to the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory's field station. Without the support of the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory this project would not be on its way to success.   

You are contributing to avian conservation! 

Human impacts such as urbanization and development, disease and invasive species introduction and natural resource depletion in combination with a changing climate severely compromise the integrity of our planet. Wildlife extinction is a problem conservationists have been facing for many years, and birds are particularly sensitive to anthropogenic pressures. In order to implement effective, productive and sustainable management practices we must research and understand the entire spectrum of environmental change, starting with the smaller and more intricate levels of species.

By supporting Operation Feather Quest, you will help myself and fellow biologists better understand the grand phenomenon of bird migration, provide opportunities to discover and implement appropriate management techniques for wildlife populations at risk, and promote the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory's ongoing commitment to the conservation of birds and their habitats.   

Frequently Asked Questions

Does pulling feathers hurt the birds?

The very last thing this project aims to do is put any of the birds at risk or inflict any pain upon them. All of the procedures involved with the capturing and handling of the birds were guided by the North American Banding Council Bander's Code of Ethics, in which the operation's priority is the safety of the birds. The pulling of the tail feathers occurred quickly and cautiously, and any pain associated with this was only experienced momentarily. Pulling tail feathers is harmless; similar to pulling out a hair. The Coyote Creek Field Station employs a series of protocols and training to ensure the handling of the birds is safe and injury free.    

What happens to the birds after you are finished sampling them? 

All of the birds are released into the wild at the site of capture so that they can continue their migration. The time it takes to capture the bird, band them, take measurements and pull tail feathers takes only about 5 minutes.  

What are your qualifications for conducting this type of research?

I have been volunteering with the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory at the Coyote Creek Field Station Training to band birds since May, 2012. I hold a background and undergraduate degree in Animal/Pre-Veterinary Sciences where I have spent over seven years handling a variety of species of animals. I have handled approximately 500- 600 birds. I was trained to pull feathers from birds by professionally certified bird banders.  

What type of permits do you need for this project?

I am required to have a University IACUC (Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee) protocol, a Federal Bird Banding permit, and a state Collections permit. I have all of the permits and approvals, in collaboration with the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory, required to undertake this research.   

When will you get results?

Once I receive all of the funding to send my feather samples to the U.C. Davis Stable Isotope Facility the analysis process will take approximately 4-6 weeks. 

What will you do with the results?

Once I receive the feather isotope results, a series of statistical correlations will be used to compare feather values to breeding origin values, based on the natural isotopes in precipitation. I will compare the feather isotopes of the pacific-slope flycatchers to the natural isotopes in precipitation and determine where each bird migrated from. 

The results from this research will be provided to the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory for the Coyote Creek Field Station  biologists to create predictive models of migrating flycatcher populations in the future. The results will also be provided to the Bird Banding Laboratory of the U.S. Geological Survey and to the Migratory Bird Center of the Smithsonian Conservation Biology Institute to allow conservation biologists to implement proper management techniques to further protect pacific-slope flycatcher populations. Lastly, the results will be used for my Environmental Studies Master's thesis at San Jose State University and prepared for future publication. 

About the researcher

My name is Emily Moffitt and I am a M.S. graduate student at San Jose State University in the Environmental Studies department. I am originally from the east coast, and nature and wildlife were very much a part of my daily life as a child. I was raised to honor and appreciate all aspects of the living environment, thus prompting my biophilic personality. I received my B.S. in Animal Science from the University of Vermont. 

My love for birds truly began when I worked in Atlin, British Columbia after graduating college with the non-profit educational organization, Round River Conservation Studies, and Bird Studies Canada on a breeding bird atlas. When I moved to the Bay Area 3 years ago, I became involved with the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory as a volunteer bird bander at the Coyote Creek Field Station and as a colonial waterbird monitor where I conducted surveys of breeding heron and egret populations throughout the South San Francisco Bay. I've continued working with the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory and interned this past summer with their Snowy Plover Recovery Program, helped with California Gull monitoring, and trained with folks from the USGS and USFWS on a variety of wildlife surveys. 

I am a bird nerd to say the least. As a passionate bird watcher, avian science advocate, habitat preservationist, and environmentalist, I am deeply concerned about earth's ever-changing environment. I have a passion for scientific knowledge and a strong vision that can sustain us and our planet.

I am committed to and eager to make a difference in the protection of our environment through avian research and hope that you can help me reach that goal!

story:
HELP SUPPORT PALESTINIAN FARMERS AND THEIR FAMILIES IN THE OCCUPIED TERRITORIES WITH OLIVE TREES. 

THIS FEBRUARY, WE WILL PLANT THE TREES WITH FARMERS WHOSE TREES HAVE BEEN UPROOTED, TORCHED OR CUT DOWN BY ISRAELI EXTREMISTS -- FARMERS WHO RELY ON THOSE TREES FOR THEIR LIVELIHOOD.

They will beat their swords into plowshares and their spears into pruning hooks. Nation will not take up sword against nation, nor will they train for war anymore (Isaiah 2:4).
Rabbis for Human Rights is a rabbinic organization rooted in the belief that, as all 

people are created in the image of God, we are obligated to protest against every injustice enacted against any other person. As part of our work, we fight against acts of vandalism, destruction and abuse towards Palestinians and Palestinian property by Jewish extremists. Palestinian agriculture, and specifically, olive trees, are a prime target of attacks by these extremists.


For the last ten years Rabbis for Human Rights has planted olive trees with our Palestinian partners in the Occupied Territories in what has become one of our most notable traditions.  As we witness new levels of vandalism against these ancient and precious trees, we see our mission as more urgent and valuable than ever. More than an international symbol of peace, our olive trees also represent the mending of  injustice and wrongs between Israeli Jews and Palestinians. Hope coming alive, these trees will one day bear beautiful olives that will benefit generations of Palestinians to come.


In Palestinian society, olive trees carry huge significance. So much that a Palestinian farmer describes them as “the foundation of the home.” Some farmers own trees that have been passed down through their family for generations, caring for the same trees they harvested with their parents and grandparents. 

You are buying more than an olive tree.  Every donation also promises:

  •  Palestinians and Israelis working together on a common goal 

  •  Jews, Muslims and Christians planting the seedlings of justice and hope

  • Greater prosperity for Palestinian farmers 

  •  Sustained and strengthened access for farmers today and for their  children tomorrow 

For Palestinians, olive trees represent connection to the land. With its deep roots and ability to survive harsh winters and dry summers, the olive tree is a symbol of hope and steadfastness. In addition, olives are an economic staple for many Palestinians in the Occupied Territories. At least 100,000 families depend to some extent on the harvest for their livelihoods year-round. 

Give an olive tree today.  Plant Change—Grow Hope.

For more on what we do, please visit us at:

http://rhr.org.il/eng/


Please share this campaign widely - Thank you for making a difference!

More than an international symbol of peace, our olive trees also represent the mending of  injustice and wrongs between Israeli Jews and Palestinians. Hope coming alive, these trees will one day bear beautiful olives that will benefit generations of Palestinians to come.



In Palestinian society, olive trees carry huge significance. So much that a Palestinian farmer describes them as “the foundation of the home.” Some farmers own trees that have been passed down through their family for generations, caring for the same trees they harvested with their parents and grandparents. 
You are buying more than an olive tree.  Every donation also promises:


 Palestinians and Israelis working together on a common goal 




 Jews, Muslims and Christians planting the seedlings of justice and hope





Greater prosperity for Palestinian farmers 




 Sustained and strengthened access for farmers today and for their  children tomorrow 

For Palestinians, olive trees represent connection to the land. With its deep roots and ability to survive harsh winters and dry summers, the olive tree is a symbol of hope and steadfastness. In addition, olives are an economic staple for many Palestinians in the Occupied Territories. At least 100,000 families depend to some extent on the harvest for their livelihoods year-round. Give an olive tree today.  Plant Change—Grow Hope.


For more on what we do, please visit us at:
http://rhr.org.il/eng/

Please share this campaign widely - Thank you for making a difference!

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Aaron and I was born on the organic blueberry farm I am now regenerating. Growing up, I spent a lot of my time with my Dad at the Earthcare, Richmond’s community garden, and travelling around NSW with him certifying organic farms. I am now passionately dedicated to providing a framework for a local food system that is beneficial for the environment and the community.

A CSA is a way for community members to directly shape the way they interact with their environment and the food they eat.  I think it’s important for people to have the opportunity to be more directly involved in the farm where their food is grown and to have access to good quality, seasonal, local and organic produce.

By investing in the farms, you can co-create, a community based, organic, local food system.  CSA projects are in the embryonic stage in Australia. They have been successfully running for decades around the world. For example in Japan it is called Food with The Farmers Face. By subscribing you become part of the global movement towards environmental restorative agriculture.

 

What We Need & What You Get

These funds will be used to take to farm to the next level of production so that we can provide 30-60 members with quality fortnightly boxes of produce that replace their normal fresh food shopping. The Bilpin farm is perfect for growing your delicious, household veggies while the Mt Tomah farm has well-established berries, figs and nut trees.

Most importantly, a CSA is an opportunity for you to be part of the farm and to get to know who is growing your food. Once the farms are up and running, I hope you will be part of the farm for years to come as we grow and improve together.

If we fail to meet our crowd-funding goal, we will simply do the best with what we have.

 

The Impact

For three years Harvest Hampers has been gathering produce directly from farmers and delivering it to people’s doors in a timely and efficient manner. Now with Harvest Farms we hope to provide the next step of closeness to your food and the land.

 

Risks & Challenges

 

Of Course there will be challenges, insect infestations, disease, bad weather, etc. but the idea of a CSA is that we are in this together, we share in the losses just as we share in the bounty of beautiful abundance on the good harvest.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don’t feel you have the money to help us on our way. Please share this page with your friends so we can get our word out there. Your help will be greatly appreciated.

story:
Here's the deal.  Carl Safina and the Blue Ocean Institute is a strong presence in the marine conservation community and do amazing things for healthy seas. Sandy wiped out their fundraising gala. I want to bring the conservation community together and support one of our own during this time. I wanted to dig in and help at least fix a fence or two, but a slight problem - they're in NY; I'm unfortunately not.  So...See that awesome Sandy Octo-pie above you?  For every $100 we get Carl and the Blue Ocean Institute, I'll personally make a (homemade) Sandy Octo-pie (or a dozen cupcakes or cookies.  This one is triple chocolate cheesecake.  Either way, they'll be delicious and cute) and deliver them to the families that use the Angel Network foodbank here in Hawaii just in time for Thanksgiving (and Christmas!).  You get double karma bang for your buck!  I'll also take photos of every pie, post/send out, and personally deliver the goods.  

Blue Ocean Institute: http://blueocean.org

And a bit more on the Angel Network:

"Angel Network Charities, Inc. (ANC) is a private, non-profit organization serving Oahu's homeless and at-risk families. Originally designated by the State as Hawaii Kai's Homeless Village, ANC replaced the village concept with a scattered site plan that did not stigmatize residents. At the time ANC partnered with various churches, businesses, professionals, and other agencies to insure that the families gained the skills and education needed to become and remain self-sufficient. Many of these families continue to be self-supporting to this day. 

Families that we assist at ANC are required to work with a case manager to develop and pursue a self-sufficiency plan, avoid drugs and alcohol, and give back to ANC and the community through volunteer services. Particiants are also encouraged to pursue their spiritual development within a religious community of their choice." 

Thanks - Kelly

story:
AQEX Wastewater Index (WWI)

AQEX is a new company devoted to bringing the true cost of nature's services to the financial services. While doing so, we stumbled on a fantastic find! Wastewater has all the potential to be the new extractive industry which is both environmentally friendly and financially lucrative!

Let me explain the business model around wastewater:

Wastewater is currently a liability (it costs people and businesses money in the form of deteriorating health, environment, and taxes, along with cleanup costs). However, after working in waste management for over 15 years (google our founder, Candace Chandra), we see that wastewater is actually the natural resource par excellence. Technology is now available (actually it has existed for over 30 years, but is now commercially viable at small sites, as well as large sites) which allows minerals, chemicals, and other pollutants to be extracted from wastewater, WHILE cleaning the water, so the water itself can be reused (or returned in a clean state to the local environment).


Think how FANTASTIC this is:

wastewater actually produces multiple revenue streams:

-reusable cleaner (not always potable/drinking) water, plus

-chemicals (such as fertilizer) which can be resold and used, plus

-minerals used for industry, plus

-the relief of tax liabilities reduced or destroyed, plus

-the return of wildlife and fish to former dead zones (thus recreating related industries such as fishing, tourism, etc)!

By contributing to the development of an index (which prices wastewater, similarly to the oil industry such as Brent Crude), you are helping to develop this nascent industry!

Production Costs

In order to create a viable (accepted by financial institutions and other users) index, the following steps must happen:
 
a) AQEX staff will travel to various sites around the US and verify water amounts, quality, types of contaminants, and feasibility of extraction;
b) AQEX staff (and you, if you are a BIG funder) will analyze types of water and conditions for consistency and produce categories for index. A survey of potential users will also take place;
c) pricing (using AQEX founder's patented algorithm) will be applied to wastewater locales and types;
d) information regarding pricing and water types will be shared globally via an Internet site listing the daily fluctuations (this step will be funded separatedly due to its gigantic cost relative to the rest of the project, unless you are all very generous and fund above and beyond the amount set!!).

The Impact

LET THE ENVIRONMENTAL ECONOMY BEGIN!!
 
When this business model succeeds, it will show business people, students, and the world how to restructure their thinking to produce locally friendly businesses which are profitable. How better to help the world than that??
 
If you are tired of talk and want to do something concrete today, contribute to us and put this business model on the map!!
 
Since the scale of the polluted water problem is logarithmic (meaing that pollution has many add-on effects when left in water, creating a 2x, 3x, 5x and beyond negative effect on the environment and our health), we have used a logarithmic scale for funding levels too. We are serious about creating change, and wouldn't be soliciting outside funding if we had it ourselves!!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute today, consider us again tomorrow or next month! In the meantime, we would be eternally grateful if you would share our link with your friends, family, and colleagues!
 
Unsolicited advice, help, and participation is always welcome (although we always have the right to turn you down).

story:
The Bay of Fundy Experience Centre (BoFEx) is a Canadian federally-registered charity and broad based community organization established in 2011. Our express purpose is to develop a Centre where visitors can experience the marine phenomena unique to the Bay of Fundy - home to the world's highest tides and 12 species of whales! And as an innovation showcase for Fundy-based industries and a renewable energy centre of excellence.

  • The Bay of Fundy- one of North America’s 2 finalists and Canada’s #1 in the recent “New 7 Wonders of Nature".
  • This geographic phenomenon provides an experience like no other & is the economic backbone for a host of industries.
  • Our region needs this educational centre to showcase the Bay of Fundy's unique phenomena and to help develop and promote its associated industries. It will be an important factor in the growth of our region's economy.  
  • Contributions will be used for marketing, such as a state of the art film that presents and explains the Bay of Fundy. The film will take viewers on a journey over, into and under the Bay of Fundy to discover how the tides work, the importance and abundance of marine life here, as well as the industries and lifestyles that are active along this coastline...what a sense of wonder and discovery!  This film will be utilized to attract corporate and other support. It may also provide the basis for the immersive multimedia experience to be presented in the BoFEx Centre upon its opening. 

This is just the beginning…. join us on this “whale of an adventure” on the Bay of Fundy!  Please support our efforts to build the BoFEx Centre to let the world visit & experience this great and unique natural resource. 

  • Our goal initially is to raise awareness and financial support of at least $150,000 for marketing (film production) and to attract additional support.
  • The total BoFEx Centre costs will be $9.5 million at a minimum. 
  • Your perks will be as unique as the Fundy! How about an authentic Fundy scallop shell "gift pack"? Dulse for flavourful gourmet cooking? Fundy tours? Harbourfront accommodations? Genuine Fundy scallop shell luxury jewellery? Or the ultimate in Fundy authenticity - a custom at-sea experience aboard a genuine lobster vessel! And our most generous supporters can design their own luxury Fundy perk!  All perk level prices include delivery costs.

Be sure to visit our website at www.bofex.ca for more details. You can read excerpts from a recent feasibility study on the BoFEx project, view our charity status document, learn some Fundy Fun Facts and enjoy some great Fundy photos. Get ready for the ride of your life!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our Fundy Experience story with your networks! We know there are many Fundy Fans out there; we need your help to reach them.
  • Be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
Update - June 18, 2013


So, this is what the grocery store would look like without bees. Hope y'all like oranges because if Colony Collapse Disorder keeps going we may find ourselves short of a lot of the produce we are used to seeing.

But don't worry yet, because I'm getting bees, and they're going to help! They aren't hatched yet, but hopefully they will be ready to come this weekend! I don't think I'll get much money this year, but they may winter better than Spring-started hives so that's a good thing.

Anyway, we're getting really close to the end of this campaign, so if you're going to send a few bucks to help get these hives up and running, please to be doing so now. Please also share this with your friends & family and put in a good word for me. I got a TON of flowers around here, waiting for bees!

I've made a nice little $3 perk for y'all. I'm going to section off the last few feet of lawn before the woods start for flowers that I'll just plant right into the lawn. Tulips, lupins, etc etc. Less for us to mow, and some good chow for the bees. For every $3, I shall plant and extra seed or plant!

Update - June 10, 2013

Wow! 2/3 of the way there. Crazy! A HUGE thanks to everyone who has contributed. We aren't 100% there, but close enough that I am proud to say that it's officially on! I am meeting with the kind and helpful Debbie (http://www.debbeesbees.ca/) as early as this weekend to pick up two hives, bees and supplies. Will keep y'all posted!

I also wanted to show you this tree:

The flowers have already fallen off this year but it's a testament to how well my area supports bees. When it is in full flower, you can stand under it and just hear droning. In 2014, the local bumblebees will have to share this tree with the honey bees. Maybe I'll plant another!

Update - June 6, 2013

An AWESOME day and AWESOME people yesterday meant that we've reached 30% of our goal. In one day! Which is amazing, but still a ways to go!

Did you know that a honeybee will produce only 1/12th of a teaspoon of honey in its lifetime? As the honeybees collaborate to make pounds and pounds of honey each year, so must we collaborate to pull off this beehive project! A wee little contribution is worth knowing you're doing good for the world, and sleeping well because I'm the one risking getting stung, isn't it?

So please, please do me a favour - whether you have, plan to, or don't plan to contribute, please share this link because it doesn't take that many one or five or ten dollar contributions to add up to a hive.

Disappearing bees!

Yikes. With 1/3 of our food existing thanks to pollinators, it’s no wonder we are alarmed – and with good reason. The numbers have been dropping since the 1940s despite the fact that the number of actual hives has grown.

Ontario alone experienced a 7% loss in honeybee populations 2012, which is low compared to reported losses as high as 70% in other parts of the world.

The cause is not confirmed but fingers point at a class of pesticides known as neonicotinoids, widely used on corn, which is widely cultivated everywhere.

What can we do?

Europe recently introduced a ban on neonicotinoids and Ontario beekeepers and environmentalists are calling for a similar ban here in Canada. We think it is just a matter of time until neonicotinoid use is restricted or banned, but in the meantime, we have to take care of our bees as best we can.

In Ontario, there are 4000 hobbyists and 250 professional beekeepers. Join us in strengthening our local environment, raising awareness and maintaining honeybee populations by installing two hives on our homestead in Vars near Ottawa, Ontario. We are well situated in a forested / agricultural area, far from cornfields.

What we need:

The initial cost of approximately $550 for a single hive includes

  • the hive box
  • frames (for the bees to build comb to store honey)
  • a smoker
  • a hat and veil
  • a variety of tools necessary to maintaining the hive
  • the bees, of course!

An additional $450 will go toward a second hive, further strengthening the bee population. Any additional funds raised will go toward honey harvesting supplies, additional layers for the hive (allows for a larger population), and supporting local advocacy groups and hobbyists.

Bonus:

You know what makes hard work and occasional stings a lot more bearable? Honey. Honey is amazing – as a sweetener, it is much better for you than refined sugar or no-calorie substitutes. It keeps forever. Slather it on a cut to stave off infection. Makes your skin and hair feel awesome when applied directly. Reduces sore throat and cough.

It may shock you to find out that the stuff you get in the grocery store may not, in fact, be pure, straight-up honey. It could be cut with as much as 49% high fructose corn syrup.

So by supporting local beekeepers you are also supporting local honey. And if you support us, you may get some local honey of your own!

A note on perks:

Obviously, we can’t guarantee how much the bees will produce. We will do our best to fulfill the perks in 2013, but some of them may be pushed over in 2014.

There are currently only three sponsorship perks available. If we raise enough to start a second hive, three more sponsorship perks will be made available and they will be allotted to anyone who may have already invested the amounts in question before being made available to subsequent sponsors. So if you want a sponsorship slot but there isn't one currently available, please contribute anyway, because the contribution you hold back might be enough to push us into a second hive!

So if you want a sponsorship slot but there isn't one currently available, please contribute anyway, because the contribution you hold back might be enough to push us into a second hive!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Kissime Shred, I'm a 19-year-old wheelchair bound girl from Arizona on SSI. I have Muscular Dystrophy, I've been in a wheelchair all of my life. I live with my parents, my sister and her fiance. My dad works 3 jobs, and he always does his best to provide for my family. I've always tried to apply to as many jobs as I can, but I've recently decided to go back to high school after dropping out 3 times and feel that I cannot balance that and a job due to my depression and social anxiety. We are backed up on our bills, in extreme debt and sometimes go a week or 2 living on eggs, bread and lunch meat. Any kind of donation would be much appreciated, I know that there are people out there with less than I but, if you're feeling generous, my family and I would really appreciate your support!


** I WILL ALSO DONATE 20% OF MY EARNINGS TO THE MUSCULAR DYSTROPHY ASSOCIATION WHERE IT WILL GO TOWARDS RESEARCH AND SENDING KIDS WITH MD TO CAMP! **

What We Need & What You Get

We don't ultimately have to reach my goal, as any kind of money helps

Anyone who donates and is willing to give me their address/email, I will write a personalized thank you card and express my extreme gratitude. I can't do much else, but I assure that the money will be used for necessities. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you cannot donate, I definitely understand that, as most people around the world are struggling with money. Just by sharing this, you can help out!

story:
What is PowerShift

PowerShift is been a one-of-kind, transformative organizing project growing in Canada. 

Launched in 2009 as a national youth-led climate change summit, PowerShift today is much more - it is a catalyst for energizing and empowering new momentum organizing for climate justice. 

In 2013, PowerShift BC launched a new phase of organizing kicking off a plan to hold 6 PowerShifts across Canada in the next 2 years. PowerShift is driving new energy into the climate movement in Canada, empowering youth to take action, like in the burgeoning Fossil Free Canada Divestment campaign. 

So far we have brought together and trained thousands of young people, and in 2014 we want to make that even more to support movement building piece by piece. 

What We Need

With rising ambitions to bring regional PowerShifts across Canada, so too comes a rising need for resources. This year we want to try and put on 2 regional PowerShifts, in Halifax in March and then another PowerShift in the fall. Each PowerShift costs upwards of $100,000 to bring speakers, rent space, provide scholarships and more, and your support for this campaign will help make this happen. 

The Impact

Regional PowerShifts are striving towards training, connecting and empowering 10,000 young people across Canada to take action for a just and sustainable future. PowerShift alumni are already taking action in a range of ways from fossil fuel divestment campaigns to local organizing action to stop fracking and tar sands, to organizing high school students and more. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute?

  • Help share this video and spread the word!

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
What is the idea:

Hello, my name is Richard. Me and my dog Bruce are on a mission to build a self-recharging electric bike using recycled parts so that we can continue to enjoy cycling despite my ageing knees, and give something back too.

  • Stage 1 - is complete... I am now ready to build the proof of concept after having done extensive research and planning
  • Stage 2 – I need donations of funds or materials to build the prototype
  • Stage 3 – I will then take the bike on a roadshow around the UK to educate others at Eco events and festivals about how to build one for yourselves.

Benefits to me:

  • Saves my ageing and injured knees by giving power assistance when needed
  • Allows me to continue my love of cycling and exploring the country with my dog
  • Won't need to drive or waste planetary or monetary resources on a car

This isn't just about me:

  • It can aid cycling for longer periods than the average 3 hours from current electric bikes
  • The battery is self-charging whilst on the move, and trickle charges when stationary.
  • It uses road vibration piezoelectric hybrid batteries of my design, and supercapacitors built from low-toxicity materials
  • The technology could be developed for other sustainable energy projects

What you'll get in return for helping me:

  • £5 - email updates on progress of build
  • £25 - E-postcards from Bruce on the first year of our travels
  • £50 - Detailed e-book guide and video on how to build one for yourself... After the prototype has been completed and tested

How the money will be spent:

  • Appropriate recycled bike frame/wheels £100
  • Re-used drive motor £50-100
  • Non-toxic materials for the hybrid batteries and supercapacitors £200
  • Magnesium anodes x12 £80
  • Copper and stainless sheets x10 £50
  • Recycled tools and equipment (ones I don't have already) £50-100
  • Used basic oscilloscope £30
  • Other parts/supplies £100
  • Fabrication as I can't do welding £100
  • Wi-fi hardware/solar panel/related equipment for roadshow demonstrations £150

Any extra funds will be invested in the running of the roadshow events and further research into green re-use technologies.

How you can get involved:

  • Donations... However small will all help
  • Donate recycled parts or materials as listed above
  • Let me know suggestions for events for the roadshow
  • Please use the share options and spread the word

The concept: My friend recommended I explain the concept more clearly, so heres the science bit; the generating batterys use an outer spiral-wound copper cathode and a solid magnesium anode in a dry electrolyte housed in a flexible PVC tube, this creates low amperage power when resting that is stored in the embedded capacitors (in the dry alkaline electrolyte), also embedded in the sodium/alum mix are aligned peizoelectric potassium dihydrogen phosphate crystals (home grown) that give voltage pulses as vibrations and impacts are encountered riding which are smoothed and stored in the capacitors. A simple solar charge controller then uses this store to replenish the main batteries that are a hybridised copper/stainless mesh lightweight cell using pva gel alum electrolyte for safety and environmental security. Lithium is not safe for the user or the planet so we need solutions that benefit everybody, not just mining corporations and power companies; an off-grid e-bike.

Together we can help save knees all over the planet, and give Bruce a tow!

story:
Our Mission

Hi, we're a team of passionate conservationists, paddleboarders and surfers. We're combining these passions and making a record breaking 1000km paddle along the length of Panama to raise funds and awareness of conservation issues affecting Panama. We’re also collecting our own ecological data as we go in the hope that this will contribute to environmental protection of the areas we're exploring and the unique species they contain. Our aims are to:

  • Set a new long distance world record for prone paddleboarding, not a small feat for a three thousand year old sport! And discover unridden surf spots along the way.

  • Search for undiscovered populations of Antillean manatee, Trichechus manatus ssp. manatus (yes I did mean to write manatus twice!) as we go.

  • Determine the status of and hopefully thereafter take the first photos of a critically endangered Salamander, Oedipina maritima endemic to Isla Escudo de Veraguas.

  • To record this journey sharing with the world images of a seldom visited and largely unexplored coastline.
  • To fundraise as we travel for the environmental charity Seacology who run human-environment linked conservation projects in coastal Panama. www.seacology.com


The Impact

Through the adventure we hope to positively engage the public with conservation action not just in Panama but in the wider context of acknowledging our social responsibility to preserve these places of exquisite beauty and intrigue for future generations to enjoy. This is more important today than ever.

We sincerely hope that in part as a consequence of the data we collect greater environmental protection can be attributed to this land while it is wild and before commercial or other human interests compete with conservation and species preservation. This pre-emptive action for conservation can be particularly effective.


Here are a few Manatee, affectionately known to many as sea cows. At up to 13 feet long and weighing 590kg you would think we couldn't miss them. They're an endangered species of herbivore that would you believe are thought to have given rise to the mermaid myth. They exclusively inhabit the Caribbean seaboard and fewer than 2,500 mature individuals remain in the wild and this number is decreasing.


What We Need & What You Get

We've invested all the funds we have into launching this expedition and now we need you to help get us on the starting line before the wet season begins and scuppers our chances of finding these manatee. We're also looking to record our experiences for a documentary, with our capacity to do this dependent on how successful this campaign is.

Where are we short:

  • Cash to pay for local support vessels, particularly vital as we cannot explore unchartered rivers for manatee without them. And for the latter stages of our trip as we island hop home through the Perlas Archipelago during the Humpback whale migration. For this we would also like to pay for a cameraman. 
  • Money to purchase documentary equipment, EOS 60D, GoPro's, slider, tripod, audio.We'd love to do this justice and record the journey on the equipment that is suited to the adventure rather than that which we can gather.
  • A reservoir of funds to pay for unforeseen charges, import fees, park access and film fees and later funds for editing our footage.


What do I win I hear you say?

Well the great thing is, we're offering you some incredible original perks in return for your support, including the WORLD'S FIRST ever photographs of Oedipina maritima (fingers crossed for this one!), the chance to NAME YOUR VERY OWN SURF SPOT: we'll even send you the GPS co-ordinates to your PRIVATE SURF PARADISE and maybe one day you'll get to go, exclusive early access to a bank of images of a coastline that produces zero accurate hits on a google image search, a chance to grafitti a message onto our expedition boards: I love you Barbara, good luck, paddle harder, this kind of thing, and a sneak preview of our documentary to boot!



Other Ways You Can Help

Share, share, share our page. The more people who know about the trip, the more successful it will be in terms of the conservation objectives we're trying to achieve. And a successful campaign means that the work we're doing has the greatest chance of success.

So please make some noise and share, here: using Indiegogo sharing tools, there: to schools who might like to follow our progress, clubs, communities and everywhere. Nature thanks you for it.

Kind Regards,


Arron, Rob, Max
