story:
I'm Paul Epstein, retired teacher, lifelong musician, songwriter, writer, and environmental activist. While $4,000 would have paid in full for our first event, the money raised in this campaign was a good start toward a successful fundraiser. We're on track to raise significant funds. To purchase you ticket or donate to AWARE, go to awarewv.org


My rewrite of the chorus to Woody Guthrie's, This Land is Your Land, which I've been singing at rallies goes like this:

"Our Mountain Mama, they've spoiled your waters,

Cut down your mountains, it's a true slaughter,

But we will rise up and stand together, saving

This land will be our legacy."

Here I am singing it at Kentucky's I Love Mountain Day.


I've made it my mission to raise money for the WV Environmental Council, the almost 50 member groups it represents and other environmental groups in West Virginia. As founder and director of AWARE, I need your help to restore West Virginia, and if we're successful, the region and the country.

The purpose of AWARE is to get people (our definition of Artists is anyone in any artistic discipline or who 'lives life artfully') working together in creative ways to raise funds to restore WV to Almost Heaven

  • In West Virginia, coal is king: politicians have been afraid for decades to say a word about strip mining, which in recent years has reached such a massive scale, it is called Mountain Top Removal -- they blast away mountains and fill up the valleys and have covered up thousands of miles of mountain streams, destroying communities, their natural springs and wells, and cause high rates of cancer and other illnesses including drug addiction from hopelessness.
  • Huge gas wells are being drilled using hydraulic fracturing (fracking). Landowners are seeing their beautiful rural landscapes destroyed and their water contaminated. Poorly regulated methane releases are reported to be offsetting any benefits of the reduction of coal burning from competition.
  • Poorly managed runoff from factory sized chicken and pig farms in eastern WV are polluting watersheds including the Chesapeake Bay.
  • A recent coal industry chemical spill into the Elk River near Charleston contaminated the water of 300,000 customers of the private water company which supplies water to 9 counties. The WV Department of Environmental Protection was exposed for its lax enforcement of regulations. Many are still afraid to use their water.

Help us raise AWAREness and raise money to

help fund Environmental Groups 

in West Virginia!

There are many folks inside and outside West Virginia who are willing to donate time and talent to produce events that can bring out people receptive to the message of environmental organizations. The $4,000 we raise together in this campaign will cover start-up costs and our first fundraising event so we can raise the needed money for those hard working folks who are on the ground working every day to hold the WV DEP to account, to file lawsuits protecting our mountains, streams, air, and communities, to lobby for stronger environmental laws, and to create parks and protect forests. 

AWARE will give all supporters and contributors a voice--a vote in deciding which organizations get the money we raise.

  • If you can't donate money, perhaps you can help us find others who can donate, spread the word, sell tickets, volunteer in some way, donate art for us to sell....the possibilities are endless. 
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools, Facebook, Twitter, whatever you can to get the word out. If we raise more than we need to produce the concert, additional funds will be given to environmental orgs or used to produce our next event!

story:
We are a team of adventurers, filmmakers, and writers committed to keeping Patagonia wild. The region’s two major rivers, the Baker and the Pascua are threatened. Chilean-European conglomerate HidroAysén has proposed 5 major dams that would fragment and permanently degrade the diverse, enigmatic ecosystems of Patagonia. And, the environmental travesty wouldn't end there. The proposal also involves building the world’s longest transmission line, one that would lacerate the country, cutting across private lands, wilderness areas, and the Chilean equivalent of national parks. So we took action, and since 2010 we’ve been documenting the stunning beauty of pristine Patagonia, developing inspirational films and media and tipping the scales in favor of conservation. With 74% of Chileans now expressing opposition to the dams, we are continuing to raise awareness and show support so that we can finish this fight to protect Patagonia's untouched lands. 

OUR FILMS

‘Power in the Pristine,’ our first film came out in 2010 chronicles the journey of team Rios Libres, led by athlete Timmy O’Neill and writer Craig Childs, on an adventure tracing the Rio Baker from source to sea. Immersed in the remote culture of Chilean Patagonia, we were able to film compelling interviews with the people who are directly threatened by the proposal. LINK

‘Streams of Consequence,’ our second film was released in January of 2013. In April of the previous year, co-founder James Q Martin ('Q') traveled south once again and landed  in the midst of massive anti-dam protests. He captured outstanding footage of the protests, spending nine weeks traveling the length of the country talking to gauchos, scientists, activists and the public in search of answers. The result was ‘Streams of Consequence’- a solution-based film that addresses the hard questions: “What does an alternative energy model look like?” and “Could Chile become a global leader by gaining energy independence via green technology?” LINK

‘Rios Libres - Environmental Dispatches’ A short video series that highlights four different aspects of the fight against five proposed dams in Chile’s Patagonia region. In partnership with National Geographic, NRDC, and International Rivers.


Episode 2  //  Episode 3  //  Episode 4


The Issue

If allowed to proceed this catastrophic project would involve:

  •  Two dams on the Rio Baker, Chile’s longest and highest flowing river
  •  Three dams on the Rio Pascua, Chile’s third highest flowing river.
  •  Clear-cutting 1,600 km (1000 mi) of old-growth forest
  •  Building the longest transmission line in the world, over 2,450 km (1,500 mi)

Why It Matters

Chilean Patagonia is a remote region of the world where nature, long left to its own devices grows wild, beautiful and largely untouched by man.  As South America’s last frontier, the region boasts incredible biodiversity, breathtaking landscapes, and a remote solitude that is increasingly rare in our burgeoning world.  Dappled with pristine lakes, jagged peaks, ancient glaciers, rushing rivers, coastal rainforests and dry grasslands, the area’s diversity is striking and its magnificence unmatched. The protection of this global treasure is an issue that transcends national boundaries, and as citizens of an increasingly globalized community we have a responsibility to show our support for the people of Chile in their fight to protect Patagonia The project proposed by HidroAysén would irrevocably damage this entire region. Chile is a country rich in natural resources, and renewable energy alternatives. This is an opportunity for Chile to stand as a global leader in responsible energy, if we help the people win the fight.


Why We Must Act NOW

In the last few months there have been a lot of major updates surrounding the campaign. Chile’s current president, Sebastian Piñera, who is notorious for his support of the dams is nearing the end of his term. Although it seems Piñera has been distancing himself from HidroAysén, his administration has been trying to fast track two laws, coined ‘las leyes de HidroAysén' (laws of HidroAysén). These laws would provide a legal loophole to approve the construction of the world’s longest transmission line. The dams have already been approved, but the transmission line has not yet been approved. If these laws pass, the project would be able to move forward and the construction of the dams would begin. We must act now to prevent this from happening.

photo by james q martin

Rios Libres: Continuing to Fight 

In 2014, we aim to broaden our international outreach by bringing our films on tour throughout Chile. The film tour will raise awareness and will serve as a platform to host thought-provoking, solution-based discussions that include local experts from each region we visit. We intend to empower people to take action by showing support for the existing Chilean effort and by helping people realize that Chile can act as a global leader in responsible energy development. We hope to demonstrate that they are not alone in the fight to protect these precious rivers.

In addition to the film tour, we will be collaborating with Patagonia Inc-sponsored trail runners Krissy Moehl and Luke Nelson to execute an ultra-run from source to sea along the Baker River. The run, which will be completed by late February 2014, will serve as means to document the audacious beauty of the Baker River, from its glacial origins to the place where it meets the sea.

But we can’t do all of this without your help! 



Donate!

Your generous donations will be rewarded with good karma, our undying gratitude, a shout-out on our website, and not to mention some super-cool prizes.


Spread the word!

Raising awareness is a critical component of our overall mission, and a convenient way that you can be tremendously helpful. Tell your friends and family. 'Like' us on Facebook, follow us on twitter and instagram and encourage your friends to do the same.
story_txt:
We are a team of adventurers, filmmakers, and writers committed to keeping Patagonia wild. The region’s two major rivers, the Baker and the Pascua are threatened. Chilean-European conglomerate HidroAysén has proposed 5 major dams that would fragment and permanently degrade the diverse, enigmatic ecosystems of Patagonia. And, the environmental travesty wouldn't end there. The proposal also involves building the world’s longest transmission line, one that would lacerate the country, cutting across private lands, wilderness areas, and the Chilean equivalent of national parks. So we took action, and since 2010 we’ve been documenting the stunning beauty of pristine Patagonia, developing inspirational films and media and tipping the scales in favor of conservation. With 74% of Chileans now expressing opposition to the dams, we are continuing to raise awareness and show support so that we can finish this fight to protect Patagonia's untouched lands. 
OUR FILMS


‘Power in the Pristine,’ our first film came out in 2010 chronicles the journey of team Rios Libres, led by athlete Timmy O’Neill and writer Craig Childs, on an adventure tracing the Rio Baker from source to sea. Immersed in the remote culture of Chilean Patagonia, we were able to film compelling interviews with the people who are directly threatened by the proposal. LINK
‘Streams of Consequence,’ our second film was released in January of 2013. In April of the previous year, co-founder James Q Martin ('Q') traveled south once again and landed  in the midst of massive anti-dam protests. He captured outstanding footage of the protests, spending nine weeks traveling the length of the country talking to gauchos, scientists, activists and the public in search of answers. The result was ‘Streams of Consequence’- a solution-based film that addresses the hard questions: “What does an alternative energy model look like?” and “Could Chile become a global leader by gaining energy independence via green technology?” LINK
‘Rios Libres - Environmental Dispatches’ A short video series that highlights four different aspects of the fight against five proposed dams in Chile’s Patagonia region. In partnership with National Geographic, NRDC, and International Rivers.

Episode 2  //  Episode 3  //  Episode 4

The Issue
If allowed to proceed this catastrophic project would involve:



 Two dams on the Rio Baker, Chile’s longest and highest flowing river


 Three dams on the Rio Pascua, Chile’s third highest flowing river.


 Clear-cutting 1,600 km (1000 mi) of old-growth forest

 Building the longest transmission line in the world, over 2,450 km (1,500 mi)

Why It Matters
Chilean Patagonia is a remote region of the world where nature, long left to its own devices grows wild, beautiful and largely untouched by man.  As South America’s last frontier, the region boasts incredible biodiversity, breathtaking landscapes, and a remote solitude that is increasingly rare in our burgeoning world.  Dappled with pristine lakes, jagged peaks, ancient glaciers, rushing rivers, coastal rainforests and dry grasslands, the area’s diversity is striking and its magnificence unmatched. The protection of this global treasure is an issue that transcends national boundaries, and as citizens of an increasingly globalized community we have a responsibility to show our support for the people of Chile in their fight to protect Patagonia The project proposed by HidroAysén would irrevocably damage this entire region. Chile is a country rich in natural resources, and renewable energy alternatives. This is an opportunity for Chile to stand as a global leader in responsible energy, if we help the people win the fight.
Why We Must Act NOW
In the last few months there have been a lot of major updates surrounding the campaign. Chile’s current president, Sebastian Piñera, who is notorious for his support of the dams is nearing the end of his term. Although it seems Piñera has been distancing himself from HidroAysén, his administration has been trying to fast track two laws, coined ‘las leyes de HidroAysén' (laws of HidroAysén). These laws would provide a legal loophole to approve the construction of the world’s longest transmission line. The dams have already been approved, but the transmission line has not yet been approved. If these laws pass, the project would be able to move forward and the construction of the dams would begin. We must act now to prevent this from happening.
photo by james q martinRios Libres: Continuing to Fight 


In 2014, we aim to broaden our international outreach by bringing our films on tour throughout Chile. The film tour will raise awareness and will serve as a platform to host thought-provoking, solution-based discussions that include local experts from each region we visit. We intend to empower people to take action by showing support for the existing Chilean effort and by helping people realize that Chile can act as a global leader in responsible energy development. We hope to demonstrate that they are not alone in the fight to protect these precious rivers.


In addition to the film tour,
we will be collaborating with Patagonia Inc-sponsored trail runners Krissy
Moehl and Luke Nelson to execute an ultra-run from source to sea along the
Baker River. The run, which will be completed by late February 2014, will serve
as means to document the audacious beauty of the Baker River, from its glacial
origins to the place where it meets the sea.
But we can’t do all of this
without your help! 
Donate! Your generous donations will be rewarded with good karma, our undying gratitude, a shout-out on our website, and not to mention some super-cool prizes.Spread the word! Raising awareness is a critical component of our overall mission, and a convenient way that you can be tremendously helpful. Tell your friends and family. 'Like' us on Facebook, follow us on twitter and instagram and encourage your friends to do the same.

story:
THE CAMPAIGN

We are a group of Ugandan and Israeli scientists and Ugandan community leaders committed to enhancing food security in the Putti Village region of Eastern Uganda.  

We would like to build a model farm together with local and Israeli agricultural scientists in order to support small holding farmers in the village and the surrounding areas and explore sustainable and efficient agricultural methods.

With your support, this is a very achievable goal!

Unfortunately, the current state of fields used for agriculture is insufficient to support both subsistence and commercial farming. Tragically, many children, pregnant women and other vulnerable community residents suffer from insufficient access to food during parts of the year. This is partly a function of the crops grown and the lack of proper irrigation systems to store water from the rainy season.

The pilot project will address one crucial challenge: how to improve irrigation systems so as to provide year round access to water to grow essential vegetables, so children and adults do not suffer from a lack of food security during the dry season.

The group has been put together by Tarphon, a Jewish community leader who recently came to Israel with the help of Rabbi Riskin (Chief Rabbi of Efrat and Chancellor of the Ohr Torah Stone Organization) to study and forge stronger connections with Israel and the Jewish World.  

We hope to share this knowledge and experience with communities in the Putti Village region, which includes Muslims and Christian communities.   We hope this project will become a model for Jewish, Christian, and Muslim inter-faith cooperation. 

A video of Tarphon and the local agronomist Johnbosco Birenge explaining the purpose of the project can be found below. The video has captions, which can be accessed at the bottom of the video screen, the third icon from the right. 



THE JEWISH COMMUNITY OF UGANDA

For nearly a century, a small group of Ugandans have been practising Judaism. These are the descendants and followers of Semei Kakungulu, a charismatic political leader, who broke from the Christian church and began adhering to the Old Testament.  The community is called Abaydaya, which means ‘People of Judah’.  

We encourage you to learn more about their inspiring history and read about how this isolated community suffered under Idi Amin’s forced conversions but ultimately found their way back to Judaism and rebuild the community following Amin’s devastating reign.

The Jewish Virtual Library and the Be’chol Lashon organistion are excellent starting points.

Despite their difficult history today this is a strong, proud and happy community. We encourage you to watch the video of Rabbi Gershom who is the spiritual leader and learn more about this unique community:



And the community having some fun!



OUR GOAL

The goal of this campaign is simple: we aim to raise the funds necessary to build a model farm to help local farmers improve their agricultural techniques and discover solutions to some local challenges.

Together we can achieve this goal - we are looking to raise the modest amount of $10,000 to start financing the pilot project.  The entire project will cost approximately $120,000 over the course of 4 years, but we need the $10,000 to get started by sending Myron Sofer to Uganda to see the reality on the ground and start on construction.  We hope to get the rest of the money through grants once we have kickstarted the project.

Farmers in the region face unique agricultural challenges and a program must be calibrated to fully and sensitively meet local needs and circumstances to ensure viability and sustainability of the project. Local and Israeli agricultural scientists will use funds from this campaign to teach the small holding farmers in the village and the surrounding areas more about sustainable and efficient agricultural methods suited to the region. Improved irrigation systems and techniques are key to this approach.

The pilot project will look to improve crop production and irrigation techniques so farmers will be able to store water from the rainy season and water vegetables during the dry seasons, improving their overall yields.


THE IMPACT

Working with international experts, we expect to raise the standard of living by lessening some of the economic hardships that farmers in the area currently face. We expect that enhanced food security for the community will be a direct benefit.

But it’s important to consider just how broad the impact of this campaign, and your contribution, can be. We anticipate that other areas of communal life will benefit as greater access to food leads to improved health and improved farming techniques lead to higher standards of living. In particular, improved irrigation techniques will enable those particularly vulnerable, such as children and pregnant women, to eat healthy year round, and will significantly alleviate the suffering currently endured during dry seasons.

Moreover, this pilot project may have been formed with the direct involvement of Jewish community leadership, but the goal is to share the knowledge and experience with the surrounding communities as well. The communities around the Putti Village include Jews, Muslims, and Christians.  

This project has the potential to become a shining example of Jewish, Christian and Muslim cooperation. 

OTHER WAYS TO BE INVOLVED

The $10,000 raised will be used to finance the pilot project and this is an important part of the support necessary to improve the health and wellbeing of the Putti Village Region.

But there are other ways to be involved as well! We look forward to hearing from people interested in sharing their knowledge, expertise and passion. Please get in touch. Some of the skill sets that could help make this project a success, include:  grant writing, agriculture, environment, Africa, Jewish studies, or fundraising!


If you have any questions, please feel free to contact Moshe Halpern (moshehalpern416@hotmail.com), Tarphon (tarphon7days@yahoo.com), Aviva Feifer (afeifer@gmail.com) or Myron Sofer (myronsofer@gmail.com)

story:
Truth About Tar Sands Oil 

and 

the Keystone XL Pipeline

News Flash: 

On July 28 a Washington-based Journalism group offered to match the next $3,000 in donations. (Read press release.) By one week later, we'd earned the entire matching gift.

 Our Project

We are Alex MacLean, an aerial photographer and Dan Grossman, a science journalist. We're experienced environmental journalists, teamed up to offer images, descriptions and research on the pollution of rural Alberta by big oil's tar-sands development.

     You probably have heard that the proposed Keystone XL pipeline would carry almost a million barrels a day of oil from Alberta to refineries in the US, just when—because of global warming—we should be cutting back on carbon fuel consumption. Environmentalists want to stop the project and slow use of the fossil fuels, especially more carbon-intensive ones like tar sands.  The local and regional effects of mining Alberta's tar sands deposits are less well known. 

     Mining companies are disturbing vast tracts of Alberta's virgin forests and peat bogs in their rush to turn a swamp of gooey subterranean oil into billions of petri dollars—never mind the thousands of tons of carbon waste they're putting in the atmosphere and millions of tons of toxic industrial waste they're leaving on the ground. Whether or not the XL Pipeline is approved, energy companies say they're determined to export  tar sands oil to the US and elsewhere on an incredible scale.  

     Help us tell the truth about tar sands oil. Help us tell the stories of stories of people like Kevin Marcel, a Native American in village of Fort Chipewayan. As an employee  in tar sands mines, Kevin digs up the forests and marshes where he once hunted and fished (see video below).

                   

     We spent a week in Alberta last April, in collaboration with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting, GlobalPost and the GroundTruth Project. Our preliminary photos and writing have now come out in GlobalPost, the Huffington Post, Fast Company Co.Exist and the DeSmog Canada, among other online publications. We've received tens of thousands of "likes," and thousands of "retweets"—many people are using our materials to spread the word.

     Our work is not complete and we need your help. We're doing further documentation by reporting again and taking more photographs in Alberta, in September. Here's why: What aerial photos reveal depends on the season. Spring snows on our prior reporting trip helped us put on public display the astounding private network of clear cuts made in advance of future mines. Stack gases stood out in April's cool temperatures

     If we can photograph the same land with leaves on the trees and vegetation on the  ground, we'll have a powerful side-by side demonstration of intact as well as cleared  forest. We also will spend more time on the ground, reporting about ailing wildlife, broken indigenous communities. We'll meet more indigenous people, like Alice Rigney a Fort Chipewayan elder of the Dene band (see video below).


     We'll learn more about the scientific research now underway on tar sands impacts. We'll meet more people like Doctor John O'Connor, who discovered an unusual cluster of a rare cancer of the bile duct downstream of the tar sands mines (see video below).

     With your help, still more people will learn the truth about how close to you is tar sand development in far-off Alberta. You can help to preserve Alberta's forests and wildlife, and the lifestyle of indigenous people under siege by mining companies. Our work in Alberta documenting the local and regional effects of tar sands oil, could slow fossil fuel production, which scientists say must be stopped to avoid catastrophic climate change.

     It costs about $250 an hour to rent a plane in Alberta. Accommodations in the tar sands capital, Fort McMurray, are expensive. Your donation will help us go on with our project. Hundreds of thousands of people have already seen our photos and read our posts. With your help even more will learn about the destructiveness of tar sands oil development, both locally and on the global scale.

Fine Print

Who are Alex and Dan?

Alex MacLean

     Pilot and photographer Alex MacLean has flown his plane over much of the United States documenting the landscape.  Trained as an architect, he has portrayed the history and evolution of the land from vast agricultural patterns to city grids, recording changes brought about by human intervention and natural processes.  His powerful and descriptive images provide clues to understanding the relationship between the natural and constructed environments.  MacLean’s photographs have been exhibited widely in the United States, Canada, Europe and Asia and are found in private, public and university collections. He has won numerous awards, including the 2009 CORINE International Book Award, the American Academy of Rome’s Prix de Rome in Landscape Architecture for 2003-2004, and grants from foundations such as the National Endowment for the Arts and Graham Foundation. MacLean is the author of eleven books.

Daniel Grossman

     Daniel Grossman has been a print journalist and radio and web producer for 25 years. He has reported from all seven continents including from near both the south and north poles. He holds a Ph.D. in political science and a B.S. in physics, both from MIT. He is a Contributing Editor of National Geographic’s News Watch and contributes frequently to PRI’s program The World. He was has been awarded a Ted Scripps Fellowship in Environmental Journalism and an Alicia Patterson Foundation Fellowship. He is author of Deep Water: As Polar Ice Melts, Scientists Debate How High Our Oceans Will Rise, and coauthor of A Scientist’s Guide to Talking with the Media: Practical Advice from the Union of Concerned Scientists.

How will Alex and Dan Use the Material They Collect in Alberta?

Alex and Dan intend to produce a variety of products distributed on several platforms to make sure their work is seen by a large and diverse audience. Their collaborators, the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting and GlobalPost, will help to guarantee the success of these efforts. Global Post has assigned Alex and Dan to write one new illustrated story based on their September trip. Dan will write an interactive ebook compiling his findings from two reporting trips (and, possibly, from additional reporting on tar sands transport and processing in the US), illustrated with Alex's photos. Alex and Dan anticipate that they will find many other outlets for their work. DeSmog Canada has requested a new set of photos. Alex will be offering free use of his photos for print publications, websites and social media campaigns to non-profits raising awareness of climate change issues. 

What will you get if you donate?

The most important thing you'll get is the possibility of a better planet for you and future generations. We'll also offer donors special online access to our reporting and, depending on the size of the donation, physical products of our work.

How Will Alex and Dan Spend the Money They Raise?

The funds requested are for expenses only, including airfare to Canada, prop-plane rental, auto rental, food and accommodations. If they raise more money than they need to accomplish their mission in Alberta, they will apply the excess funds to a future trip to the Texas Gulf Coast, where they will report on refining of tar sands oil.

What if Alex and Dan Don't Reach Their Goal?

If Alex and Dan do not reach their full goal, they seek supplemental funds from past supporters. If, they are not far from the funding goal they will economize. If, after seeking supplemental funds, they have reached less than half of their goal, they will return donations.

What Else Can You Do, Apart from Donating?

Lots. Tell your friends about Tar Sands Truth. Send them this link to our funding campaign.

story:
THANK YOU TO ALL WHO SUPPORTED US!!!

If you wish to make a donation please donate through our GOFUNDME campaign right here: http://gofundme.com/ka3p7ahc
Checks made out to "The Art Of Healing Foundation" can be mailed to PO Box 1787, Bothell WA 98041
All donations are Tax Deductible
Our website is www.rainbowofbeing.wordpress
Livestream sessions from the Parliament of World's Religions will be available here starting on the 17th of October: http://livestream.com/accounts/3116574
***With Deepest Of Gratitude for you and for all of life***
Devi Tide, Chris Akbar Miller, Mary Lyons, Jessica Bromby, Pershali Ami, Eila Paul, and all of us working on this project. 

Help us bring down-to-earth indigenous wisdom and unconditional love to the Parliament of The World's Religions

Maori, Mayan, Ojibwe, and Hopi elders are coming together to speak to thousands about the simple and necessary wisdom they share.  We link into a divine source and carry a sacred trust with all of life on planet Earth.  With the power of unconditional love, we can heal our one family.

Our Project

Kia'ora te whanau ('Hello dear family' in Maori),

Aanii (Greetings, in Ojibwe),

We are medicine carriers, wisdom bearers, spiritual elders, grandmothers from different indigenous tribes around Papatuanuku our Earth Mother, and we come together now with your blessing in this time of our planet and our humanity's big transition into a global family — to pray, to make ceremony, to listen, to sing, and, throughout all of it, to remind each other that we are one human family, all races, creeds, and ways included; that we are one with the Earth, with her waters, her winds, and her mountains. We, humanity, are caretakers of this planet and its multitude of flying, running, and swimming living creatures, all of whom are our kin.

We were all called to come speak out for future lifetimes across the planet - just as you can yourself.  All of our traditions - Maori, Ojibwe, Hopi, Mayan, Sufi, perhaps yours - express the same sacred truth: that we are one world family.  All of us travel and teach in our own right, but we stop now to come together for the need of us all.

We have been invited to the Parliament Of the World’s Religions, where we have been asked to speak to over ten thousand people of all faiths.  The Parliament has been meeting since 1893 and is the greatest interfaith forum we have to share this message with leaders from around the world.  As the world is now changing rapidly, 2015 is a very auspicious year. 

We have been invited to offer many sessions.  We will hold Healing Services and Ceremonies for the Earth every day.  We will speak in four plenary sessions (the entire Parliament Body) as well as three other scheduled programs, and we will reach thousands.  They want us to present our message.

We need your help.  Our admissions are covered, and partial plane fares.  We need hotel rooms for one week, as we are not young.  We need to eat.  The rest of our airfares need to be covered.  And we need transportation to and from the events.

Devi tells the story of how this journey came about:


Why Are We Doing This?

Our journey of coming together was instigated by Dr. Rangimarie Turuki Rose Pere, Maori Tuhuna (reincarnated spiritual elder), who asked Devi Tide to travel amongst different indigenous tribes of the planet to reach out in oneness for the sake of wisdom, and for the sake of encouraging our coming together in a time when humanity needs all the wisdom it can get.

The Maori have a saying: "Everyone included, no one left behind.”  And that's the message, each of us having our rightful place in life, standing in our own wisdom and power, and as Ojibwe Grandmother Mary Lyons likes to say: "Living in harmony with the 'We'." 

Here's The Point

In many indigenous traditions, there are prophecies of a time of birthing, of a time of awakening in the world. We will all make this transition.  Each person must believe that the small actions they make in harmony with the whole are really making a difference. 

 "We have to do everything that we possibly can to help people remember that they are both celestial and terrestrial beings, and that we are actually one big family. We link directly in with our mother, Earth Mother Papatuanuku, and so for us we embrace all colors, ok? People of all colors and nations –we do not separate anyone. And the other thing that we expect all people to do is to care for all of Earth Mother’s progeny, the best way we possibly can –our kin that swim, our kin that creep and fly –all that."

  -  Dr. Rangimarie Turuki Rose Pere, Maori Tohunga, Invited Major Speaker at the 2015 Parliament of World's Religions

Please help us share this message of remembering our covenant with all of life. 


What We Need

We need the following: 
  • $9,000:  8 Nights of Hotel Rooms for the Grandmothers, near the Parliament
  • $3,500:  8 days of food for the Grandmothers and our group in Salt Lake City (10 people) 
  • $750:     Transportation - a couple of the Grandmothers cannot walk to and          from the Parliament, we are anticipating taxi cab rides, maybe a rental car
  • $5500:  Flights to the Parliament. We have already raised $7,000 in airfare! 
  • $1250: Photography and Documentation of the Parliament
After the Parliament, all the Grandmothers will be covered for the Journey through the Southwest. (You can join us on the trip - 3 spaces are still available on the tour with the Grandmothers for $2950, click here for details.)


Our Gifts To You

  • $5 - Earth Awakening Sticker: A conscious sticker to spread the word and awaken others + Grandmothers will blow you a kiss in thanks
  • $15 - Grandmothers Blow You A Kiss: A digital photo of the Grandmother's blowing you a kiss! (Plus all previous gifts)
  • $25 - Ceremonies For The Earth: Video footage of the Grandmothers' Healing Services For The Earth at the Parliament Of Worlds' Religions, and from the Rainbow Journey through the SW. Offered as a video download link. (Plus all previous gifts)
  • $40 - Hopi Corn:  Corn for the Hopi people is very symbolic - it's sprinkled during prayers and ceremonies, an ear of corn is given to a newborn and planted to symbolize the continuity of life and of continuing the planting. These corn kernels were gathered on Hopi lands for you to have on your altar or for your own prayers and ceremonies. Write-up of the Hopi meaning of corn and the continuity of life included. (Plus all previous gifts) 
  • $60 - Blessed Waters: This small vial of sacred waters will be blessed at the Healing Service For The Earth at the Parliament of Worlds Religions by all the grandmothers and Ojibwe Waterkeeper Grandmother Mary Lyons. Comes with a prayer in Ojibwa to bless all waters. (plus all previous gifts) 
  • $75 - 5x7 Reminder To Awaken: A beautiful 5x7 print that you get to choose from different photos taken on the Rainbow Journey (plus all previous gifts)
  • $85 - Blessed Pounamu NZ Greenstone: This piece of Pounamu (New Zealand Greenstone Jade) will be blessed by Maori Grandmother Eila Paul for you, as a connection to our journeys. Pounamu is a stone of the wairua, the world of the spirit realm that surrounds all. Pounamu is traditionally only received as a gift - we give this gift to you with Aroha - divine love. (Plus all previous gifts) 
  • $100 - Grandmothers Blessing Pouch:  Beautiful Blessing Pouch from all the Grandmothers to hold ceremonial and sacred objects: (plus all previous gifts)
  • $250: NZ Pounamu Jade Necklace: This piece of Pounamu (New Zealand Greenstone Jade) will be blessed by the grandmothers as we carry it through our journeys. Wearing it you will be connected to our journey, and humanity's. Pounamu is a stone of the wairua, the world of the spirit realm that surrounds all. Pounamu is traditionally only received as a gift - we give this gift to you with Aroha - divine love. Or you can get it as a gift for one you love. (Plus all previous gifts) 
  • $500 - Blessing Basket: A beautiful blessing basket, open to all hearts and all walks, to hold these sacred gifts, and a telephone or Skype blessing from one of the Grandmothers. (Plus all previous gifts)
  • $700 - Large Sacred Pounamu Necklace:  This powerful piece of Pounamu (New Zealand Greenstone Jade) will be carried by and blessed by the grandmothers for you, as a connection to our journeys. It's a pendant necklace brought from NZ by Maori Eila. Pounamu is a stone of the wairua, the world of the spirit realm that surrounds all. Pounamu is traditionally only received as a gift - we give this gift to you with Aroha - divine love. Or you can get it as a gift for one you love. (Plus medicine pouch)
  • $1000 - 11x14 Framed Jane Feldman Photo: A gorgeous 11x14 archival quality print by Jane Feldman. After the campaign finishes, you will be able to choose from different images for your print. Janefeldmanphoto.com  (Plus medicine pouch)
  • $1500 - 16x20 Framed Jane Feldman Photo: A gorgeous 16x20 archival quality print by Jane Feldman. After the campaign finishes, you will be able to choose from different images for your print. Janefeldmanphoto.com  (Plus medicine pouch) 
  • $2000 - Dinner With The Grandmothers: VIP Dinner with the Grandmothers in Salt Lake City, You are the welcomed guest of the Grandmothers at this meal. Come to SLC where the Grandmothers are gathering for the Parliament this October, and join the Grandmothers for dinner and conversation, face to face or virtually via Skype.  A one-time opportunity! 
  • $5000 - Dinner & Parliament: Join the Grandmothers as a member of the group at the Parliament, representing the birthing of a new way of being with each other and with the Earth. + A seat at dinner with the Grandmothers. 
  • Please feel free to not take any gifts in return for your donation if you don't want them and would rather your whole donation go to supporting the project.  

What Comes Next

After our time at the Parliament, we will journey through the Southwest to visit with elders and healers of several traditions. If you are moved, join us - there are 3 spaces left.  You can learn more about our journey and see pictures of the 2014 Rainbow Journey at https://rainbowofbeing.wordpress.com/rainbow-journey-2015-tour/

Last year our journey began in New Zealand and went through the SW, and by the time our journey completed we had been invited to speak before 10,000 people at the People's Climate March in NYC. This 

Who Are We

Dr. Rangimarie Turuki Rose Pere - Tohunga of the Maori People

Short Bio: Dr Rangimarie Turuki Rose Pere is a Tohunga (Sower of the Sacred Seeds of Knowledge, Keeper of the Secrets). As a Traditional Maori Elder and Leader who upholds the Spirit of Oneness, of everything in Creation, she sees the whole of Humanity as one Family who lives in the Four Directions. As an Icon in Education, and a Wisdom Keeper, who interacts Nationally, and Internationally, Dr Rangimarie Turuki Rose Pere is honoured and recognized by both Indigenous and Non-Indigenous People worldwide. As a Healer for Peace, she embraces all cultures, and respects their religious beliefs. Through her ancient ancestry from Peace Keepers, her religious beliefs are based on Aroha ( The Presence and the Breath of the Divine Source...Unconditional Love), Aio ( Peace), Koa ( Joy) and Pono ( Truth).

Grandmother Flordemayo - Curandera Espiritu of the Maya People

Short Bio: Flordemayo was born and grew up in the highlands of Central America in a family of healer Mayan healers and raised by her mother a midwife.  She travels the globe to share her healings and to foster a more spiritual understanding among humanity.  She  has been a founding member of the Church of the Spiritual Path, the Confederation of Indigenous Elders of the America, Institute of Natural and Traditional Knowledge, International Council of Thirteen Indigenous Grandmothers, and The Path. “We long for the great mystery”, seehttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W70cG4Nsj-k.


Grandmother Mary Lyons - Ojibwe Elder, Niizh-Nibi-Ikwe, Elder of Mitigwakk-Daywaygus-Giwstashskad, Sr. Member “Top Hat Medicine Dress/Long Skirt Society”

Short Bio: Grandmother Mary Lyons, Ojibwe Elder, Niizh-Nibi-Ikwe “Second Water Woman”, Elder of Mitigwakk-Daywaygus-Giwstashskad “Water Drum Circle”, Sr. Member of the “Top Hat Medicine Dress/Long Skirt Society”, Spiritual Advisor, Storyteller, Wisdom Teacher. Grandmother Mary carries an intense professional portfolio, her contribution to the wellness of women and families stands at the forefront of her commitments in the areas of “talking circles, ceremonies, Vision interpretations, one on one Spiritual Guidance.

Reverend Eila Paul - Elder and Healer of the Maori People

Short Bio: Reverend Eila Paul is a healer with a spiritual and physical connection to her people, the Maori of Aotearoa New Zealand and to our world culture. Eila works with the elderly and children, using sacred sound as a tool to heal and transform space within people and the environment. She has traveled through North America and Europe offering sacred seeds of knowledge and healing. Eila’s philosophy is that path of Love, Harmony and Beauty.

Grandmother Pershali Ami - Hopi Tewa Elder

Short Bio: Grandmother Pershlie Ami-Hopi-Tewa Elder, dedicates her time on many projects that motivates and improves the quality of life of all she touches.  Pershlie is an active volunteer with the Phoenix Indian Center committed to bringing awareness on the danger of underage drinking,and drug use.  She shares her message of concern regarding suicide prevention with Native American Organizations. She is eager to donate her time assisting the Native American Urban Ministry that focuses on aiding the homeless and individuals struggling with addictions. She is known for her intuitive, caring and focused approach to teaching,guiding, and mentoring using Native Wisdom and Universal Principles.


Reverend Murshida Devi Tide - Convener of the Awakening the World Project

Short Bio: Reverend Murshida Devi Tide is convener of the Awakening the World Project, linking indigenous tribes around the world to invite the revitalization of natural human wisdom. She is Head of the Sufi Healing Order in North America, Australia and New Zealand since 1999. She has over thirty years of experience as a spiritual teacher, and teaches internationally at venues such as the Harvard Mind Body Institute and the Fellowship program of the University of Arizona. She was an invited guest at the UN Millennium Peace Summit.


Other Ways You Can Help 

You might not be able to give any money but you can still help!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share with friends on Facebook
  • Email friends you think might be interested
  • Pray with us for the birthing of a new consciousness here by chanting Rose's chant for the Birthing Of The World Consciousness - the video with subtitles is below. 


Photo Of Grandmother Rose Pere

(send us a picture of yourself with your waters and we will upload it to our website)


Jane Feldman

Photos by Jane Feldman, janefeldmanphoto.com:


Many Photos used in the promotional video © Jane Feldman

story:
WWOOF INDIA  , GLOBAL VILLAGE ( WGV) Project Khajuraho,  MP state , .


 

WWOOF has plans up in its sleeves to expand the scope and reach of its activities in the days ahead. Even as it plans to expand the scope of its current initiatives, we are proposing to set up WWOOF GLOBAL VILLAGES (WGVs).  WWOOF plans to set up 4 such WGV s across the country that would serve as meeting point for WWOOFERS in .  The main objective of WGV is that the Indian WOOFERS could meet each other here and share their WWOOFING experience in . At WVG the WWOOFERs could also take relax from their hectic WWOOFING farm schedule and expected only to work just 3-4 hours daily and are free for lot of sight seeing and travel to places of tourist interest so that they become close to experience the Indian historical and cultural background which they can take back home . The project work for first such WGV has started recently and WWOOF has donated 4.5 Acres of land for this project at Village Surajpura near World famous Khajuraho temple town in MP adjacent to the and Panna Tiger Reserve.

The proposed WGV in long run would function, evolving into a model of sustainability using traditional knowledge and cultural practices.  This would closely work with the farmers in various clusters of villages in development of organic agriculture, education for children, local handicrafts and other village developmental activities. People will stay in the traditional family homes with the family and eat delicious traditional food . The Ultimate goal of the WGV would be to regenerate soil, conserve water, raise the water table, work along â€œNatural Farmingâ€ methods towards a model of self-sufficiency on all fronts.


About WGV Khajuraho ( MP )  

WWOOF has already purchased the land needed for setting up WWOOF GLOBAL VILLAGE and fencing around the land is completed . Now work is in progress for build mud huts for volunteers , we are planning to plant 250 different types of fruit trees of. We have to start work for the nursery for vegetables for which we have to construct shaded beds. We have plans for setting up a co-operative with organic farmers from our area for exchanging knowledge, organic seeds and plan to sell and transport produce together  creating a model of an integrated sustainable farming community. We aim to structure and develop our work so that it is accessible to a wider group of local people. The long term goal is to become a recognized research center in sustainability practices by providing workshops in alternative agricultural practices, food processing and preparation, alternative energy, eco-building, community exploration, and personal development, as well as documenting our work in natural farming and permaculture by involving  WWOOFers coming to India.  

Present situation in the area : Due to continuous drought like situation for last 6 years due to climate change , crops  are badly damaged farmers have lost their crops severely , local families suffer badly  and community member do not have any other job, they purchase food from local market at very high cost. The trees are been cut down for agricultural purposes but the main threat is the use of wood as the primary fuel source for local families. Village Surajpura  is a fairly isolated settlement and as such there is need for skill development for local craft expertise. The villagers can take up handicraft related activity as a additional source of income which could be easily sold to large number of tourist visiting Khajuraho every year. Local crafts in the areas are carpentry, masonry, bamboo craft, pottery to name few

Come and join us in building the WWOOF GLOBAL VILLAGE :

Expectations from volunteers â€“ To complete the project , help is needed financial and physical both, The volunteers staying here would be expected to work using local material, alternative construction with low cost technology,  build mud huts, toilet construction, water harvesting tanks, eco development, teaching English to children , help family in cooking , house management. .Communicating with local villagers, participating in local festivals, religious  celebration, social events, school program, enjoy life with other  WWOOFERS , living tranquility  with the nature, building check dam for water harvesting,  bunding and planting tree, creating  the jungle garden,  working in the vegetable gardens, building a composting structure etc

Lodging & boarding: You can expect simple & traditional but comfortable living as you stay at WGV Khajuraho project area. The WWOOFERS will stay with farm families of the village till our basic infrastructure at the WGV becomes fully functional.    We have kept in mind the hygiene needs while planning for our guestsâ€™ requirements. As a guest you would be provided with:

Food: Home cooked vegetarian food will be served and it will be mostly from the ingredients grown locally .There is a tradition of two main meals in Bundelkhand region of MP. One full meal late morning around 9-10 am a followed by light evening tea around 4.00 & 5.00 pm with some snacks and an early dinner between 7.00 & 8.00 pm as the village goes to sleep early. In other words you will share all the same amenities as the family enjoy. Your only other expenses will be for personal shopping when you go to the local market or on excursions on your own.

Cost: We would appreciate a little contribution towards food and stay . Your 7 $  or 300 INR per day contributions would provide you free facilities like Accommodations, Bicycles and delicious Traditional food and also this money will help us to purchase items needed for WGV project.

state , .
 WWOOF 
has plans up in its sleeves to expand the scope and reach of its activities in
the days ahead. Even as it plans to expand the scope of its current
initiatives, we are proposing to set up WWOOF GLOBAL VILLAGES (WGVs).  WWOOF 
plans to set up 4 such WGV s across the country that would serve as meeting
point for WWOOFERS in .  The main objective of WGV is that the Indian
WOOFERS could meet each other here and share their WWOOFING experience in .
At WVG the WWOOFERs could also take relax from their hectic WWOOFING farm
schedule and expected only to work just 3-4 hours daily and are free for lot of
sight seeing and travel to places of tourist interest so that they become close
to experience the Indian historical and cultural background which they can take
back home . The project work for first such WGV has started recently and WWOOF  has donated 4.5 Acres of land for this
project at Village Surajpura near World famous Khajuraho temple town in MP
adjacent to the  and Panna Tiger Reserve.
The proposed WGV in long run would function, evolving into a
model of sustainability using traditional knowledge and cultural practices.  This would closely work with the farmers in
various clusters of villages in development of organic agriculture, education for
children, local handicrafts and other village developmental activities. People
will stay in the traditional family homes with the family and eat delicious traditional
food . The Ultimate goal of the WGV would be to regenerate soil, conserve
water, raise the water table, work along â€œNatural Farmingâ€ methods towards a
model of self-sufficiency on all fronts.

story:
We are moving to Phase II of our campaign!

This indiegogo campaign will expire in a few short days, but we will continue to campaign until the NAPHN Conference week!  Please contact Ashley Murphree if you miss the deadline:

a.n.murphree@gmail.com

Summary

The annual conference for North America Passive House Network is coming to the Bay Area this October, and we are celebrating with our project, The Ice Box Challenge!

This project is our way of reaching out to our local building industry, teaching real solutions for resilient, high quality construction, and then promoting our solutions and our leadership nationally.  

Our solution is Passive House.  Our leadership is you!

This fundraising campaign is seeking sponsors for a modest construction budget with a large impact:

The Ice Box Challenge is a simple, yet head-turning comparison featuring two display boxes—one built to the Passive House standard and the other to California’s building code—each box housing a block of ice. The melting exhibit is a vivid demonstration of Passive House comfort, quality, and thermal performance: How well do the simple, passive construction strategies work?

We will reach a wide audience for Passive House awareness by demonstrating the boxes at locations including a university, a lumber yard, and public places in California. Working together with the conference outreach team, the Ice Box Challenge and its supporters will be marketed broadly across the web through social media, online news articles, and newsletters. It will conclude with a contest and prizes to guess the weights of remaining ice in each box.

https://www.naphnconference.com/

 

What We Need & What You Get

We are starting with a campaign goal of $4000 to fund the following:

  • Building materials to build 2x phone booth sized boxes 
    • Windows
    • Lumber and OSB
    • Weather barrier
    • Insulation
    • Siding
    • Screws
  • Large ice blocks
  • Printing for educational brochures and poster stickers
  • Truck rentals to move and set up the displays
  • Prizes awarded to Challenge winners

Any extra money raised will go towards the 4th Annual Conference for NAPHN!

SAVE THE DATE FOR #NAPHN17 !  Oct. 4-8th, 2017 in Oakland, CA

http://www.naphnconference.com/

 

The Perks!:

  • Sponsors of $25 will get their name or company listed as a supporter in the Ice Box brochures and on the conference Ice Box Challenge website
  • Sponsors of $50 will have their name or company promoted as a local resource for Passive House products/services in the Ice Box brochures ,plus all lower contribution perks
  • Sponsors of $100 will get one free admission to the Exploratorium Night at The Museum during conference week, plus all lower contribution perks
  • Sponsors of $300 will get a free one year membership to Passive House California, plus all lower contribution perks
  • Sponsors of $500 or more will have their company name/logo displayed on the Passive House Ice Box, plus all lower contribution perks

 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways!

  • Donate building materials, printing services, or trucking in lieu of cash
  • Volunteer a few hours of time to set up the Boxes and talk to  folks about Passive House

Contact Ashley Murphree to give a hand:  a.n.murphree@gmail.com

story:
We have been taking care and protecting this land for twenty years, and all the infrastructure has run down. Now we have this wonderful opportunity, that a group of agroforestry and permaculture enthusiasts wants to make a caravan from Rio De Janeiro to the central Brazil to help us progress, so we need to reform the infrastructure. Please check this site www.projectnewman.com We are a private owned reserve RPPN (private natural reserve heritage) of 10.000 ha, located at the top most plateau in Brazil, where lives the Mergus duck, the rarest bird on the planet. Mergus Octocetaceous (UNESCO critically endangered species); The place is also called The craddle of the Water.

21.12: Grateful thanks to the contributors until now. The planning of the camp is in progress. The donated money will be used for materials and tools, to build platforms for people to stay at the Land in tents, and to build drytoilets. If we get enough fonding, we would like to prepare before the camp, to repair the existing buildings at the land. In that case, the camp can go further with the building of a Buddhahall, a place for group meditations. If not, depending of the amount of donations, the camp will be reparing the existing houses.

story:
Save Bonaire's Critically Endangered Sea Turtles 

Twenty-five years ago, Sea Turtle Conservation Bonaire (STCB) began monitoring the status of three of the world’s six endangered or critically endangered species of marine turtles: the hawksbill, green, and loggerhead turtle.

At the moment we are in need of funding, as the most serious challenges facing Bonaire’s sea turtles are not direct threats like poaching or lack of support for sea turtle protection, the main threats now are indirect, related to a rapidly increasing human population and the development that goes along with it. These indirect threats to sea turtles are also the major threats to Bonaire’s rich ecosystems, biodiversity, and our own quality of life.

In this landscape, we no longer look at sea turtle conservation as something apart from society. To ensure a secure future for Bonaire’s sea turtles, we must address the issues that threaten sea turtles - biodiversity and social well-being, because they are inter-related. Sea turtles can thrive only when their ecosystems are healthy and the human community thrives. Conservation and applied research remain the core work of STCB. Our work spans education and outreach, advocacy, research and conservation. 

Your Donation will go to Five of our Programs

  • Nest Monitoring: During the nesting season (April-January), STCB staff and volunteers patrol the beaches most used by sea turtles, recording signs of nesting and hatching, as well as monitoring the safety status of nests.
  • In-water Surveys: Since 2003, STCB has been conducting standardized          in-water surveys and tagging programs to gather information on sea turtles in the waters surrounding Bonaire. 
  • Turtle in Trouble: Several times a year STCB is called upon to attempt to rescue a sea turtle in distress or danger. 
  • Community awareness program: STCB shares the compelling story of sea turtle conservation on Bonaire in a variety of ways—from school or public presentations to informative articles via all forms of media.
  • Advocacy: To protect Bonaire’s endangered sea turtles, advocacy remains one of our strategic goals. As an organization we are a proactive and strategic advocate for social and economic activities, policies and legislation that prioritize the protection of Bonaire’s sea turtles and the value of biodiversity. 

About Us

We value efficiency and transparency in our work. Have a look on our website to read our Research & Monitoring Reports and our Annual Financial Reports. 

You Can Also Help By

  • Sharing our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram or by e-mail.
  • Letting us know if you have a special skill and would like to volunteer.
  • Signing up for our newsletter, via our website.
  • Reducing your plastic use.
To learn more about all the work we do on Bonaire, please have a look here.

To stay tuned about our work please sign up for our bi-monthly newsletter here.

To learn more about our advocacy work, click here.

STCB is a non-profit, non-governmental organization, which is financially supported by WWF-NL. Besides their support we depend on funds raised through merchandise sales and individual and business donors. 

Photos by Solvin Zankl © Thank you Solvin, they are gorgeous!!
