story:
Campaign Coverage:

Thank you to the many bloggers and media outlets who have covered our campaign!

  

 

 

 

 

 

 

The Goal

We will build a cost effective solar water pump and system that will help improve the lives of 50 million people in developing countries. The solar pump is the key component of a complete water-to-crops irrigation system that is being designed by leading experts in the fields of irrigation, systems engineering, and solar energy. Using a method proven by Paul Polak, the system will be sold to farmers in some of the poorest regions in the world, enabling the farmers themselves to break their poverty cycles. We have the designs, the prototypes, and the motivation. Now we need your help as we work to build a production model we can take to field tests.

 

The Background

Did you know that there are a billion people in the world that make just $2 a day? Can you imagine what your life would be like if you made less than $20 a week? The vast majority of the families who live this reality are farmers in the developing world with small plots of land. They work together to grow the food they eat and hope to sell in the market. They make just enough to survive and have difficulty investing in labor-saving equipment.

To break out of the poverty cycle, poor farmers need to grow cash crops to increase their income. Cash crops are crops above and beyond the farmers' needs, but growing them is a challenge. Many farmers pump water by hand or carry it in buckets from a village pond to their crops. Not only is this a slow and physically grueling task, but often times the shallow wells and seasonal rains mean farmers can't grow crops in the dry season. Farmers need a reliable, low-cost water pumping system to grow the extra food they need to make a poverty-busting profit.

Diesel pumps are one option, but they use expensive diesel fuel, break down often, exhaust carbon into the atmosphere, and are relatively expensive. Diesel pumps cost $500 to buy and $700 a year for fuel and maintenance. Over a three year span the costs can reach $2,600, assuming diesel prices don’t increase. Electric pumps are another option. They’re cheap, but they use grid power that is unreliable in developing countries like India. In fact, grid power is so unreliable that most farmers who have an electric pump have a backup diesel pump too. Electric pumps can alternatively be powered with solar energy, but current systems can cost $5,000 or more, which is way out of the reach of poor farmers.

 

Solar powered systems are available, but they are currently far too expensive for poor farmers.

The Plan

Our big-picture goal is to create the entire water-to-crops system. We are creating a pressurized irrigation system that brings water to a one-hectare plot with a cost target of $2,900. This cost includes well drilling, water storage, tubing, installation, and the solar pump itself. Our whole system will be cheaper than buying just the panels and pump in the current solar-powered systems! In our quest to make our solution as affordable as possible we have worked in India with craftsmen to improve well efficiencies and with manufacturers to lower irrigation equipment costs.

The much lower cost means farmers will be able to pay off the loans they use to purchase one in less than two years. Plus, there’s no fuel to buy. This game-changing reduction in cost will enable farmers to transform their small plot agriculture, create water markets where they don’t currently exist, and significantly increase their earnings. 

The plan is to first sell them to farmers who make $3 to $5 a day who will be more likely to secure financing. When two or more of these pumps are in the same vicinity it creates a micro-market for excess water, creating opportunity for the poorer farmers. Selling a large number of these pumps over the next few years will also yield production efficiencies that can be used to lower prices even further so that more farmers can afford them. We know this works since we've seen it happen with our foot-powered treadle pumps.

 

A treadle pump from Paul Polak's previous work. These helped raise 17 million people out of poverty.

What We Need

It's not just the panels and the pump, we're out to improve everything from drilling the well to the tubes that carry the water to the crops. To make this kind of price leap we need to do end-to-end system testing and optimization. 

Quarter Scale Test ($25,000): A few things happen in parallel at this level.

  1. We will build a 500 Watt system that will be our testing platform for all the different components. We will build the whole system out including the panels, a concentrator, inverter, pump, and the irrigation tubing.  
  2. We will buy all the testing equipment, support hardware, and extra widgets that we need to make sure we're building the best system possible.
  3. We will fund all the perks out of the first several thousand dollars.

All three of these things have to happen at the same time!

 

Manufacturing Phase ($10,000): If we raise this much more money then we will build a full scale version after we learn as much as possible from the quarter scale testing. There will still be some tweaking as we perfect the system. We will also start getting supply chains ready for bulk purchases so we can reduce costs on the final version.

 

Test Phase ($15,000): Raising an additional $15,000 will let us field test the system! We will ship our best system and test it in the fields. Getting the system into the real world is incredibly important. If we can raise this much money we're well on our way to success.

 

Final Tweaks Phase ($5,000): An extra $5,000 will let the team make any major changes required from field testing.

 

Production design of the SunWater solar pump.

What You Get

We've lined up a series of perks meant to help you share in the spirit and excitement of using technology to help some of the poorest people on earth. We feel a lot of enthusiasm for our project and what it means and we want to help plant that seed in you as well. Check out our descriptions on the right and see what kind of inspiration we can create in your life.

 

Our Team

It’s a big dream, so why do we think we can succeed? The answer is that we've assembled a winning team. We have experts in affordable technology design, solar engineering, systems design, water pumping, and irrigation, all lead by an internationally known expert in international development and social business. 

Paul Polak is leading the team. He is internationally known for fighting poverty using business and technology, and is the author of the book Out of Poverty. He founded International Development Enterprises, an NGO that ended poverty for 17 million people, and has sold 1 million foot-powered treadle pumps to farmers in the developing world.

Jacob Mathew is the founder of Idiom Design and Consulting, a leading 100-person design consultancy in Bangalore, India. Jacob has developed many similar technology projects including the system design for Spring Health, a clean water business in India.

Jack Keller is a civil engineer and our expert on irrigation and water pumping. Keller has taught and conducted research and consultation in sprinkle and trickle irrigation in more than 60 countries. He is the author of more than 90 technical papers and two textbooks in the areas of agricultural water resources planning and engineering, on-farm water management, and irrigation system design.

Steve Katsaros is an award-winning engineer, patent agent, and CEO of Nokero. Nokero is a for-profit company with a mission to provide affordable solar technology solutions for poor, off-grid communities around the world. Steve is an expert in solar product design, manufacturing, and supply chains.

Many of the team's volunteer engineers come from Ball Aerospace & Technologies Corp., the same company that developed the science instruments in the Hubble Space Telescope and many other space systems. As professional space systems engineers they are experts in solar energy, mechanical, and systems design. This unique partnership gives the team access to a tremendous amount of knowledge and expertise, made possible through the efforts of their former CEO, Dave Taylor.

 

Bringing it all Together

Paul Polak has been traveling the world and fighting poverty for decades with award winning solutions. He works very closely with poor people in remote villages to understand what they need to improve their lives. Time and again the answer is access to water for their crops. There are pumps available, but they’re expensive to buy and maintain. To make a big impact we have to make a big reduction in the cost. When farmers can buy their own solar-powered pump a whole new avenue for securing their own financial security is opened.

We have a need. We have a solution. Now we need your help as we build it!

 

FAQ

Question: Why solar powered pumps?

Answer: Solar powered pumps don’t use diesel fuel, they rarely break down, and when they do they can be repaired easily. This system has very low operating costs compared to a diesel pump. Plus, they don’t create carbon emissions.

Question: Why are you using mirrors?

Answer: The single biggest cost in the sysytem is the solar panels. One panel can be several hundred dollars or more. A mirror is a few dollars and is widely available. By using a mirror to shine extra sunlight onto the panel we are increasing the energy output for a tiny fraction of what it would cost to buy another panel. Calculations show we can get the energy we need to run the pump with a set of these mirrors, saving thousands of dollars in the process.

Question: Why don’t you give these away for free? 

Answer: Charity is a wonderful, and often necessary, act of giving that will always have a place in the world. However, long term solutions to large problems need to scale up rapidly and be able to support themselves. That means a commercial enterprise. If the solution is profitable it can generate the resources needed to reach hundreds of millions of people. SunWater will help farmers make more money, which will drive interest in other farmers buying their own pump, enabling the benefits to be provided to more and more people.

Paul Polak and the team have also found that solutions are more successful if farmers own the pump. When a poor village receives a free water pump it almost always falls into disrepair and disuse because there’s no ownership of it, even when water is one of their key problems. But when a poor farmer buys his own pump the results are vastly different: it stays well maintained, is used as effectively as possible, and creative ways of extending the benefits to the farmer are found. If we want to solve long term problems in a long-term way the poor need cost-effective solutions they can own instead of handouts on a sporadic basis.

Question: How effective do you really think the project will be?

Answer: This matters on a large scale - we think we can install 1 million of our pumps in India in the first 10 years. This will reach 50 million people, raising millions of them out of poverty. In addition, through future extensions of the core technology, there will be the potential to turn millions of farmers into energy entrepreneurs, bringing solar electricity, household lighting, and cell phone charging to millions of rural households that will never connect to the grid. All this, plus we’ll reduce carbon emissions by replacing the diesel pumps with clean solar pumps. Paul Polak, Jacob Mathew, and Jack Keller have been working directly with the farmers for decades and understand what will work in the long run. They feel this is the kind of game changing project that can make a difference.

Question: I’d like a little more detail on what these pumps are for and how you plan on making this work. Can you share more information?

Answer: There are two key components to this project: develop and field test cost-effective solar powered pressurized irrigation systems and establish a commercial enterprise to promote their adoption by farmers in India.

Pumping surface or groundwater for irrigation is energy intensive and traditional photovoltaic (solar) powered irrigation systems can’t compete with fossil fueled surface irrigation systems. To make it work we have to minimize the energy requirements of crop irrigation. We will accomplish this by applying a systems approach for optimizing the series of water flow components from the water supply to the irrigated crops. The critical design tasks include: 

  • The well filter and screen must be designed to reduce drawdown.
  • The solar panel array, mirror concentrators, and pump mechanism must be optimized to produce pressurized water using the sun's energy.
  • The water distribution system must be optimized to increase the crop production per unit of irrigation water applied.

Giving away the system will be ineffective in the long run; farmers must invest in the pumps in order to create the motivation that ownership brings. To do this, a commercial company will be established first in India and then in Africa. The business model will integrate solar-powered pumping systems with a package of services including financing (lease to own or loan), support for design, installation and operation/maintenance training, and farm advisory services to enhance farming enterprise profitability.

Paul Polak and his team have previously made drip irrigation more affordable for poor farmers. Drip irrigation is more effective than using sprinklers or flooding techniques.

Question: How is the proposed technical solution sufficiently different from currently available technologies? 

Answer: The pump will be much cheaper than available options, but it's not just the pump that will make this work. We're using our collective field experience with small plot irrigation in Asia to create an end-to-end system specifically designed to help poor farmers irrigate their crops. We are taking a zero-based design approach to the problem, improving the whole process of irrigating crops with no limiting preconceptions. 

It’s worth noting that solar powered pumping systems with water delivery similar to five horsepower engine pumps are being promoted in India, but they require subsidies of up to 86% to make them attractive. Subsidies are costly and practically impossible for small plot farmers to obtain.
story_txt:
Campaign Coverage:
Thank you to the many bloggers and media outlets who have covered our campaign!

  

 

 
 

 
 

 
The Goal
We will build a cost effective solar water pump and system that will help improve the lives of 50 million people in developing countries. The solar pump is the key component of a complete water-to-crops irrigation system that is being designed by leading experts in the fields of irrigation, systems engineering, and solar energy. Using a method proven by Paul Polak, the system will be sold to farmers in some of the poorest regions in the world, enabling the farmers themselves to break their poverty cycles. We have the designs, the prototypes, and the motivation. Now we need your help as we work to build a production model we can take to field tests.
 
The Background
Did you know that there are a billion people in the world that make just $2 a day? Can you imagine what your life would be like if you made less than $20 a week? The vast majority of the families who live this reality are farmers in the developing world with small plots of land. They work together to grow the food they eat and hope to sell in the market. They make just enough to survive and have difficulty investing in labor-saving equipment.
To break out of the poverty cycle, poor farmers need to grow cash crops to increase their income. Cash crops are crops above and beyond the farmers' needs, but growing them is a challenge. Many farmers pump water by hand or carry it in buckets from a village pond to their crops. Not only is this a slow and physically grueling task, but often times the shallow wells and seasonal rains mean farmers can't grow crops in the dry season. Farmers need a reliable, low-cost water pumping system to grow the extra food they need to make a poverty-busting profit.
Diesel pumps are one option, but they use expensive diesel fuel, break down often, exhaust carbon into the atmosphere, and are relatively expensive. Diesel pumps cost $500 to buy and $700 a year for fuel and maintenance. Over a three year span the costs can reach $2,600, assuming diesel prices don’t increase. Electric pumps are another option. They’re cheap, but they use grid power that is unreliable in developing countries like India. In fact, grid power is so unreliable that most farmers who have an electric pump have a backup diesel pump too. Electric pumps can alternatively be powered with solar energy, but current systems can cost $5,000 or more, which is way out of the reach of poor farmers.
 
Solar powered systems are available, but they are currently far too expensive for poor farmers.
The Plan
Our big-picture goal is to create the entire water-to-crops system. We are creating a pressurized irrigation system that brings water to a one-hectare plot with a cost target of $2,900. This cost includes well drilling, water storage, tubing, installation, and the solar pump itself. Our whole system will be cheaper than buying just the panels and pump in the current solar-powered systems! In our quest to make our solution as affordable as possible we have worked in India with craftsmen to improve well efficiencies and with manufacturers to lower irrigation equipment costs.
The much lower cost means farmers will be able to pay off the loans they use to purchase one in less than two years. Plus, there’s no fuel to buy. This game-changing reduction in cost will enable farmers to transform their small plot agriculture, create water markets where they don’t currently exist, and significantly increase their earnings. 
The plan is to first sell them to farmers who make $3 to $5 a day who will be more likely to secure financing. When two or more of these pumps are in the same vicinity it creates a micro-market for excess water, creating opportunity for the poorer farmers. Selling a large number of these pumps over the next few years will also yield production efficiencies that can be used to lower prices even further so that more farmers can afford them. We know this works since we've seen it happen with our foot-powered treadle pumps.
 
A treadle pump from Paul Polak's previous work. These helped raise 17 million people out of poverty.
What We Need


It's not just the panels and the pump, we're out to improve everything from drilling the well to the tubes that carry the water to the crops. To make this kind of price leap we need to do end-to-end system testing and optimization. 
Quarter Scale Test ($25,000): A few things happen in parallel at this level.

We will build a 500 Watt system that will be our testing platform for all the different components. We will build the whole system out including the panels, a concentrator, inverter, pump, and the irrigation tubing.  
We will buy all the testing equipment, support hardware, and extra widgets that we need to make sure we're building the best system possible.
We will fund all the perks out of the first several thousand dollars.

All three of these things have to happen at the same time!
 
Manufacturing Phase ($10,000): If we raise this much more money then we will build a full scale version after we learn as much as possible from the quarter scale testing. There will still be some tweaking as we perfect the system. We will also start getting supply chains ready for bulk purchases so we can reduce costs on the final version.
 
Test Phase ($15,000): Raising an additional $15,000 will let us field test the system! We will ship our best system and test it in the fields. Getting the system into the real world is incredibly important. If we can raise this much money we're well on our way to success.
 
Final Tweaks Phase ($5,000): An extra $5,000 will let the team make any major changes required from field testing.
 
Production design of the SunWater solar pump.
What You Get
We've lined up a series of perks meant to help you share in the spirit and excitement of using technology to help some of the poorest people on earth. We feel a lot of enthusiasm for our project and what it means and we want to help plant that seed in you as well. Check out our descriptions on the right and see what kind of inspiration we can create in your life.
 


Our Team
It’s a big dream, so why do we think we can succeed? The answer is that we've assembled a winning team. We have experts in affordable technology design, solar engineering, systems design, water pumping, and irrigation, all lead by an internationally known expert in international development and social business. 
Paul Polak is leading the team. He is internationally known for fighting poverty using business and technology, and is the author of the book Out of Poverty. He founded International Development Enterprises, an NGO that ended poverty for 17 million people, and has sold 1 million foot-powered treadle pumps to farmers in the developing world.
Jacob Mathew is the founder of Idiom Design and Consulting, a leading 100-person design consultancy in Bangalore, India. Jacob has developed many similar technology projects including the system design for Spring Health, a clean water business in India.
Jack Keller is a civil engineer and our expert on irrigation and water pumping. Keller has taught and conducted research and consultation in sprinkle and trickle irrigation in more than 60 countries. He is the author of more than 90 technical papers and two textbooks in the areas of agricultural water resources planning and engineering, on-farm water management, and irrigation system design.
Steve Katsaros is an award-winning engineer, patent agent, and CEO of Nokero. Nokero is a for-profit company with a mission to provide affordable solar technology solutions for poor, off-grid communities around the world. Steve is an expert in solar product design, manufacturing, and supply chains.
Many of the team's volunteer engineers come from Ball Aerospace & Technologies Corp., the same company that developed the science instruments in the Hubble Space Telescope and many other space systems. As professional space systems engineers they are experts in solar energy, mechanical, and systems design. This unique partnership gives the team access to a tremendous amount of knowledge and expertise, made possible through the efforts of their former CEO, Dave Taylor.
 
Bringing it all Together
Paul Polak has been traveling the world and fighting poverty for decades with award winning solutions. He works very closely with poor people in remote villages to understand what they need to improve their lives. Time and again the answer is access to water for their crops. There are pumps available, but they’re expensive to buy and maintain. To make a big impact we have to make a big reduction in the cost. When farmers can buy their own solar-powered pump a whole new avenue for securing their own financial security is opened.
We have a need. We have a solution. Now we need your help as we build it!
 

FAQ
Question: Why solar powered pumps?
Answer: Solar powered pumps don’t use diesel fuel, they rarely break down, and when they do they can be repaired easily. This system has very low operating costs compared to a diesel pump. Plus, they don’t create carbon emissions.

When a poor village receives a free water pump it almost always falls into disrepair and disuse because there’s no ownership of it, even when water is one of their key problems. But when a poor farmer buys his own pump the results are vastly different: it stays well maintained, is used as effectively as possible, and creative ways of extending the benefits to the farmer are found. If we want to solve long term problems in a long-term way the poor need cost-effective solutions they can own instead of handouts on a sporadic basis.

Answer: This matters on a large scale - we think we can install 1 million of our pumps in India in the first 10 years. This will reach 50 million people, raising millions of them out of poverty. They feel this is the kind of game changing project that can make a difference.

The solar panel array, mirror concentrators, and pump mechanism must be optimized to produce pressurized water using the sun's energy.
The water distribution system must be optimized to increase the crop production per unit of irrigation water applied.
Giving away the system will be ineffective in the long run; farmers must invest in the pumps in order to create the motivation that ownership brings. To do this, a commercial company will be established first in India and then in Africa. The business model will integrate solar-powered pumping systems with a package of services including financing (lease to own or loan), support for design, installation and operation/maintenance training, and farm advisory services to enhance farming enterprise profitability.

story:
Help our students have continuous learning opportunities. Help us obtain solar panels

With your help we hope to raise money for purchasing a solar panel energy storage system for our school. Kikaaya College and Vocational School.  We are wanting to find a safer, cleaner and cheaper way to power our school's computers and lights and water source.  Currently, when the power goes out, we have a backup generator that relies on gasoline to run.  Unfortunately, the amount of energy generated by our gas powered motor backup is only enough to power the lights and a few of our school computers but not all.  Therefore, if the power goes, so does student access to computer learning.  Obtaining dependable, clean energy production means in the form of solar panels would be unimaginably rewarding for our students enrolled at Kikaaya College and Vocational school.  Seeing the solar panels, learning how the sun's power is utilized to provide electricity (and continuous learning opportunities via use of our school's computer technology) would also be an educational experience for both young and older members of the village of Kikaaya.

We need 5,450 dollars to pay for the procurement and shipping of a solar panel generator to power the school whenever power goes away.  In the event of our goal going unmet, funds raised will go towards purchasing computers for the school and providing tuition assistance for children with financial struggles, and luminAid solar lights to Kikaaya community members. 

Again, making a choice to donate  means that you are also making a choice to improve environmental conditions at Kikaaya Collge and Vocational School and the surrounding community.  You are also making a choice to educate the children of school on the importance and benefits of clean, renewable energy.

If you aren't able to donate money you can still help.  Spread the word to people you know that might be able to help us raise funds. Also, Kikaaya is always looking for willing, passionate volunteers.  Please take a trip to www.kikaayacollegeschool.net for more information.  Thank you.

story:
Overview

Every year, thousands of the most intelligent creatures that inhabit our oceans are savagely and needlessly killed in a small town in Japan named Taiji. If you’ve seen the 2009 documentary The Cove, you’re already familiar with this. What many of you may not know is that, in Taiji, the cove still runs red every year between the months of September and February. Hundreds of dolphins, porpoises, and whales have already lost their lives this season.

My name is Micah and I am a volunteer with the Sea Shepherd Conservation Society. Here at home in Seattle, Washington, I’ve been educating the public about Taiji. On September 1st, we took the fight to the doors of the Japanese consulate in downtown Seattle. Now it’s time to bring the fight to the shores of Japan. 

If you can find it in your ability to donate, know that it makes a difference.

Not everyone can go to Taiji, but everyone can help. The dolphins need your help, Sea Shepherd needs your help, I need your help.

My name is Micah Rowland and I will be a Cove Guardian.

The Impact

Change at Taiji can only come from within Japan. What goes on in Taiji is not widely reported in Japan and the presence of Cove Guardians creates an awareness to the dolphin slaughter that the media and the Japanese people and the world cannot ignore. The more Cove Guardians we have, the more photos, videos, and information can come out of Taiji. The more Cove Guardians, the bigger the news story, the bigger the reach.

If your response is overwhelming and we raise more than what I personally require, any excesses will help defray the cost of other Sea Shepherd volunteers that join the effort at Taiji this year.

What I Need

Traveling to Taiji is not cheap. Between flight, lodging, transportation, and other expenses, a two week visit from Seattle costs an average of $5000. I’ve broken out my projected expenses so you can see where your money will go. Not a single dollar raised will go into the economy of the city of Taiji. 

Funds Breakdown

A 14-day trip estimate breaks down as follows

Flight - Seattle to Osaka - $1117

Lodging - $1469

Car Rental - $1518

Food - $653

Misc - $243

I've also built in the IndieGoGo fees so that the funds after they take their cut are sufficient.

Donation Gifts

In appreciation for your donations, I've designed a collection of gifts available at specific donation levels. Gifts are cumulative up to the $50 level. That means if you donate $25. you'll get the button and wristband and at $50, you'll get the patch, button, and wristband!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, you can still help. Tell your friends about this fundraising site. Forward them the video so they can get involved.

Subscribe to the @SeaShepherd twitter feed to keep tabs on live happenings in Taiji. Talk to everyone you know about what is going on and especially to any acquaintances in Japan, as the Japanese people are the only ones with the power to persuade their government to end this senseless slaughter.

Also, support Sea Shepherd directly. Your donations help Sea Shepherd enforce conservation laws that governments of the world can not or will not enforce themselves.

Non-Tax-Deductible Donation Information

To keep operating costs at a minimum Sea Shepherd volunteers are not paid. Due to legal requirements governing non-profit organizations, Sea Shepherd is not allowed to directly raise funds for individual Cove Guardians and we are therefore responsible for all personal fundraising. What this means to you is that your donation is not tax-deductible and this fundraising is not affiliated directly with the nonprofit organization Sea Shepherd. Your contribution to my/our journey is, for tax purposes, a personal gift.

story:
ARE YOU CONCERNED WITH OUR ENVIRONMENT?   DO YOU WANT TO HELP OUR MILITARY VETERANS?  Wounded Nature Working Veterans, an IRS approved non-profit , is an organization that is very passionate about two things...  OUR ENVIRONMENT AND OUR VETERANS.  No matter how big or how small - WITH YOUR HELP, WE CAN MAKE THIS HAPPEN - Every dollar counts!! 

Due to the devastation of Hurricane Sandy, we are seeking to fund a fleet of flat-bottom coastal houseboats that will be deployed around the areas hardest hit by the storm.  These vessels will be staffed by a crew of military veterans that will perform coastal cleanup, and disaster aid relief.  We are seeking funding to acquire these vessels and pay operating expenses in order to begin our fight to clean up these areas, while enabling our military veterans to find meaningful employment and transition into the private sector.  

Every year, hundreds of thousands of sea turtles, dolphins, sea birds, and other marine life are consumed by the sea. We know that some of these species perish from litter and trash ingestion. This causes a slow, painful, and gruesome demise. When sea creatures become sick, they leave the shore areas to avoid predators and head out to sea. Eating shoreline debris results in intestinal blockage causing all food eaten to accumulate and form intestinal gas. Over the next couple of days, the animal is unable to eat and cannot submerge due to the gas build up. As they float in a weakened condition on the top of the water, baking in the sun, predators discover and eat these helpless creatures or their bodies are washed ashore.

Wounded Nature Working Veterans puts the overwhelming majority of our resources and donations toward remedial action to end this vicious cycle.  Most non-profit organizations use less than three percent of all funds and personnel to actually fix the problem through remedial action.  Within the non-profit sector most donations are spent on policy, research, education, recycling, and conferences around the world.  Our vision is to make an impact throughout the US and, ultimately, the world—leaving it a better place for the next generations.

Our long term goal is to have a fleet of vessels covering our nation's coast lines, to help aid in the fight to return our coast lines to pristine conditions.  We want our children, grandchildren, and great grandchildren to have the same wonderful experiences we had at the beach.

Please pass this along to your family, friends, co-workers.  Follow us on Facebook and watch for us in the Wall Street Journal and on NBC.  The Military channel has also pledged to cover the launching of our first vessel so that is GREAT!!  Help us make this a reality.

** Please take note - when making a contribution, ANY dollar amount may be entered to show your support - there is NO minimum **

Woundednature.org is an IRS approved non-profit charity.  Woundednature.org’s IRS non-profit EIN number is: 27-3570810.  As with all donations to charity, we recommend you consult with your financial advisor regarding tax credits and deductions.  

If you have any questions or suggestions please feel free to email me at john@woundednature.org

As they float in a weakened condition on the top of the water, baking in the sun, predators discover and eat these helpless creatures or their bodies are washed ashore.
Wounded Nature Working Veterans puts the overwhelming majority of our resources and donations toward remedial action to end this vicious cycle.  Most non-profit organizations use less than three percent of all funds and personnel to actually fix the problem through remedial action.  Within the non-profit sector most donations are spent on policy, research, education, recycling, and conferences around the world.  Our vision is to make an impact throughout the US and, ultimately, the world—leaving it a better place for the next generations.
Our long term goal is to have a fleet of vessels covering our nation's coast lines, to help aid in the fight to return our coast lines to pristine conditions.  We want our children, grandchildren, and great grandchildren to have the same wonderful experiences we had at the beach.
Please pass this along to your family, friends, co-workers.  Follow us on Facebook and watch for us in the Wall Street Journal and on NBC.  The Military channel has also pledged to cover the launching of our first vessel so that is GREAT!!  Help us make this a reality.
** Please take note - when making a contribution, ANY dollar amount may be entered to show your support - there is NO minimum **
Woundednature.org is an IRS approved non-profit charity.  Woundednature.org’s IRS non-profit EIN number is: 27-3570810.  As with all donations to charity, we recommend you consult with your financial advisor regarding tax credits and deductions.  
If you have any questions or suggestions please feel free to email me at john@woundednature.org

story:
Our Project Summary

Hi-my name is Maria and I am the group leader of the Citizens Climate Lobby -Santa Fe group. I've been a climate activist since I saw Al Gore's Inconvenient Truth back in 2006. Last year, I had the privilege of attending Gore's Climate Reality Leadership Training Conference and became a CRP Leader. At that conference, I met the people from Citizens Climate Lobby. Dedicated to creating the political will (no small feat) for a stable climate, CCL organizes through grassroots citizen advocacy groups. There are over 70 groups across the US and Canada.

Having been a climate activist since 2006, I agree with Marshal Saunders (CCL founder) that in order to get the change we need, we need to change the behavior of Congress and not just individuals. I eagerly jumped on board the CCL train and began the Santa Fe group.

CCL is an organization made up of amazing and optimistic people. Often citizens view their elected officials with cynicism and disdain. If we expect so little, that is exactly what we will get.  CCL believes that politicians don't create political will, they respond to it. We believe that if we articulate, we can be dangerous to ignorance and apathy.

While others have said it's not possible, we've been successful in elevating the discussion about a carbon fee on the fossil fuel industry and a return (rebate) of that money to the American people. Getting legislation at the Federal level is crucial in our fight to lower greenhouse gas emissions. Pricing carbon wil stimulate and energize the renewable energy sector, helping create a speedy transition to a strong economy based on clean energy.

In June we have an international CCL conference, Creating a Climate for Change, and lobbying event in DC. All attendees are responsible for paying their own way. Our Santa Fe group is short on funds to attend that meeting. We hope to raise at least $1000 to offset the cost (airfare, hotel, transportation)of getting a couple of our members there.
 
We know that the relationships we form at this event, and the collaboration between groups across the US and Canada, all working on the same goal will be invaluable to help us grow as a group.
 
We can learn from our counterparts without reinventing the wheel, and with climate change is bearing down on us, we don't have time to waste.
 

We need your help!!

Please help us get to Washington DC in June for this conference. All funds collected will be distributed to the group members attending the conference to pay for expenses.

Any small donation is appreciated!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t contribute...

  • Click here to go to Citizens Climate Lobby and start or join a group. This is an all hands-on deck moment for humans as climate change and how we respond to it is the defining issue of our time. Join us!!
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools and share our campaign with those you know.

 

"If you want to join the fight to save the planet, to save creation for your grandchildren, there is no more effective step you could take than becoming an active member of this group."- Dr. James Hansen

story:
What We Do

Show Me Green Coal has identified ways to transform waste material from urban and rural communities (or biomass for a more scientific term) into “torrefied” products, sometimes referred to as green coal. Green coal brings environmentally friendly solutions to a number of industries, useful in the following ways:

  • As a soil amendment — includes farming, lawn and garden and golf course management applications;  
  • In the plastics industry — for use as a low-cost filler but with additional product attributes such as the ability to repel water;  
  • As activated charcoal — it can be used to remove pollutants (e.g. sequestration of mercury) from the air (e.g. smoke stacks in coal plants) and/or from municipal water treatment facilities; and
  • As a sustainable source of energy — used in the form of pellets for wood stoves, as a substitute for coal in utility plants,  and/or as a way to power generators used on farms and in small commercial operations.

Biomass materials such as switchgrass, green wood chips, crop stover or even manure are abundantly available in the nation’s heartland. In addition, waste from nearby urban communities, such as grass clippings, tree trimmings, saw dust and waste lumber, can be diverted from city landfills and added to the mix. 

Piped into a dryer, a gasifer and a torrefication reactor, the biomass material is spit out in the form of pellets, powder or coal-like briquettes. While Europe has been using this technology for decades, America continues to slumber. You can help! 

The Show Me Green Coal team knows that: 

  • The technology exists;
  • Our country has an abundance of natural resources for the right ingredients;  
  • We have the human capacity; and
  • We have evidence of financial viability. 

What we need now is your help so Show Me Green Coal can take the next step!

Who We Are

Joel and Jim, the founders of Show Me Green Coal, were born and raised in Missouri and have extensive knowledge of land and land uses, connections in rural farming communities, business experience, and a passion for sustainable energy.

Founded in 2009, Show Me Green Coal has been doing research and feasibility studies to discover the best technology and the best site to launch their dream — a plant to manufacture and market torrefied biochar.


Jim Downey, Co-founder

Jim has a proven track record of business development and execution in both domestic and global environments. He is owner and manager of James Downy Appraisal, specializing in appraising agricultural properties. He has extensive knowledge of the land and the farming community in northwest Missouri. Jim received his Bachelor of Science degree from Missouri Western State College, and has served with the United States Marine Corps. 

Joel Brummel, Co-founder

Joel has both a Bachelor of Science Degree in Agricultural Economics and a Master’s Degree in Horticulture and Forestry from Kansas State University.  His background includes numerous partnerships with real estate and land development companies in the Midwest — bringing together his expertise in both business operations and land management. Joel served as company commander in combat operations in the United States Marine Corps and was awarded the Bronze star and Purple Heart for his actions.

It takes a village to start a revolution. Here is a list of experts who are on their team to make this project work:

  • D.E. Shinn, PE, Overland Park, Kansas - Engineering
  • Polsinelli Shugart, Kansas City, Missouri - Legal
  • Bill Arthaud - Government Affairs
  • Hagen & Partners, Leawood, Kansas - Marketing & Community Relations
  • Bill Taylor, Taylor and Company LLC -  Business Advisor
  • Jay Lang, CFO, LifeLine Foods

We Need You!

The company’s ultimate goal is to develop a biomass torrefaction production facility in the midwest (for starters)  that will employ more than 60 workers with an estimated payroll of $2.5 million dollars. Besides generating electrical and thermal power, the torrefied biomass and biochar products produced at the facility will be used in a variety of ways including as a soil amendment, in the plastics and polymer industries and as pellets to be used as a clean burning energy source.

We have invested our own personal funds and received one state grant.  Yet our start-up expenses continue to mount. We need to raise at least $15,000 to help with the legal, admin and research fees necessary to get us to the next level. 

If we keep doing what we’re doing we’ll keep getting what we’ve got. Isn’t it time to try something new?

If you want to be a part of the green revolution and change the way America thinks about energy, you can!  No matter how much you contribute — a little or a lot — you become a catalyst for change. Thank you in advance for your help and support. We look forward to hearing from you.

Other Ways to Make a Difference

There are other ways you can help. Here are two simple things you can do:

  • The old fashioned way — tell your like-minded friends about us! Give them this link; or
  • The social media way — spread the news of this campaign through Facebook, your Twitter account or via email; see the links above for easy sharing!

For more information, go to www.ShowMeGreenCoal.com.

story:
A Brief History...

Sarah Wilson and Luca Budello created Shallow Waters in early 2011. Our backgrounds in conservation, environmental science, scuba diving and science communication came together in the development of this community focused coral reef conservation project. 

 

 


Our Method.

Over the past five years we have personally experienced the massive decline in the availability of academic funding for independent science and conservation projects such as ours. Having directly benefitted from volunteer conservation work ourselves, and knowing the difference that practical experience makes to your personal development, skills sets (and your CV!), we decided the best possible method for everyone involved was to fund our research in the long term through volunteer research assistants. 


The Impact.

The area around Koh Sdach is currently being developed as one of 'the next big' tourist destinations in Cambodia and already there are noticeable impacts from the mainland such as sediment run off from deforestation into the ocean. These fast growing tourist developments added to the ongoing problems of overfishing, illegal fishing methods and a lack of refuse disposal systems means the local coral reefs and fish stocks are under serious threat. 

 

Both the local and national governments are aware and supportive of the need to develop in an environmentally and socially conscious way. However, the countries lack of funds and in-country NGO's focussed on the needs of marine management means that groups such as Shallow Waters are well placed to fill an important gap in this process.

 

 

The nitty gritty...

We are looking to raise $10,000 to complete the second phase of our operations, these funds will be used to set up and develop our key project areas:

 

1. Community education and youth projects, this will include presentations at the local school, snorkelling lessons, beach clean ups and creative workshops.

 

2. Research equipment including computers and specialised hardware, under-water survey tools, microscopes and laboratory instruments.

 

3. Stakeholder workshops: in order to create a community fishery organisation, workshops that bring together the fishermen and other stakeholders of Koh Sdach to allow open discussion, awareness and cooperation are vital. This will create the foundation for submitting an application to the regional Fishery Cantonment for creating a recognised community fishery organisation. We will run these workshops in collaboration with the Fishery Cantonment and Wildlife Conservation Cambodia.

 

We have been through The Rufford Foundation's rigorous application process and were awarded a small grant for conservation to complete phase 1 of our project (see Luca's project profile here), now we need your help to get ourselves securely into phase 2. 

 

Perk Info

 *Unique wildlife photography by Cristian Dimitrius - contributors who choose to take home one of Cristian's fantastic wilflife images will be sent an email with the image choices once their payment is confirmed. Check out this sample!!!

 

 

**Your choice of Air Swimmer will be posted from the UK and contributors will incur the costs dependant on location.

 

***Stephane Delapree's paintings are iconic here in Cambodia. They capture this colourful land with images of everyday life, one of his limited edition serigraphs is a true collectors item. Keep watching for a video update of an interview with Stephane at his studio in Phnom Penh.


****Both final perks can be tailored to your requirements, whether you are a qualified or non-diver, it's an amazing opportunity to come out and meet the people, do some diving, get involved with the community and experience practical conservation first hand! For more information about the expedition and internship activities you will get to experience have a look at the website.


Other Ways You Can Help...

We are all about the DIWO! (Do It With Others) so please spread the word about our campaign, Facebook, Twitter, your own blog or website. Tell your friends and family to come and join Shallow Waters online community and get updates on the campaign, our project and important ocean science going on around the world, the more the merrier! Check out our website, Facebook page and follow us on Twitter.

 

Any Questions?

Please get in touch if you have any questions regarding the project, perks, donations, or just to say Hi!

Email: sarah@shallow-waters.co.uk

Skype: shallow.waters.info

Tel: +855 (0) 11 39 45 45

 

 

We Would Like to Thank Our Supporters and Partners

story:
My name is Shelley harding, and I am a mother of three gorgeous children, Brittany, Cheyenne and Dillon. They are the loves of my life, along with my husband Rich. My son Dillon has had the worst bed for MONTHS now. It falls apart all the time, and we have to fix it all thew time. All he has been asking for is a new bed, with more "grown up" bedding. He will be 13 this year, and has outgrown his Mario themed bedroom. This is so important to me and to him, because that stupid bed of his literally falls apart at the seams. You guys helping me would mean so much, because then my son could sleep and sit on his new bed in peace!

 

The bed I found is $400 on the Walmart site, and then bedding, which I would let him pick out once I get the money, runs anywhere from $30 to $150 dollars (for a bed in a bag set).I am hoping to raise $600 to cover the cost of the bed, shipping, and some money for the bedding set he would need. Here is the link if you would like to see the bed I am hoping for. http://www.walmart.com/ip/Charleston-Storage-Lo...

 

You will help us to be able to get Dillon a new bed and bedding set, and he would be so excited to recieve this! I am trying to surprise him by taking him up to get the bedding once money is raised.

We lived on a fixed income because my husband Rich is disabled due to Cancer, and I stay home to take care of him. So Dillon got this hand me down bed which is horrible.

Most times, he sleeps on his mattress in the living room, because the bed comes apart at the seam on the top by the headboard. If I do not reach my entire goal, I will save up every extra penny I have to be able to get this for him. It's all he has been asking for, even for his birthday in July.

 

The Impact

You would be helping Dillon get the one thing he wants the most, and put a smile on his face. He would also be excited to go to bed again! I have raised money before for children who need it, so I am sure I can do everything in my power to try to get this for my son. I will pay it forward as much as I can (with our fixed income is gets hard at times) but I am willing to help someone else in need when we can!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help money wise, there are other ways you can help! Shout this out on facebook or email to your friends and family, and pass it along, so we can get as much help as we need! Word of mouth is just as fantastic as helping by donating money. Indiegogo tools are a great way to share with your friends and family!

story:
We're the Backwards Girls...

Hola! This is neroL, eniloraC, sixelA, and amlA. Simply, we're the Backwards Girls :) We're all freshman in high school, we all come from different backgrounds, and we all share a common goal... we want to travel to the coast of Florida this summer and experience something totally new! We will be going step-by-step outside our comfort zone and strenghthening the bonds of our friendship!  Be it getting over the fear of claustrophobia or being self-conscious about her body, we're ready for this! BUT, we can't do this without your help, O Simply Fantabulous Contributors! Our goal is to raise $2,500 and we need your help, even if you donate 5 dollars, every little bit counts! :)

 

Number Crunching & Your Symbolic Vacation...

Simply put, we need 2,500 dollars. The amount we raise will go directly towards either the transportation fees or the preparations to go to Florida.  If we happen to not raise enough money or there is a zombie apocolyse that threatens the end of the human race, the Backwards Girls will meet up and discuss and we'll post an update. We cannot offer a jar filled with Florida sand or money or pirate treasures or illegal baby turtles but we CAN do something symbolic... for every contributor, whether you donate 5 dollars or 500, we will tie a red ribbon around the handle of each of our suitcases that we are taking with us to Floruda. So when we leave Georgia, you will be symbolically going to Florida with us and experiencing everything, too! <3 Bon Voyage~

 

What if We Don't...

raise enough money? All the money we raise will go directly towards either the transportation fees or preparations. Nothing else, nothing more, we pinkie promise! <3 

Instead of Lunch @ Mickey D's...

We appreciate any kind of donation and we can't experience any of this educational, environmental, emotional, and encouraging program without YOUR help! If you could spread the word to fellow co-workers, church go-ers, golf buddies, neighbors, Starbucks drinkers, tea drinkers, Pinterest posters, Instagram lovers, Snapchat users, cake pop bakers, iPhone users, Android toters, homework do-ers. exercise buddies, family, friends, and/or facebook/twitter buddies, we would appreciate it!

 

THANK YOU VERY MUCH, love the Backwards Girls <3
story_txt:
We're the Backwards Girls...
Hola! This is neroL, eniloraC, sixelA, and amlA. Simply, we're the Backwards Girls :) We're all freshman in high school, we all come from different backgrounds, and we all share a common goal... we want to travel to the coast of Florida this summer and experience something totally new! We will be going step-by-step outside our comfort zone and strenghthening the bonds of our friendship!  Be it getting over the fear of claustrophobia or being self-conscious about her body, we're ready for this! BUT, we can't do this without your help, O Simply Fantabulous Contributors! Our goal is to raise $2,500 and we need your help, even if you donate 5 dollars, every little bit counts! :)
 
Number Crunching & Your Symbolic Vacation...
Simply put, we need 2,500 dollars. The amount we raise will go directly towards either the transportation fees or the preparations to go to Florida.  If we happen to not raise enough money or there is a zombie apocolyse that threatens the end of the human race, the Backwards Girls will meet up and discuss and we'll post an update. We cannot offer a jar filled with Florida sand or money or pirate treasures or illegal baby turtles but we CAN do something symbolic... for every contributor, whether you donate 5 dollars or 500, we will tie a red ribbon around the handle of each of our suitcases that we are taking with us to Floruda. So when we leave Georgia, you will be symbolically going to Florida with us and experiencing everything, too! <3 Bon Voyage~
 

What if We Don't...
raise enough money? All the money we raise will go directly towards either the transportation fees or preparations. Nothing else, nothing more, we pinkie promise! <3 
Instead of Lunch @ Mickey D's...
We appreciate any kind of donation and we can't experience any of this educational, environmental, emotional, and encouraging program without YOUR help! If you could spread the word to fellow co-workers, church go-ers, golf buddies, neighbors, Starbucks drinkers, tea drinkers, Pinterest posters, Instagram lovers, Snapchat users, cake pop bakers, iPhone users, Android toters, homework do-ers. exercise buddies, family, friends, and/or facebook/twitter buddies, we would appreciate it!
 
THANK YOU VERY MUCH, love the Backwards Girls <3

story:
Our goal is to help make the world a greener place.

GREENWILL is a socially-driven environmental initiative being spearheaded by EuCham – European Chamber, a non-profit organization with members representing some 370,000 businesses and partners.  We are based in Budapest but have global ambitions. We have an established presence in over 25 countries worldwide.  We’re looking to spread the word starting in our own backyard through the use of storefront stickers, similar to Foursquare, Yelp, TripAdvisor, etc.

Nowadays consumers find it difficult to distinguish which businesses and organisations are acting in an environmentally friendly manner. Our stickers, signifying who has adopted GREENWILL, will give consumers the ability to distinguish and choose to support those acting in a greener way. Our strategy is to create a mutually re-enforced cyclical effect to make the world a greener place. As more consumers are empowered to "vote with their feet" they will pressure more and more businesses to want to become more environmentally responsible.

We are looking for €500 for stickers to give to businesses to put in their front windows advertising themselves as GREENWILL pledgers. We're not asking for money so much for 'stickers', but to ensure consumers will know that a business or organization has pledged GREENWILL and started taking steps to improve its environmental footprint. Any surplus funds we receive will be used for other marketing materials (eg flyers, banners, etc.), but the primary objective is to purchase stickers for pledgers to further spread the word about GREENWILL. 

We're field testing this concept in a pilot city, Budapest, located in the center of Europe, with the intention to replicate this model in cities around the world. This campaign is a test run to create something that causes a global impact.

Any and all donation amounts are welcome and much appreciated!  With your help, we can further our initiative and help make the world cleaner and greener today, and more importantly, for future generations!

Of course, we would love for you to donate to this specific campaign.  However, if you are unable to we completely understand.  You can still help us by visiting our website at greenwill.org and becoming a partner by pledging to our cause or volunteering to work with us.

story:
Naissance du projet

 

·         En 2012, j'ai pris connaissance dans un journal suisse de l'idée de Mr. Domjean (première personne ayant fait le tour du monde en bateau solaire)  de faire naviguer un bateau solaire sur le lac Titicaca.

L’idée m’a vraiment parue magique pour le Pérou,  pays qui depuis 15 ans est le mien et où j'ai monté mon agence de voyage.  Je n’ai pas hésité à le contacter pour le dire mon enthousiasme et mon envie de participer à ce magnifique projet.

·        En 2013, Mr. Domjan est venu au Pérou. Nous avons pu tester la fiabilité du projet sur place. Puis , à LIMA, nous avons obtenu audience auprès de certains ministères et autres autorités pour leur présenter le projet et voir l'intérêt qu'il suscite pour le Pérou. Les réactions furent prometteuses.

·Bertrand Muller (et Mr. Domjan), sur Amantani pour voir le potentiel des panneaux solaires.       

En 2014, c’est le lancement officiel du projet avec la recherche de fonds en Suisse et un peu au Pérou.

·        En 2015 Après avoir parlé avec Mr. Domjan, nous nous mettons d'accord pour que je prenne en charge le projet à mon compte.

·        En 2016, Nous avons décidé de racheter un bateau solaire qui a été construit pour l'exposition de Séville, de le remettre en état optimal et de le transporter soit en bateau (containers) soit naviguant jusqu'au Pérou, faire certaines modifications à Lima et de le transporter sur le Lac Titicaca.

Nous sommes donc dans la phase financement actuellement, par le biais d'Indiegogo. La priorité est d'acheter le bateau, le reste des fonds servira pour l'aménagement et l'amélioration du bateau avant sa navigation sur le Lac.

·        En 2017, navigation de notre bateau sur le lac Titicaca

 

 

SITUATION SUR LE LAC TITICACA

Aujourd’hui, les habitants des îles du lac vivent en autarcie et avec des moyens limités. Ils n’ont pas d’électricité et aucun service médical n’est organisé.

 

Le trafic indigène entre les îles et Puno, la principale ville du lac, est assuré par service régulier, mais seulement deux fois par jour.

Tous les bateaux sont privés et beaucoup naviguent« à la demande » : le départ ne se fait qu’à partir d’un nombre minimum de passagers. Malgré ce manque d’organisation il y a, selon les statistiques du port de Puno et suivant les mois, entre 1 000 et 4 000 « nationaux » qui entrent ou sortent du port chaque mois.

Le lac Titicaca est un haut-lieu touristique. La région est déclarée « Reserva National Del Titicaca » depuis 1978. Elle attire entre 150 000 et 180 000 touristes par an (statistique du port de Puno entre 2005 et 2013). Ceci, tout au long de l’année, avec un léger creux en février, en octobre et en novembre.

Au Pérou, la quasi-totalité du trafic touristique sur le lac se fait au départ de Puno vers les îles flottantes d’Uros, les plus rapprochées, et les îles d’Amantani et de Taquilé.

Actuellement, il y 150 embarcations  dans le port de Puno. Environ 100 bateaux à moteur diesel sont dédiés au service touristique. Le 1/3 restant est constitué de bateaux de pêcheurs, généralement à rames et à voile. Il y a encore 6 bateaux rapides appartenant à des agences de voyages basées à Lima. Les bateaux touristiques embarquent entre 16 et 44 personnes. Durant la haute saison, 30 à 50 bateaux naviguent journellement vers l’île de Taquilé et une dizaine vers l’île d’Amantani. Tous les bateaux s’arrêtent sur les îles flottantes.

Ce service motorisé a un coût très important pour les insulaires. Au Pérou, le prix d’un litre de diesel est d’environ $ 1.30. Si le salaire moyen du pays est de $ 490.- par mois, bien peu d’habitants des îles gagnent plus de $ 200.- par mois. Lorsqu’il trouve un embarquement vers l’île de Taquilé, un habitant paie en moyenne $ 30.- l’aller-retour. De plus, l’impact écologique est également important : un bateau diesel consomme entre 80 et 100 litres par jour de navigation, un bateau rapide 120 à 150 litres.

Un autre problème important du lac Titicaca est une lentille d’eau (Lemna gibba) qui est en train de coloniser la surface du lac. Sa densité bloque les rayons du soleil, empêchant la photosynthèse. La vie aquatique se meurt. La cause n’est pas uniquement attribuée au trafic motorisé mais à l’absence d’usine de traitement des eaux usées.

A ce jour, aucun bateau solaire, ni électrique ne navigue sur le lac.

Pourtant, en raison de l’altitude, l’ensoleillement est plus important qu’au niveau de la mer. Il fait froid et le rendement de panneaux solaires est plus efficace. L’ensoleillement moyen annuel est de 8,2 heures par jour. Les distances entre les rives et les îles permettraient une utilisation idéale d’un bateau solaire. Les conditions sont toutes réunies pour faire de notre projet un exemple à suivre et à développer.

Le bateau    

Le bateau  est un Aquabus C60 d'occasion qui a été construit en 2001, par l'architecte  Jean Nouvel qui souhaitait un mode de transport moderne et original pour aller visiter le Monolithe de Morat durant l'Expo 02. Ce bateau faisait partie d'une flotte de 4 catamarans, dont les 3 autres sont aussi toujours en navigation (Lac Majeur en Italie, Genève, et Chichester Harbour en GB).  Cette flotte avait transporté plus d'un million de passagers en 2002, sans aucun soucis! 

Les modification sera fait par l’entreprise  Custer Yatch à Lima.

Il s’agit d’un catamaran pour 48 personnes, avec une terrasse pour profiter d'une belle vue et d’être à l’abri en cas de mauvais temps.La cabine peut être convertie en cabinet médical. Autres équipements :2 salles de bains pour le bien-être des participants, un bar et une boutique de souvenirs, 4 téléviseurs avec système Bluetooth pour pouvoir profiter d’un des autres avantages d’un moteur électrique, le silence.

Équipé aux normes de sécurité européennes.

Certificat Officina bateau Veritas

Générateur de secours Hybride pour permettre de retourner au port si les conditions météorologique l’imposent.

Potentiel solaire: batterie pleine: 8 heures soit une distance possible de parcours  de 80 km à une vitesse de 10 kilomètres par heure.

2 heures supplémentaires avec l'énergie solaire avec production de panneaux de navire.

Autonomie Générateur de 40 litres de capacité, soit une production de suffisante pour 10 heures de navigation.

 

BUDGET DU BATEAU

Achat  du bateau d'occasion                        100000€

Remise en état et batteries                           20000€

Transfert entre l'Europe et le Pérou           20000€

Transport Lima - Lac Titicaca                       5000€                   

Participation d'Indiegogo                               5000€

TOTAL: 150000€

BUDGET EXTRA si fonds supplémentaire du Crowdfunding

Modification de toute la Cabine                  50000€

Changement du moteur                                40000€

ÉVÉNEMENTS

Mise à l'eau (inauguration)                           20000€

 

Mon histoire 

Dans la vie, il y a des rencontres qui ne s'oublient pas et qui sûrement conditionnent notre futur. Ma rencontre avec ce guide de Cuzco dans mes jeunes années, ainsi que le dessin animé " Les Cités d'or" que je regardais chaque mercredi après-midi, ont sûrement contribué à tout cela, à mon amour pour le Pérou.

Après un apprentissage dans une agence de voyages de la place Lausannoise, je me suis vraiment convaincu que le monde des voyages était fait pour moi. J’ai travaillé dans plusieurs grandes agences suisses et en ai profité pour faire de nombreux voyages dans le monde.

Après un long périple sur le continent américain qui s'est terminé au Pérou, j'ai décidé que ce pays deviendrait le mien.  Un retour en Suisse pour préparer ma nouvelle vie et me voici de retour au Pérou depuis 2000, date où j'ai ouvert une agence de voyage avec laquelle j’ai travaillé avec de nombreuses agences suisses et françaises.

Maintenant que mon agence tourne, j’ai un peu de temps pour me consacrer à d’autres projets.
