story:
WHY THE REVOLUTION?
At the last Green Gathering lots of people asked"Why is a Green festival still hiring plastic, chemical-flush loos?"  and "Please can we have more compost loos?"

This year, the answer is YES, we can have more compost loos. We've made a commitment to increase the proportion of compost loos, but it's going to cost
A WHOLE LOT MORE than if we hired all plastic chemi-loos, because of the regs around storage and transport of poo, and because we don't own the land so we can't build permanent structures and will have to hire in flatpack loos.

WHAT'S THE SOLUTION?
Natural Event has agreed to sponsor us, to supply loos that meet the regulations, and to take away and compost our poo, all at a reduced rate because we are sooo Green... However, that reduced rate is still a hefty chunk of our festival budget.

We'd rather not divert funds from other areas of the festival, so we're asking everyone who feels passionate about switching to compost loos to help us make the transition by contributing to the compost loo fund!


We've set up this crowdfunder and are hoping to raise £1000. If you'd like to see loos like those above instead of banks of blue plastic, please contribute.
If you're one of the people who wrote "MORE COMPOST LOOS" on your feedback form - you know who you are and we love you!  Let's do this together.

WHOSE FOOLHARDY IDEA WAS THIS?
It was me, Em Weirdigan, newest Green Gathering director and arch champion of compost loos! I've spent many, many hours over the last 12 months persuading everyone at GG HQ that switching to compost loos should be a Green Gathering priority. Poo or art? Poo or music? Poo or solar panels? See, it's tough.

I talked everyone round in the end - I went on about poo so much that I was given free rein to go ahead and take up Natural Event's offer of sponsorship. This sponsorship has reduced the cost of the toilets, but we're still looking at considerably more money than we'd be paying for portable plastic loos, so I was also given a budget.

Woohoo!

Unfortunately, the budget isn't quite enough to meet the costs of the loos. Hence this appeal to Green Gatherers, Green Gathering supporters and any random fellow arch-compost-loo-champions to help me out.

Every £1 will help, every £10 will take a weight off my shoulders, if anyone can afford more than that - wonderful! I'll kickstart the campaign myself with what I can afford to put in, because I really, really want this to happen.


SOME BACKGROUND
The Green Gathering is trying to do something authentic and different. It's run by a staunchly non-commercial CIC (Community Interest Company) and combines eco-activism, holistic wellbeing and education for sustainability, as well as all the usual shenanigans and tomfoolery of a festival. The Gathering is an annual long weekend of temporary community, network building and fun, with repercussions that go well beyond that one weekend on that one Welsh hillside.

We struggle to challenge the current capitalist system while necessarily having to engage with it in order to hold the festival. We do our best to keep ticket prices relatively low while creating a magical and inspiring experience for participants... and of course jumping through all the legal and licensing hoops required to hold a 5000-person event.


Lots of wonderful people put huge amounts of time and energy into The Green Gathering, all year round in the planning and then in a tremendous burst of creative energy on site. Some people provide expertise and kit and get paid for that, generally at well below the going market rate. Many others volunteer, for the fun of it and because we know that every year, people's eyes are opened and lives transformed by this very special event.

The Green Gathering is not run to make a profit; if the event makes a surplus, we've pledged to put that into the Green Gathering Charity, which has an 'education for sustainability' remit. To be honest, we're a way off making a surplus.

Which is why I'm asking you to help us, and contribute to this crowdfund.


WHAT YOU GET
As well as knowing that your poo is going to a good home, you get perks!
Thankyous and mugs and programmes and cider... all this can be yours :)

WHAT IF WE DON'T MAKE THE TARGET? Or make more than the target?!
All the money will go towards compost loos, however much we raise.

If we miss the target we'll still take up Natural Event's offer of sponsorship and we'll still have compost loos, but the budgetary balance between art and poo will be tricky, and we won't be able to transition as neatly and wholeheartedly as we'd like.

If you give more than a £1000, then we'll have more compost loos and fewer loo-queues - and plenty of art - and that can never be a bad thing!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP
We do understand that times are tough, and that there are many worthy causes clamouring for your crowdfund pound.

If you don't feel able to contribute to this crowdfunder, please spread the word.
Tell friends, share on facebook, tweet, shout from your rooftop, add a link in emails.

Oh, and if you have contributed, please spread the word too. Tell the world!
Thankyou.
story_txt:
WHY THE REVOLUTION?At the last Green Gathering lots of people asked"Why is a Green festival still hiring plastic, chemical-flush loos?"  and "Please can we have more compost loos?" This year, the answer is YES, we can have more compost loos. We've made a commitment to increase the 
proportion of compost loos, but it's going to cost A WHOLE LOT MORE than if we
 hired all plastic chemi-loos, because of the regs around storage and 
transport of poo, and because we don't own the land so we can't build permanent structures and will have to hire in flatpack 
loos.WHAT'S THE SOLUTION?
Natural Event has
 agreed to sponsor us, to supply loos that meet the regulations, and to take 
away and compost our poo, all at a reduced rate because we are sooo 
Green... However, that reduced rate is still a hefty chunk of our festival budget.
 We'd rather not divert funds from other areas of the festival, so we're asking everyone
 who feels passionate about switching to compost loos to help us make 
the transition by contributing to the compost loo fund!



We've set up this crowdfunder and are hoping to raise £1000. If you'd like 
to see loos like those above instead of banks of blue plastic, please 
contribute. If you're one of the people who wrote "MORE COMPOST LOOS" on your feedback form - you know who you are and we love you!  Let's do this together.WHOSE FOOLHARDY IDEA WAS THIS?It was me, Em Weirdigan, newest Green Gathering director and arch champion of compost loos! I've spent many, many hours over the last 12 months persuading everyone at GG HQ that switching to compost loos should be a Green Gathering priority. Poo or art? Poo or music? Poo or solar panels? See, it's tough.I talked everyone round in the end - I went on about poo so much that I was given free rein to go ahead and take up Natural Event's offer of sponsorship. This sponsorship has reduced the cost of the toilets, but we're still looking at considerably more money than we'd be paying for portable plastic loos, so I was also given a budget.Woohoo! Unfortunately, the budget isn't quite enough to meet the costs of the loos. Hence this appeal to Green Gatherers, Green Gathering supporters and any random fellow arch-compost-loo-champions to help me out.Every £1 will
 help, every £10 will take a weight off my shoulders, if anyone can 
afford more than that - wonderful! I'll kickstart the campaign myself with what I can afford to put in, because I really, really want this to happen.
SOME BACKGROUNDThe Green Gathering is trying to do something authentic and different. It's run by a staunchly non-commercial CIC (Community Interest Company) and combines eco-activism, holistic wellbeing and education for sustainability, as well as all the usual shenanigans and tomfoolery of a festival. The Gathering is an annual long weekend of temporary community, network building and fun, with repercussions that go well beyond that one weekend on that one Welsh hillside.We struggle to challenge the current capitalist system while necessarily having to engage with it in order to hold the festival. We do our best to keep ticket prices relatively low while creating a magical and inspiring experience for participants... and of course jumping through all the legal and licensing hoops required to hold a 5000-person event.
Lots of wonderful people put huge amounts of time and energy into The Green Gathering, all year round in the planning and then in a tremendous burst of creative energy on site. Some people provide expertise and kit and get paid for that, generally at well below the going market rate. Many others volunteer, for the fun of it and because we know that every year, people's eyes are opened and lives transformed by this very special event. The Green Gathering is not run to make a profit; if the event makes a surplus, we've pledged to put that into the Green Gathering Charity, which has an 'education for sustainability' remit. To be honest, we're a way off making a surplus.Which is why I'm asking you to help us, and contribute to this crowdfund.
WHAT YOU GETAs well as knowing that your poo is going to a good home, you get perks!Thankyous and mugs and programmes and cider... all this can be yours :)WHAT IF WE DON'T MAKE THE TARGET? Or make more than the target?!All the money will go towards compost loos, however much we raise. If we miss the target we'll still take up Natural Event's offer of sponsorship and we'll still have compost loos, but the budgetary balance between art and poo will be tricky, and we won't be able to transition as neatly and wholeheartedly as we'd like. If you give more than a £1000, then we'll have more compost loos and fewer loo-queues - and plenty of art - and that can never be a bad thing!OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELPWe do understand that times are tough, and that there are many worthy causes clamouring for your crowdfund pound.If you don't feel able to contribute to this crowdfunder, please spread the word. Tell friends, share on facebook, tweet, shout from your rooftop, add a link in emails.Oh, and if you have contributed, please spread the word too. Tell the world!Thankyou.

story:
SUMMARY/RÉSUMÉ:

I am Jade, a 20 years old art student. I'm studying in Computation Arts at Concordia University, because of that I'm always working on my computer but I'm sick of the digital world.
I want to rediscover nature like when I was young.
I booked my flight for Iceland in May. I don't want to be constrained to any schedule, so I decided to take my bike with me to travel around the island for 30 days where I'll explore the King Road.
It will be a physical performance where I'll need to pedal 60 km per day.
I'll be alone for this project. It is important for me so that I can reconnect again with my body and with nature.
For the creative part, I have many ideas, like building a disposable camera headset on my bike helmet so that I can take 360 degree shots of my surroundings. But I want to focus on the journey, so all my creative outcome will result from the 30 days experience.

/////////////////////////

Je me présente, Jade, je suis une jeune étudiante en arts numériques à l'Université Concordia,

Je travaille constamment sur mon ordinateur à cause de mes études et je suis fatiguée du monde digital. Je veux redécouvrir la nature comme quand j'étais jeune. J'ai pris un billet d'avion pour l'Islande au mois de mai.
Je ne veux pas être contrainte à aucune sorte d'agenda, j'ai donc décidé de prendre mon vélo pour parcourir l'ile durant 30 jours où j'explorerai la route du Roi (1500km).
Cela sera une performance physique où je vais devoir pédaler 60 km par jour.
Je serai seule durant ce projet. C'est important pour reconnecter de nouveau avec mon corps, ainsi qu'avec la nature.
Pour la partie créative, j'ai beaucoup d'idées, comme construire un casque de caméras jetables que je mettrai sur mon casque de vélo pour prendre des photos panoramiques de mon environnement sur 360 degrés.
Mais je veux focuser sur le parcours, donc tous les résultats de ma créativité prendront essence dans cette expérience de 30 jours.

MY GOALS ARE TO:

Be creative with the available ressources
Reach my limits
Loose notion of time
Feel each and every muscle in my body
Live for myself

/////////////////////////


MES BUTS SONT DE:

Être créative avec les ressources disponibles
Pousser ma limite physique
Perdre la notion du temps
Sentir chaque muscle de mon corps
Vivre pour moi


WHAT I NEED / CE QUE J'AI BESOIN:

Bike Equipment/Équipement de Vélo:
- bike on board/vélo à bord: 150$
- Kevlar tires/pneu Kevlar: 100$
- emergency inner tube/chambre à air de secours: 15$
- tool kit/boite à outils: 20$
- chain/chaine: 10$
- portable pump/pompe portable: 30$
- brake cables/cable de frein: 6$
- handlebar tape/ guidoline: 30$
- lights and reflectors/lumières et réflecteurs: 30$

Clothing/Vêtements:
- waterproof bike bag/sac imperméable de vélo: 100$
- waterproof gloves/gants imperméables: 30$
- waterproof pants/pantalon imperméable: 40$
- raincoat/imperméable: 60$

Camping equipment:
- one-person tent/ tente une place: 100$
- camping stove/réchaud: 30$

Creative equipment:
- disposable waterproof camera/camera jetable imperméable: 13$
- sound recorder/enregistreur: 60$


HOW CAN YOU HELP/COMMENT VOUS POUVEZ AIDER:

I'm not going to purchase all this equipment, it is too expensive.
I'm looking for people who could lend me things I need during my trip, or people who could give me tips and tricks to bike travel.
If you would like to help another way than financially, don't hesitate to contact me: jadeseguela@hotmail.com

/////////////////////////

Je ne vais pas acheter tout cet équipement, cela serait beaucoup trop cher.
Je cherche des gens qui pourraient me prêter des choses dont j'ai besoin pour la période du voyage, ou qui pourraient me donner des trucs et astuces sur les voyages en vélo.
Si vous voulez aider autrement que financièrement, n'hésitez pas à me contacter: jadeseguela@hotmail.com



Thank you all so much,
I'm a super excited child,
Kindly,
Jade.

Merci à vous tous,
Je suis un enfant super excité,
Au plaisir,
Jade.

PS: I won't bring back rocks. I didn't realize when I was filming that it was problematic. I don't want to disturb the environment.
PS: Je ne vais pas ramener des roches. Je n'avais pas réaliser quand je filmais que c'étais problématique. Je ne veux pas perturber l'environnement.

story:
Hi, I am David Ha'ivri. If you are seeing this campaign, you have probably been following my work via social media, Facebook, Twitter or E-mail notification, or you have met me in real life and we interact in one way or another on a regular basis.


Over the past few years, my work advocating for Israel has taken me around the world, speaking to groups and lobbying in international capitals. However, I am happiest when my feet are on the ground here in Israel's Heartland - Judea and Samaria, the home of my family and the land that our fathers walked on so many years ago.


I am glad to share with you an amazing opportunity that has come my way. Through the framework of my academic studies at the University of Ariel, I have been approved to take part in the archaeological dig at ancient Shilo.


Below are some quotes and links to news reports on some of the amazing findings that have been unearthed at this dig over the past year.


This is truly exciting - we are actually bringing the search for the Tabernacle and the lost Ark of the Covenant to real life.


The goal of this campaign is to raise support for my tuition and upkeep, to keep me and my research going.


I am offering you different levels of partnership, information and prayer at this very significant biblical location. According to your choice of perks, you will receive updates, pictures, acknowledgement and prayers at the holy place.


By the way, one of the most significant sources for the Jewish teaching of prayer, directly to HaShem, is learned from the story of Hannah's prayer at the Tabernacle in Shilo. I will write more about that in future updates from the dig.


So please choose your perk to be part of this special experience.


Thank you,


David Ha'ivri


For decades, archaeologists have been searching for evidence to support the hypothesis that Shiloh served as a religious center in ancient times. Now, a stone altar dated to the Iron Age—the period of Israelite kings—was accidentally exposed during a dig conducted by an archaeological staff officer of the Civil Administration in Judea and Samaria.


The altar was found amid the stones of a wall dated to the Byzantine period. Apparently, the Byzantines removed the altar from its original location in Tel Shiloh and used it to build a structure at the foot of the tel. The discovery is the first tangible evidence that Shiloh was a cultic center prior to and during the First Temple period. Previously, the only evidence for that theory was from descriptions in the Bible about the Tabernacle at the time of Joshua and later in the time of Eli the high priest and the prophet Samuel.

http://www.algemeiner.com- November 20, 2013



An ongoing archaeological dig in the ancient Jewish village of Shilo in Samaria (Shomron) has turned up a stone altar dating back thousands of years.


The altar is believed to date back to the period from roughly 1,200 BCE to 600 CE known as the Iron Age.


More specifically, archaeologists dating it to what some Israeli researchers call the “Israelite era” – the period of time after the nation of Israel entered the land of Israel, and before the destruction of the First Temple.


Shilo was home to the Tabernacle brought with the Jews as they entered the land of Israel. It served as a site of religious pilgrimage until King Solomon’s construction of the First Temple in Jerusalem, centuries later.


Israel National News - November 19, 2013


AAncientJewish Altar Found in Shilo – Arutz 7

ArchaeologistsBelieve They May Have Found Where the Tabernacle Housing the Ark ofthe Covenant Once Stood – The Blaze

In Shiloh, an intriguing discovery alludes to the Tabernacle - Israel HaYom

Tel Shiloh Archaeological Dig Pitcher Suggests Biblical City In Israel Burned To Ground – Huffington Post

Visit Offical Website for the Ancient Shilo Visitors Center

story:
This campaign has ended. Please visit our new campaign. Thanks!

BACKGROUND AND CAMPAIGN OVERVIEW

Drakes Bay Oyster Farm is a historic family farm located in Point Reyes National Seashore, about an hour north of San Francisco, California. The oyster farm has been in operation for over 80 years. The current owners are the Lunnys, a fourth-generation ranching family in Point Reyes, where they also raise grass-fed and organic beef.

The Lunnys purchased this historic oyster farm to revive a part of the community and ensure the health of the estero. The oyster farm provides local jobs and a sustainable food product that supports local businesses and comprises almost 40% of California’s shellfish production. The Lunny family’s stewardship of the oyster farm has resulted in award-winning oysters, and has protected the pristine waters of Drakes Estero and its abundant wildlife. The seals in Drakes Estero have never been more plentiful.

In November 2012, the National Park Service issued a decision that would shut down the business. The oyster farm is contesting that decision, and the case is being appealed to the United States Supreme Court. The Lunnys have won a stay to remain in business while they petition for that hearing.

We need funding to increase awareness of the injustice of this decision. Visible public support is crucial to our cause. As a start, we’ve created a website as a central information resource, and we need to maintain and expand the site, ramp up our online presence, and increase our outreach. 

Telling our story is particularly important in the face of the misinformation being spread by those who want to see the oyster farm shut down. The Park Service and its allies are actively misrepresenting the facts about our farming practices, about the legal and historical issues involved, and about the science of oyster farming. We need funding to successfully counter this misinformation. 


HELP THESE SKILLED WORKERS KEEP THEIR JOBS

Pictured Above: Isela Meza, our staff marine biologist, oversees the handling of microscopic oyster larvae, ensuring that they set and begin to grow properly at the beginning of the oyster-planting process. The photo above shows Isela with a baby oyster in the hatchery.

Drakes Bay Oyster Farm employs 30 full-time workers and provides housing for some of them. Many of these employees have worked at the oyster farm for decades.The historic oyster farm has traditionally been a source of work for the wives of the ranch hands working in this agrarian community, and that continues to this day.

To learn more about these wonderful workers, please visit our Meet the Oyster Workers page on our advocacy site.


LUNNY FAMILY STEWARDSHIP

The Lunnys are one of the ranching and farming families in West Marin that keep this beautiful land connected to its agrarian past and are creating a sustainable future. The Lunny family began dairy ranching in Point Reyes in 1946 and is known for its agricultural innovation.

The Lunny ranch created the first certified organic and certified grass-fed beef herd in Marin County, and was the first beef ranch in California to be certified Salmon Safe for the management of its riparian areas, pastures, and manure. The Lunnys received an Excellence in Rangeland Management award from the Society of Rangeland Management in 2009, and were the first beef ranch in California to receive the Animal Welfare Approved seal for humane treatment of animals.

In late 2004, the Lunnys purchased the historic oyster farm in Drakes Estero from the Johnson family, its previous owners since 1957. The farm dates to the 1930s. The Lunnys named it Drakes Bay Oyster Company, its original name.

The Lunnys are known as careful stewards of the land and water, not only through their own sound farming practices but also with their philanthropic contributions to conservation; donated Lunny oyster shells support both the Snowy Plover habitat restoration efforts of the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory and the NOAA Fisheries San Francisco Bay Native Oyster Habitat Restoration project (news story here).

The Lunny family also provides educational tours of the oyster farm for school groups and for the public, increasing awareness of sustainable farming and educating the public about the importance of a healthy ecosystem.

In 2007, the Lunnys were recognized by the Park Service for environmental stewardship and innovation in its publication Stewardship Begins with People. (See page 45)

To learn more about our stewardship practices, go to our advocacy site.


THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE HAS MISREPRESENTED FACTS

This short video shows how the Park Service has misrepresented the facts about the Lunny family's farming practices and about science, history, and the law.




ABOUT THE LUNNY FAMILY'S PRIZE-WINNING DRAKES BAY OYSTERS

Drakes Bay oysters are famous for being clean and pristine. They have won Most Beautiful Pacific Oyster Award from the National Shellfisheries Association and are in great demand by chefs and retailers. They are featured in San Francisco's finest restaurants, such as Farralon, Waterbar, Hayes Street Grill, Zuni Cafe, Sam's Grill, Swan Oyster Depot, and the Waterfront Restaurant. Drakes Bay oysters are also found in West Marin County's finest restaurants, including The Marshall Store, Nick's Cove, and Osteria Stellina, as well as in many fine wine country locations and a few retail shops. See this list for more details, including links to many restaurants.


HERE ARE FIVE WAYS THAT DRAKES BAY OYSTERS STAND OUT:

1. Locally & Sustainably Grown:The Lunny family is a fourth-generation Marin County farming family, completely committed to sustainable farming practices and local marketing of our oysters.

2. Environmentally Friendly:Drakes Bay Oyster Farm uses environmentally friendly growing techniques, including an off-bottom, Japanese-inspired, “hanging culture” method. Used by less than 5% of U.S. oyster farmers, this method requires labor-intensive hand harvesting, resulting in our uniquely flavored, ultra-clean oysters.

3. Unsurpassed Freshness:Drakes Bay Oysters are grown in the pristine waters of Drakes Estero in Marin County. Because they are harvested, shucked, and packed daily, these award-winning oysters have no equal in freshness.

4. Exceptional Water Quality:Drakes Bay is the only shellfish farm within the Point Reyes National Seashore. Protected by a small, undeveloped watershed, our farm contains California’s finest shellfish water quality—that’s why we are the only farm in California allowed to harvest year- round. The waters of Drakes Estero give our oysters the “taste of their place”!

5. Historical Significance:Drakes Bay Oyster Farm is home to California’s last operating oyster cannery, where we have been shucking and packing our oysters on-farm for over 70 years. By helping to save Drakes Bay Oyster Farm, you are helping to preserve a precious piece of California’s history.


OYSTER FUN FACTS

1.  Oyster farming is 17 times as productive as ranching (in terms of protein per acre). Oyster farming is incredibly efficient, requiring no feed, no fertilizers, no chemicals, no cultivation, and no consumption of fresh water. Drakes Bay Oyster Farm produces 500,000 lbs of shucked oyster meat each year on less than 150 acres of water bottom. It is estimated that it would take more than 30,000 acres of pasture to produce the equivalent amount of protein on a grass-based beef operation.  It takes roughly 12,000 gallons of fresh water to produce one pound of feedlot beef.

2.  Oysters are nature’s best source of the mineral zinc, with up to 100mg per gram (second on the list is ginger root at 7mg per gram). Zinc is good for your skin, good for your immune system, and speeds up healing after an injury.

3.  All oysters are capable of creating pearls, but pearls from edible oysters have no market value. The pearls used in jewelry are from the Feathered Oyster in the Pteriidae family. Over the years, the workers in the Drakes Bay Oyster cannery have found quite a few small pearls. Ask to see them when you visit the oyster farm!

4. Oysters taste like the place they are grown. Just as the same grapes grown in different places have site-specific flavors called “terroir,” the same oysters grown in different places have site-specific flavors, sometimes called “merroir.” The salinity of the water in which they are grown and the specific nature of what the oysters eat contribute to their flavor.  Oyster author Rowan Jacobson has a fun oyster guide at his website:  What Kind of Oyster Eater Are You?  According to this guide, Drakes Bay Oysters appeal to “The Clean Freak:  You prefer filter feeders from pristine waters.” Check out the guide to learn about the handful of other oysters grown in equally pristine places—two of which are in Canadian national parks (Raspberry Points in Prince Edward Island National Park and Imperial Eagle Channels in Pacific Rim National Park).

5.  Oysters clean the water; for this reason oyster restoration efforts are under way. Oysters help waterways by eating algae, filtering out particulates and excess nutrients, and creating habitat for other organisms to thrive. One oyster can filter more than 50 gallons of water in 24 hours. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) is actively promoting oyster restoration, including restoring native oysters in the Chesapeake Bay; these efforts are accelerating, especially in Harris Creek, where 22 acres of reefs were built in 2012, and 34 acres are planned for 2013. Oyster restoration is also under way in Florida,California,and Massachusetts, among other places. The Oyster Restoration Work Group is very active in this area—read about their efforts here.

To learn more about the power of the oyster, go to our advocacy site.


FOR MORE INFORMATION, VISIT OUR WEBSITES

For more information about our cause, please visit our advocacy site: http://savedrakesbay.com/core/

For more information about the oyster farm, including how to visit the farm and where to purchase our award-winning oysters, please visit our business site:  http://drakesbayoyster.com/
story_txt:
This campaign has ended. Please visit our new campaign. Thanks!BACKGROUND AND CAMPAIGN OVERVIEW
Drakes
Bay Oyster Farm is a historic family farm located in Point Reyes National
Seashore, about an hour north of San Francisco, California. The oyster farm has
been in operation for over 80 years. The current owners are the Lunnys, a
fourth-generation ranching family in Point Reyes, where they also raise
grass-fed and organic beef.
The
Lunnys purchased this historic oyster farm to revive a part of the community
and ensure the health of the estero. The oyster farm provides local jobs and a
sustainable food product that supports local businesses and comprises almost
40% of California’s shellfish production. The Lunny family’s stewardship of the
oyster farm has resulted in award-winning oysters, and has protected the
pristine waters of Drakes Estero and its abundant wildlife. The seals in Drakes Estero have never been more plentiful.
In
November 2012, the National Park Service issued a decision that would shut down
the business. The oyster farm is contesting that decision, and the case
is being appealed to the United States Supreme Court. The Lunnys have won a
stay to remain in business while they petition for that hearing.
We
need funding to increase awareness of the injustice of this decision. Visible public support is crucial to our cause. As a start, we’ve created a website
as a central information resource, and we need to maintain and expand the site, ramp up our online presence, and increase our outreach. Telling our story is particularly important in the face of the misinformation being spread by those who want to see the oyster farm shut down. The Park Service and its allies are actively misrepresenting the facts about our farming practices, about the legal and historical issues involved, and about the science of oyster farming. We need funding to successfully counter this misinformation. HELP THESE SKILLED WORKERS KEEP THEIR JOBS
Pictured Above: Isela Meza, our staff marine biologist, oversees the handling of microscopic oyster larvae, ensuring that they set and begin to grow properly at the beginning of the oyster-planting process. The photo above shows Isela with a baby oyster in the hatchery.Drakes Bay Oyster Farm employs 30 full-time workers and provides housing for some of them. Many of these employees have worked at the oyster farm for decades.The
historic oyster farm has traditionally been a source of work for the wives of
the ranch hands working in this agrarian community, and that continues to this
day. To learn more about these wonderful workers, please visit our Meet the Oyster Workers page on our advocacy site.
LUNNY FAMILY STEWARDSHIP
The Lunnys
are one of the ranching and farming families in West Marin that keep this
beautiful land connected to its agrarian past and are creating a sustainable
future. The Lunny family began dairy ranching in Point Reyes in 1946 and is
known for its agricultural innovation.
The
Lunny ranch created the first certified organic and certified grass-fed beef
herd in Marin County, and was the first beef ranch in California to be
certified Salmon Safe for the management of its riparian areas, pastures, and
manure. The Lunnys received an Excellence in Rangeland Management award from
the Society of Rangeland Management in 2009, and were the first beef ranch in
California to receive the Animal Welfare Approved seal for humane treatment of
animals.
In
late 2004, the Lunnys purchased the historic oyster farm in Drakes Estero from
the Johnson family, its previous owners since 1957. The farm dates to the
1930s. The Lunnys named it Drakes Bay Oyster Company, its original name.
The
Lunnys are known as careful stewards of the land and water, not only through
their own sound farming practices but also with their philanthropic contributions
to conservation; donated Lunny oyster shells support both the Snowy Plover habitat restoration efforts of the San Francisco Bay Bird Observatory and
the NOAA Fisheries San Francisco Bay Native Oyster Habitat Restoration project
(news
story here).
The
Lunny family also provides educational tours of the oyster farm for school
groups and for the public, increasing awareness of sustainable farming and
educating the public about the importance of a healthy ecosystem.
In
2007, the Lunnys were recognized by the Park Service for environmental
stewardship and innovation in its publication Stewardship Begins with People. (See
page 45)
To learn more about our stewardship practices, go to our advocacy site. THE NATIONAL PARK SERVICE HAS MISREPRESENTED FACTS
This short video shows how the Park Service has misrepresented the facts
about the Lunny family's farming practices and about science, history, and the law.
ABOUT THE LUNNY FAMILY'S PRIZE-WINNING DRAKES BAY OYSTERSDrakes
Bay oysters are famous for being clean and pristine. They have won Most
Beautiful Pacific Oyster Award from the National Shellfisheries Association and
are in great demand by chefs and retailers. They are featured in San Francisco's finest restaurants, such as Farralon, Waterbar, Hayes Street Grill, Zuni Cafe, Sam's Grill, Swan Oyster Depot, and the Waterfront Restaurant. Drakes Bay oysters are also found in West Marin County's finest restaurants, including The Marshall Store, Nick's Cove, and Osteria Stellina, as well as in many fine wine country locations and a few retail shops. See this list for more details, including links to many restaurants.
HERE ARE FIVE WAYS THAT DRAKES BAY OYSTERS STAND OUT:
1.
Locally & Sustainably Grown:The Lunny family is a fourth-generation Marin County farming family,
completely committed to sustainable farming practices and local marketing of
our oysters.
2.
Environmentally Friendly:Drakes
Bay Oyster Farm uses environmentally friendly growing techniques, including an
off-bottom, Japanese-inspired, “hanging culture” method. Used by less than 5%
of U.S. oyster farmers, this method requires labor-intensive hand harvesting,
resulting in our uniquely flavored, ultra-clean oysters.
3.
Unsurpassed Freshness:Drakes
Bay Oysters are grown in the pristine waters of Drakes Estero in Marin County.
Because they are harvested, shucked, and packed daily, these award-winning
oysters have no equal in freshness.
4.
Exceptional Water Quality:Drakes
Bay is the only shellfish farm within the Point Reyes National Seashore.
Protected by a small, undeveloped watershed, our farm contains California’s
finest shellfish water quality—that’s why we are the only farm in California
allowed to harvest year- round. The waters of Drakes Estero give our oysters
the “taste of their place”!
5.
Historical Significance:Drakes
Bay Oyster Farm is home to California’s last operating oyster cannery, where we
have been shucking and packing our oysters on-farm for over 70 years. By
helping to save Drakes Bay Oyster Farm, you are helping to preserve a precious
piece of California’s history.OYSTER FUN FACTS
1. 
Oyster farming is 17 times as productive as ranching (in terms of protein per acre). Oyster farming is incredibly efficient,
requiring no feed, no fertilizers, no chemicals, no cultivation, and no
consumption of fresh water. Drakes Bay Oyster Farm produces 500,000 lbs of
shucked oyster meat each year on less than 150 acres of water bottom. It is
estimated that it would take more than 30,000 acres of pasture to produce the
equivalent amount of protein on a grass-based beef operation.  It takes
roughly 12,000 gallons of fresh water to produce one pound of feedlot beef.
2. 
Oysters are nature’s best source of the mineral zinc, with
up to 100mg per gram (second on the list is ginger root at 7mg per gram). Zinc
is good for your skin, good for your immune system, and speeds up healing after
an injury.
3. 
All oysters are capable of creating pearls, but pearls from edible oysters have no market value. The pearls used in jewelry are from the Feathered Oyster in the Pteriidae family. Over the
years, the workers in the Drakes Bay Oyster cannery have found quite a few
small pearls. Ask to see them when you visit the oyster farm!
4.
Oysters taste like the place they are grown. Just as the same grapes grown in different places have site-specific
flavors called “terroir,” the same oysters grown in different places have
site-specific flavors, sometimes called “merroir.” The salinity of the water in
which they are grown and the specific nature of what the oysters eat contribute
to their flavor.  Oyster author Rowan Jacobson has a fun oyster guide at
his website:  What Kind of Oyster Eater Are You?  According to this
guide, Drakes Bay Oysters appeal to “The Clean Freak:  You prefer filter
feeders from pristine waters.” Check out the guide to learn about the handful of other oysters grown in equally pristine
places—two of which are in Canadian national parks (Raspberry Points in Prince
Edward Island National Park and Imperial Eagle Channels in Pacific Rim National
Park).
5. 
Oysters clean the water; for this reason oyster restoration efforts are under
way. Oysters
help waterways by eating algae, filtering out particulates and excess
nutrients, and creating habitat for other organisms to thrive. One oyster can
filter more than 50 gallons of water in 24 hours. The National Oceanic and
Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) is actively promoting oyster restoration,
including restoring native oysters in the
Chesapeake Bay; these efforts are accelerating, especially in Harris Creek, where
22 acres of reefs were built in 2012, and 34 acres are planned for 2013. Oyster
restoration is also under way in Florida,California,and Massachusetts, among other
places. The Oyster Restoration Work Group is very active in this area—read about
their efforts here.
To learn more about the power of the oyster, go to our advocacy site.FOR MORE INFORMATION, VISIT OUR WEBSITES
For
more information about our cause, please visit our advocacy site: http://savedrakesbay.com/core/

For
more information about the oyster farm, including how to visit the farm and
where to purchase our award-winning oysters, please visit our business
site:  http://drakesbayoyster.com/

story:
Your Impact - Every $1 You Donate Distributes $15-$25 Worth of Supplies

  • $25 ships one wheelchair from Minnesota to be donated to someone in Bolivia and will make a huge difference in their life. (Check out pictures of a recent distribution of wheelchairs in Bolivia HERE.)
  • $100 sends 2 large boxes (roughly $1,820 worth) of donated medical, school, and construction supplies from Minnesota to Bolivia, where they are distributed to Mano a Mano projects throughout the country.
  • $20,000 sponsors an entire container shipment of donated surplus supplies worth $300,000-$500,000 from the US to Bolivia - every dollar you give allows us to ship and distribute $15-$25 worth of supplies ($18 shipped per dollar donated has been the average value in recent shipments).


Why Your Donation Is So Important

Your donation helps reduce waste in the US and improve thousands of lives in Bolivia. We have the people and infrastructure in place to collect, ship, and distribute these supplies; what we need is YOUR HELP to help pay for the shipping costs.
Distributes Supplies to Mano a Mano's Network of Clinics and Other Projects in Rural Bolivia

Saving medical, education, and construction supplies from being thrown away in the US, your financial support allows us to ship these supplies to Bolivia where they can be put to good use. Upon their arrival these items are distributed to Mano a Mano's clinics, schools, and other infrastructure projects to provide quality healthcare and services that save lives. 

Distributes Supplies to other Bolivian Organizations and Individuals, Free-of-Charge

We also distribute a significant portion of supplies to other organizations (hospitals, nonprofits, jails) and individuals throughout Bolivia, free-of-charge.

We feel strongly that in order for the supplies we send to reach those people most in need - impoverished Bolivians, primary care clinics and organizations working in small rural communities - we cannot charge these organizations. They simply have no way to pay for these supplies; which is why we need your help. Your donation ensures that those in need have access to the supplies that they desperately need but cannot afford.

Stretches Funding to Have a Bigger Impact

Every item that we are able to ship means one less thing we have to buy or make in Bolivia, allowing us to stretch our funding, complete more projects, and improve more lives. It also reduces domestic waste by preventing thousands of pounds of supplies from being discarded in US landfills.  

Our Goal

Our goal is to ship two 40-foot containers of supplies, valued at a combined $600,000-$1,000,000, with each container costing $20,000 to ship. 

Help us reach this goal and have a hand in the lifesaving work of Mano a Mano!


Our Story


Mano a Mano works with Bolivian communities to create sustainable infrastructure projects that improve health and increase economic well-being. 

In 1994 Mano a Mano was started with the goal of saving medical supplies in the US that were destined for the landfill and sending them to Bolivia, where co-founders Joan and Segundo Velasquez - and their friends and family in the US and Bolivia - knew they could be put to use and save lives. 

Twenty years later, with the help of hundreds of amazing volunteers and donors like YOU, Mano a Mano has shipped over 3.5 million pounds of supplies to Bolivia—supporting the hundreds of projects we have completed, including clinics, schools, roads, water projects, and providing emergency air rescues. 


Equipping Mano a Mano's Network of Clinics with Supplies
Ensuring that our network of clinics is well-supplied is extremely important. 

Without a consistent flow of medical supplies, it is impossible to provide adequate patient care. While the cost of shipping may sound high, many of the supplies we send to Bolivia are either of a higher quality than what is available or cannot even be purchased in Bolivia—making their shipment a necessity. 

It is this consistent flow of supplies (as part of of our ongoing clinic support) which has allowed 100% of our clinics to remain open to this day and provide high-quality care to rural Bolivians.

Shipping School Supplies

Additionally we send school supplies, which are in desperate need. 

In many communities, each student only has one notebook; when they fill it up they go back to the beginning and erase the pages to be able to reuse the notebook over and over. The donation of something as basic as a few pens & pencils and a notebook to each child in a classroom can be an extremely exciting gift. 

Shipping Construction Supplies, Office Furniture, and Other Needed Items

We also ship construction supplies, office furniture, and many other items that help support Mano a Mano's varied programs throughout Bolivia. 

    

Every Item Shipped is Put to Use
Every single item we ship to Bolivia is put to use and stretched as far as possible; our staff cut squares of gauze into quarters, unsterile supplies are used for training in their continuing health education workshops, and pieces of fabric are sewn together to make sheets and curtains. 

What Happens if We Raise More than Our Goal?

Mano a Mano always has a huge backlog for all of our projects - including shipping supplies - and we are only limited by funding. 

Any additional money raised from this campaign would go towards another shipment of supplies later on this year, once we have enough money raised for our next shipment.


What Happens if We Don't Meet Our Goal?

All money raised through this campaign will go towards our next shipment; each container costs $20,000, so if we get near half of our goal then we can ship one container. If we raise less, then we have a base of funding in place for a shipment and will just have to wait a little longer to ship.
We always have a lot of fundraising projects going on that can supplement what we raise on this Indiegogo campaign. 

Bottom line - your financial support during this campaign WILL help make a shipment possible!


Perks

  • At the $50+ level get the opportunity to be present during a supply shipment and pack your own box of surplus supplies at our St. Paul, MN warehouse!
  • At the $100+ level receive a Nino a Nino Bolivian Coffee Package. 
  • All contributions are TAX-DEDUCTIBLE and contributors will receive a 501(c)(3) receipt upon completion of the campaign. 

  • All perks ship FREE-OF-CHARGE within the U.S. ONLY. All perks will ship out upon completion of the campaign. 



Thanks!

Thank you for helping us ship supplies which truly save lives. With your help we can reduce waste in the US and make a huge difference in the lives of thousands of Bolivians.

Thank you for your support!

All contributions are TAX-DEDUCTIBLE and contributors will receive a 501(c)(3) receipt upon completion of the campaign.

story:
Why I'm Running

If you've known me a while, you'll remember a time when there was, quite frankly, a lot more of me. A time when I couldn't go up a flight of stairs without getting a bit huffy and puffy.

70 pounds, 3 Olympic-distance triathlons, 3 half-marathons and countless salads later, it's time to do something I once thought impossible.

A marathon.

I haven't done a marathon yet, this would be my first. It would be the latest in a string of fitness goals that started with me staring at a mirror and not being happy with the reflection, and has continued to a renewed health and fitness. I'm not all the way there yet, but am working on it :)

This is where I need your help. I'll be running the Marine Corps Marathon in Washington, D.C. and Virginia on October 26 as part of the Anacostia Watershed Society's team. 

AWS, a great organization I've been proud to support, has kindly offered to let me run with their team. In return, I'm pledging to raise $500 -- at least, hopefully more -- to help clean up the Anacostia River.

Why Anacostia Watershed Society?

Quite frankly, it could use some help.

Many years ago, the Anacostia was a mighty shipping river, with inland ports offloading goods from far and wide. Generations of silting changed all that, and decades of dumping and industrialization later, it's not safe to swim in. 

The Anacostia Watershed is, quite literally, our home.  I drive or Metro over the river every single day heading from home to work at the Capitol. I do interval training on riverbank trails. Distance runs are logged on the shores of the Paint Branch, which flows into the Anacostia.

And let's not forget: I did marry an environmental biology major. Doing right by the out-of-doors is in our DNA.

The Impact

Money donated in support of my run will go to the Anacostia Watershed Society, the foremost organization working to "Clean the Water, Recover the Shores and Honor the Heritage" of D.C.'s river. 


Their vision is simple: To make the Anacostia River and its tributaries swimmable and fishable.

  • AWS is an IRS-registered 501(c) 3 charitable organization
  • Donations made here will go straight to them for their important work. 

Equally important: Every dollar you donate helps me get that one step closer to a finish line that -- let's be honest -- a couple of years ago may as well have been on Mars.

Now, the impossible seems achievable. With a lot of hard work, puddles of sweat -- and your help -- I think we can get there.

I can't promise I'll finish fast. I can promise that I'll train and try my best.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute at this time, that's OK! Here are other ways to help:

  • Drop me a note of support between now and October 26 -- I'll need all the encouragement I can get!
  • Come join Eeda, Emma & Claire in rooting me on on race day!

Thanks again for your support,
-Derek-

story:
MY PROJECT

Hello, my name is Thomas, I live in East Sussex England and I'm a naturalist that aspires to a career in wildlife conservation. In my work to build a career in conservation this October I completed my Open University Natural Sciences degree and earlier in the year I spent three months volunteering on an RSPB nature reserve in Inverness Scotland.

My next project starting in early 2014 is a one month expedition to travel through the canals of the Norfolk Broads recording species for the biodiversity database Ispot (www.ispot.org.uk). Your support with funding will make this new project a reality.

My expedition will begin on the water close to Potter Heigham, top right of figure 1, and will weave through the canals to finish close to Norwich City as displayed towards the bottom left of figure 1 Below:

Figure 1: Map of the Norfolk Broads (www.tournorfolk.co.uk/maps/norfolkbroads.jpg)

Using the Norfolk Broads to weave through Eastern England is a very economical way to travel and it will allow me to observe, identify and record species in more isolated regions of the country which would be more difficult to get access to if travelling by road. 

My principle intention is to photograph and identify species and to observe how their distribution changes as I travel the canals. I will upload my recordings to Ispot on the go, phone signal allowing. A contribution to helping me complete this expedition will allow me to further the observational and data recording skills I have developed from my studies and volunteering so that I can secure a career role in conservation in the near future.

So far I have Ispot uploaded and identified a number of local East Sussex species, most of these being plants. On this expedition I intend to focus on land based invertebrate species in close proximity to the canals and also invertebrate, plant and algal species living in the water. Every year approximately 15,000 new species are identified globally with a surprising number being in the UK so hopefully I might discover something new.

Ispot is a great free access global database run by the Open University which allows any member of the public to upload photographed species and to pin point them to a specific location. With over 250,000 public species observations Worldwide Ispot is building a comprehensive picture of the ever changing distribution of species.

Figure 2: Ispot biodiversity database home page (www.ispotnature.org/uk-and-ireland)

Funding 

To fund my one month expedition I have purchased a number of pieces of equipment using my savings, these include a life jacket, a portable solar panel and a number of other small items. I still have a further £150 saved of my own money and I require a boost of £1470 from the Indiegogo community. Costs will go principally towards chartering of a small canal boat, supplies and further equipment. My expenditure is as follows:

One month charter of a canal boat: This will be my main expenditure for the expedition and will be the focus of the funding, I have researched the costs and I have budgeted £800-1000 for the chartering of a small boat for one months travel and associated costs such as the fuel and insurance.

From my savings I have purchased the inflatable kayak in figure 3 below which I will take with me on board the canal boat. This kayak will allow me to get closer to wildlife to photograph and identify species when exploring. 

Figure 3: My Intex K1 inflatable kayak 

A months supplies: I require approximately £5 a day for food which for a month’s travel I have budgeted £150. For safe drinking water in emergencies I will purchase a Lifesaver filtration water purifier bottle at £120.

Equipment: I have purchased most of the equipment I require for the trip, the one main item I still require is a waterproof action camera for photographing and filming under water and some waders for entering the water. I've budgeted £200 for this. 

Train Tickets: With my remaining £150 savings I'm going to purchase the return train tickets from Sussex to Norfolk and back. 

Perks 

All my recorded data will be freely available to access via the Ispot website so you can keep up with the species I have uploaded and identified. In supporting me to make this expedition, I will also bring you into the field through my photos and videos which I will be uploading onto youtube via my phone. For making a contribution there is also a series of perks in the form of clothing printed with "I funded Toms expedition" which I will send you once the campaign closes.

I would appreciate if you could help spread the word about my campaign. Share this link with your friends, families and networks! Feel free to contact me and ask any question you’d like about my canal biodiversity expedition and my goals.

Best Wishes

Tom
story_txt:
MY PROJECT


Hello, my name is Thomas, I live in East Sussex England and I'm a naturalist that aspires to a career in wildlife conservation. In my work to build a career in conservation this October I completed my Open University Natural Sciences degree and earlier in the year I spent three months volunteering on an RSPB nature reserve in Inverness Scotland. 
My next project starting in early 2014 is a one month expedition to travel through the canals of the Norfolk Broads recording species for the biodiversity database Ispot (www.ispot.org.uk). Your support with funding will make this new project a reality. 
My expedition will begin on the water close to Potter Heigham, top right of figure 1, and will weave through the canals to finish close to Norwich City as displayed towards the bottom left of figure 1 Below:

Figure 1: Map of the Norfolk Broads (www.tournorfolk.co.uk/maps/norfolkbroads.jpg)
Using the Norfolk Broads to weave through Eastern England is a very economical way to travel and it will allow me to observe, identify and record species in more isolated regions of the country which would be more difficult to get access to if travelling by road. 
My principle intention is to photograph and identify species and to observe how their distribution changes as I travel the canals. I will upload my recordings to Ispot on the go, phone signal allowing. A contribution to helping me complete this expedition will allow me to further the observational and data recording skills I have developed from my studies and volunteering so that I can secure a career role in conservation in the near future.
So far I have Ispot uploaded and identified a number of local East Sussex species, most of these being plants. On this expedition I intend to focus on land based invertebrate species in close proximity to the canals and also invertebrate, plant and algal species living in the water. Every year approximately 15,000 new species are identified globally with a surprising number being in the UK so hopefully I might discover something new.
Ispot is a great free access global database run by the Open University which allows any member of the public to upload photographed species and to pin point them to a specific location. With over 250,000 public species observations Worldwide Ispot is building a comprehensive picture of the ever changing distribution of species.

Figure 2: Ispot biodiversity database home page (www.ispotnature.org/uk-and-ireland)
Funding 
To fund my one month expedition I have purchased a number of pieces of equipment using my savings, these include a life jacket, a portable solar panel and a number of other small items. I still have a further £150 saved of my own money and I require a boost of £1470 from the Indiegogo community. Costs will go principally towards chartering of a small canal boat, supplies and further equipment. My expenditure is as follows:

One month charter of a canal boat: This will be my main expenditure for the expedition and will be the focus of the funding, I have researched the costs and I have budgeted £800-1000 for the chartering of a small boat for one months travel and associated costs such as the fuel and insurance.
From my savings I have purchased the inflatable kayak in figure 3 below which I will take with me on board the canal boat. This kayak will allow me to get closer to wildlife to photograph and identify species when exploring. 


Figure 3: My Intex K1 inflatable kayak 
A months supplies: I require approximately £5 a day for food which for a month’s travel I have budgeted £150. For safe drinking water in emergencies I will purchase a Lifesaver filtration water purifier bottle at £120.
Equipment: I have purchased most of the equipment I require for the trip, the one main item I still require is a waterproof action camera for photographing and filming under water and some waders for entering the water. I've budgeted £200 for this. 

Train Tickets: With my remaining £150 savings I'm going to purchase the return train tickets from Sussex to Norfolk and back. 
Perks 
All my recorded data will be freely available to access via the Ispot website so you can keep up with the species I have uploaded and identified. In supporting me to make this expedition, I will also bring you into the field through my photos and videos which I will be uploading onto youtube via my phone. For making a contribution there is also a series of perks in the form of clothing printed with "I funded Toms expedition" which I will send you once the campaign closes.
I would appreciate if you could help spread the word about my campaign. Share this link with your friends, families and networks! Feel free to contact me and ask any question you’d like about my canal biodiversity expedition and my goals.
Best Wishes
Tom
